We are the leading route-based unattended self-service coffee and convenience food provider in Europe by revenue with more than 475,000 points of sale (“PoS”) in 16 countries as of June 30, 2019, covering approximately 95% of European GDP and approximately 78% of the European population. We held the number one or number two market position based on revenue in 2017 in our ten core markets of Belgium, France, Finland, Italy, the Netherlands, Norway, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland and the United Kingdom. We served over ten million consumers per day via more than 3,800 routes as of June 30, 2019. We operate in a highly fragmented market, which provides growth opportunities, both organically and through accretive acquisitions. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2019, we generated a revenue of €1,580.8 million and an Adjusted EBITDA of €267.7 million, and we would have generated an Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) of €1,604.7 million and an Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) of €271.2 million, achieving 3.8% Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) growth compared to the twelve months ended June 30, 2018, and 18.9% Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) margins. The following map illustrates the countries in which we operate, our geographical segments as of June 30, 2019, and our market positions in the Focus Countries (as defined below) for the year ended December 30, 2017. _Source: OC&C. Market data as of 2017. Our market share in Italy consists of the 2017 market share of Argenta, which we acquired in February 2018. Our market share in the UK consists of the 2017 market share of Selecta combined with (i) the 2017 market share of the UK operations of Pelican Rouge, which we acquired in September 2017, and (ii) the 2017 market share of Express Vending, which we acquired in August 2018._ Our diversified product offering includes both coffee and hot drinks, and we have entered into strong partnerships with global premium coffee brands such as Starbucks and Lavazza, which allow us to benefit from consumers’ increasing preference for premium products, especially coffee, and result in higher margins. We also cater to the impulse-based consumer purchases with offerings of snacks, including healthy options, cold drinks and fresh food sold through traditional impulse PoS as well as our recently introduced MicroMarkets concept. 1 ----- For the twelve months ended June 30, 2019, our Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) as a percentage of the types of items we sell amounted to 56% for coffee and hot drinks, 29% for impulse items, and 15% for other. We serve customers and generate revenue in the workplace/private, on-the-go/public and trading business channels further discussed below: (*) Adjusted Revenue (CS & CS) for the twelve months ended June 30, 2019. Our business model covers the full value chain of the coffee and convenience food Unattended SSR Market, from green bean roasting to brewing to the consumer’s cup, and we have developed industry leading coffee know-how, capabilities, and expertise in connection with these processes. We roast and produce both instant and full bean coffee, which we use in our own PoS, our customers’ PoS and also sell to third parties, and as such, our roaster in Dordrecht, the Netherlands, is an important driver of our coffee expertise. We have created a strong portfolio of high-quality coffee brands, such as our in-house developed Pelican Rouge brand and its craftsmanship image that caters for growing number of consumers increasingly looking for this attribute. Our Pelican Rouge brand complements our premium coffee offering in partnership with Lavazza and Starbucks. We leverage our technology capabilities and data collection from PoS to provide relevant products, gauge consumer preferences and maximize revenue opportunities, which improve consumer experience and customer satisfaction. We also provide cleaning, maintenance, and technical support services which can be customized based on individual customer needs and preferences, even when we do not enter into a full self-service retail service arrangement with the customer. In addition to our unattended self-service and coffee roasting operations, we also sell coffee and machines, including to hotels, restaurants and cafés, and machine parts and products independent of self-service retail service arrangements. Due to the predictable nature of our business and the length of our customer contracts, we believe we are able to achieve high revenue visibility. We benefit from diversified revenue streams secured by multi-year contracts derived from a large and loyal customer base across private and public sector in 2018 and a 100% retention rate with our top ten customers over that period. As of June 30, 2019, we estimate that our average private customer contract term is three to five years, and our average public customer contract term is five to ten years. Moreover, the maintenance and cleaning services we offer as part of our self-service retail services provide us with an additional source of high margin revenues. Innovation and technology are also key drivers of our success, and we benefit from our track record of innovation leadership both in terms of technology upgrades such as cashless payment, touchscreen user interfaces and telemetry, as well as in terms of unattended self-service retail concepts, such as MicroMarkets, to drive daily revenue per PoS and open new routes-to-market. 2 ----- Since our founding in Switzerland in 1957, we have grown organically as well as through acquisitions. On September 7, 2017, we completed the acquisition of the Pelican Rouge Group, which increased our presence in nine of the 15 markets in which we operated at that time, making us the market leader by revenue in France, Spain, the United Kingdom, and Belgium. In addition, on February 2, 2018, we completed the acquisition of the Argenta Group, a leading unattended self-service retail operator in Italy, which became our 16[th] market. On August 17, 2018, we acquired Express Vending, a leading UK supplier of premium unattended self-service retail services, bolstering our position as the leading European provider of route-based unattended self-service coffee and impulse and convenience food offerings, including MicroMarkets, and further consolidated our leading position in the United Kingdom. Express Vending is at the forefront of MicroMarket design and deployment in the UK. Express Vending’s Express HUB brand stores, with open plan refreshment areas, an extensive product range and self-scan kiosks. As a result of these acquisitions, our innovation and technology leadership, and through upgrades of our business, operating systems and corporate culture, we have achieved a leading position in Europe as a routebased unattended self-service retail provider with strong know-how and capabilities in providing coffee and impulse offerings across a range of workplace/private, on-the-go/public and trading business channels. We had average market shares ranging between 10% and 15% in our core markets for the year ended December 30, 2017, compared to approximately 6% of the European market over the same period in 2016, and we served over ten million consumers for the twelve months ended June 30, 2019, compared to approximately 6 million for the year ended September 30, 2016. We see significant opportunities for further organic growth and accretive acquisition-led growth in our highly fragmented markets.

We offer consumers a wide variety of on-the-go food products for everyday consumption and impulse purchases, with a strong focus on coffee, at all hours of the day and every day of the year thanks to our unattended, 24/7, fully automated, convenience retail concept. Our concept targets captive environments and is economically viable even in low footfall locations due to our minimal operational costs compared with traditional retail concepts. Our ability to sell products in convenient retail locations and our high level of customer service has led to an average overall customer retention based on revenue of approximately 95.9% for the twelve months ended June 30, 2019, and approximately 92.5% and 94.4% for each of the years ended September 30, 2017 and 2018, respectively. We believe that the quality of our service levels and our customer relationship management contribute to customer loyalty, leading to an average relationship of approximately 15 years with our 10 largest customers. In addition, contract renewals with our existing long-term customers are typically more profitable than entering into a contract with a new customer, due to savings on equipment and other capital expenditures and customer acquisition costs. Our costs associated with new customers are followed by predictable revenue streams and we usually recoup these costs within two years. We have a scalable routebased business model that we are able to apply across the 16 countries in which we operate with the same key success factors, to drive growth in customers, daily revenue per PoS and profitability. For example, following the Argenta Acquisition in 2018, we have replicated Argenta’s MicroMarkets operating model in other countries such as Switzerland and the Netherlands. Our focus on out-of-home impulse consumption limits our exposure to competition from online retailers and offerings.

Subsubsection Title: Well Positioned to Take Advantage of Premium Coffee and Out-of-Home Consumption Growth
Subsubsection Text: We operate in the convenience food and beverage market, estimated at €42 billion in 2017 (our “Addressable Market”) in our focus countries of France, Germany, Italy, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, the Netherlands, and the United Kingdom (the “Focus Countries”). Within the Addressable Market, we focus on the Unattended SSR Market which has a market size of approximately €16 billion in our 16 countries of operations, of which approximately €15 billion arises in the Focus Countries. Our Addressable Market has grown at a CAGR of 2.1% between 2012 and 2017, reaching a total value of approximately €40.5 billion in the Focus Countries and is expected to grow at a CAGR of 3.1% reaching €47.1 billion by 2022. This trend has been driven by a positive macro-economic backdrop with an increase in GDP and stable employment levels, which have led to increased spending in the workplace channel. In addition, we believe that an increasing preference for drinking premium coffee and out-of-home consumption, increased mobility, and the desire for easy availability of healthy and quality products is driving consumers towards our pan-European on-the-go self-service retail offerings. For 3 ----- example, sales of coffee within the Addressable Market has grown at a CAGR of 2.8% between 2012 to 2017, reaching €16.0 billion, and is expected to grow at a CAGR of 3.9%, reaching €19.4 billion by 2022. Moreover, the growing trend toward premium brands has created a shift in consumer emphasis on high quality product offerings, including organic and name-brand coffee, a trend which we are addressing with our Starbucks, and Lavazza brand partnerships. For example, we are able to offer consumers a premium hot drinks experience, both in the workplace and on-the-go through our long-standing partnership with Starbucks. As of June 30, 2019, we have installed approximately 1,964 Starbucks concepts across Europe, and the price of a coffee sold in our Starbucks on-the-go concept is between 20% to 90% higher than a coffee sold in traditional self-service PoS, and such trends for premium brands support our profitability. Similarly, through our partnership with Lavazza we offer our customers and consumers additional options for a premium coffee experience. As of June 30, 2019, we had over 15,637 PoS selling Lavazza coffee and we estimate that approximately 40,000 PoS will serve Lavazza coffee in the long-term.

Subsubsection Title: Leading Unattended Self-Service Coffee and Convenience Food Provider in the European Unattended SSR Market with Growth above Market
Subsubsection Text: We are the leading route-based unattended self-service coffee and convenience food provider in the Unattended SSR Market, and had an estimated 10% market share by revenue in the Focus Countries for the year ended December 30, 2017, compared to 6% over the same period in 2016. We believe that our adjusted revenue (on a constant scope and constant currency basis) for the year ended September 30, 2018, was approximately 3.5 times that of the second largest market player. As of June 30, 2019, we had operations in 16 European countries, which covered approximately 95% of European GDP and contain approximately 78% of the European population. In 2016, we served over six million consumers per day, which we have nearly doubled to more than ten million consumers served per day. We held the number one or number two market position based on revenue in 2017 in our ten core markets, and we estimate that this market data is still accurate as of the date of this Offering Memorandum. Our sales in these markets represented 90.7% of our revenue for the twelve months ended June 30, 2019. As of June 30, 2019, we operated a network of more than 475,000 active coffee and convenience food and beverage self-service PoS, approximately 2.5 times the number of PoS of the second largest market player. With regards to our suppliers, we believe we are the largest machine buyer in the highly fragmented Unattended SSR Market, making us the customer of choice for our suppliers, which in turn provides us with competitively priced procurement arrangements on, amongst other, a wide selection of market leading machines. The Unattended SSR Market is characterized by fragmentation and intense competition on a local level. We are one of the very few operators on a pan-European level, which increases the appeal of our brands and offerings with consumers and of our services and concepts with customers, as compared with our smaller competitors. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2019, our Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) in each of our three geographic segments was split relatively evenly with Central accounting for 37%, North accounting for 26%, and South, UK & Ireland accounting for 37%. This is in contrast to the second largest market player, over three quarters of whose revenue in its last financial year was derived from Italy alone. In addition, the breadth of our product portfolio enables us to better address consumers’ preferences across geographic segments, including evolving market trends, and to provide a one-stop shop offering for our customers. Additionally, our established brands and unique concepts differentiate us from our competitors and enable us to secure attractive and comprehensive contracts with a variety of suppliers and premium brands, which help us maintain our high market share.

Subsubsection Title: Using Innovation and Technology to Drive Growth and Improve Margins
Subsubsection Text: We use innovation and new technologies to drive our growth and improve margins, and we have a track record of innovation leadership through continuous rollouts of upgrades to our PoS across all geographies. Innovation and technology improve the consumer experience, enhance operational excellence and allow us to further expand our route-based business model. Cashless payment systems and digital touchscreen user interfaces that we are rolling out across our PoS park enhance the consumer experience by providing additional accessibility and simplicity of use, thereby driving number of sales and average transaction size compared to cash transactions. As of June 30, 2019, daily revenue per PoS equipped with cashless technology are on average 10% to 20% higher than PoS that only accept cash, and the average transaction value of products sold from cashless PoS is between 5% to 10% higher, making cashless payment options an important driver in increasing sales from existing PoS. As of June 30, 2019, 95% of our public PoS deployed cashless technology. Telemetry in our PoS allows us to better adjust our pricing and product offerings to drive sales and to more efficiently monitor 4 ----- inventory levels and determine maintenance requirements, which increases our route efficiency and operational excellence, and thereby improves service quality and customer retention. As of June 30, 2019, we had telemetry devices installed in approximately 95% of our public PoS. In addition to technological innovation, we also continue to innovate and introduce new unattended self-service retail concepts, such as MicroMarkets, to adapt to market and consumer trends, increase sales and improve profitability, while reducing capital expenditures.

Subsubsection Title: Route-Based Business Model with High Density on the Last Mile
Subsubsection Text: Our route-based business model combined with our size represents a distinct competitive advantage, particularly on the last mile of service, which allows us to service and supply PoS at an optimized cost level, thereby improving our profitability compared to other competitors. In addition, we continuously optimize the density of our PoS to make routes more efficient, thereby reducing driving time and increasing our ability to service more PoS per hour and more PoS per FTE. We are, therefore, able to offer more competitive pricing at the same profitability point or the same levels of service at a lower price, as compared to less profitable smaller regional players, thereby creating genuine barriers to match our scale. We also use data from our PoS equipped with telemetry and our dedicated team of approximately 150 planners (as of June 30, 2019) to continuously optimize our over 3,800 dense and cost-effective routes. As of June 30, 2019, our 4,900 route merchandizers and 1,400 route technicians were able to service their routes using a fleet of over 5,000 vehicles. The map below illustrates the location of each of our PoS, and shows the density of our route-based networks.

Subsubsection Title: Scale Driven Business Model Creating Attractive Economics and Enhancing Established Market Presence
Subsubsection Text: We have developed a business model with a cost advantage through economies of scale and high density, and we believe it will be difficult for potential competitors to replicate the scale, breadth, and efficiency of our organization. Our scale also enables us to deliver superior customer service by leveraging our knowledge of the industry to provide customers and consumers with a comprehensive range of products and innovative service offerings. These attributes lead to an estimated 5% to 15% EBITDA margin (as defined by and according to OC&C) advantage over smaller competitors. We deploy capital expenditures in order to retain and acquire new customers and do so by acquiring new PoS and refurbishing our existing PoS in order to enhance returns on investment. Capital expenditure for new PoS and refurbishment of existing PoS of the Group typically achieves a ROI ranging from 100% to 250%, depending on the country, with the highest returns in the Netherlands, the UK and Switzerland. We have consistently achieved efficiencies stemming from PoS park rationalization (which includes margin management, relocating PoS to more profitable locations, and decreasing the types of PoS in use) and refurbishment. In addition to the operational advantages explained above we also believe that given our scale we retain a cost advantage over our competitors in terms of pricing from machine suppliers and that our in-house refurbishment and maintenance capabilities also provide us a cost advantage. 5 -----

Subsubsection Title: Attractive Financial Profile with Organic Growth, Profitability and Cash Conversion Momentum
Subsubsection Text: Our business has delivered consistent financial results with resilient Adjusted EBITDA margins and stable cash flow generation, with a non-IFRS cash conversion (calculated as Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) minus Adjusted Net Capital Expenditures (CS & CC), divided by Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC)) of 46.7%, 45.9%, and 52.0% for the years ended September 30, 2016, 2017, and 2018, respectively, and 49.1% for the twelve months ended June 30, 2019. Adjusted EBITDA minus net capital expenditures, divided by Adjusted EBITDA, amounted to 38.2%, 42.5% and 50.8% for the years ended September 30, 2016, 2017 and 2018, respectively, and 49.0% for the twelve months ended June 30, 2019. Following the Pelican Rouge Acquisition, the Argenta Acquisition, and the Express Vending Acquisition, we have also benefited from significant cost synergies including, among others, procurement savings, footprint optimization, headquarters integration, and price harmonization and streamlining. As we continue to realize synergies, our efficiency improves and cash conversion continues on a positive trend. Our strong market positions in key markets, coupled with our ongoing efforts to optimize PoS density and operational efficiencies, increased technology penetration, as well as data analytics across all markets contribute to further enhancing our financial profile and organic growth. Excluding France and the UK, we achieved revenue growth of 4.3% for the year ended September 30, 2018, compared to the year ended September 30, 2017, and 5.2% for the twelve months ended June 30, 2019, compared to the twelve months ended June 30, 2018, while achieving organic revenue growth at constant scope and constant currency (as further described under “Unaudited Non-GAAP Aggregated Financial Information”) of 3.4% and 2.7% during the same respective periods. Additionally, through our continued efforts to install new and upgrade existing PoS as well as optimize our product offering, we have seen a growth of 1.4% in our daily revenue per PoS in the twelve months ended June 30, 2019 compared to the same period in 2018.

Subsubsection Title: Experienced Executive Management Team with Proven Execution Track Record
Subsubsection Text: We have a long and successful track record of attracting and retaining top talent and have continued to invest in a high quality management team in order to most effectively manage our existing operations and execute our strategies. Our senior management team is led by our CEO, David Flochel, Chairman, David Hamill, CFO, Gabriel Pirona, and COO, Pascal Uffer, who have more than 80 years of combined experience and leadership track record with international companies. The senior management team has a strong focus on functional expertise and is complemented by local management teams with regional focus. Over the past three years, the team has successfully led the roll-out of our innovative Starbucks on-the-go concepts, the implementation of our profitable partnership with Lavazza, as well as our MicroMarkets concept, and have successfully progressed the roll-out of new technologies for our PoS across our geographic markets and the integration of the Pelican Rouge and Gruppo Argenta acquisitions. We believe that the collective industry knowledge and leadership of our senior management team will enable them to continue to grow our business and execute our strategies.
We believe that we benefit from the key competitive strengths listed below.

We intend to continue to nurture our strong reputation with our customers and consumers and to deliver consistently superior financial results, in line with our ultimate goal of achieving a culture of excellence. This excellence stems from a driven and successful team combined with a clear, strategic, and consistent framework, according to which we take decisions and run our business. We have identified the following key pillars driving our strategy, as further described below.

The first line for growing our business and improving our margins is excellence in sales, as it is through sales that we increase our pipeline of potential new contracts, increase our new contract gains and maintain our high level of customer retention. Sales excellence is the key driver of our organic growth, and over the last two years we committed a substantial portion of our resources to improving our salesforce effectiveness and further strengthening our relationship with our customers. We focus on performance-led management and increased activity dedicated to new business sales teams and account managers. As part of this initiative, we are engaging in training, coaching on the job and concept selling to enhance the capabilities of our sales force and to lead the 6 ----- execution of our strategies. The tables below show our new contract pipeline, increase in new gains and customer retention since 2017:

Subsubsection Title: Further Developing Pricing and Category Management
Subsubsection Text: We believe that there is a significant opportunity to increase daily revenue per PoS by improving pricing and category management. We have initiated an analytical approach to support decision making and assess the impact of pricing and category management across our footprint. With telemetry now equipped on most of our public PoS, it allows us to analyze sales data and unlock pricing capabilities in ways previously unavailable to us. We believe this gives us an opportunity to continuously optimize performance, with location specific product assortment and pricing initiatives, allowing us to better manage margins on underperforming accounts, upsell our services to B2B customers, and reduce leakage to competing local offerings. We expect pricing and category management efforts to have a more than €10.0 million impact on revenue for our 2019 fiscal year.

Subsection Title: Robust Pipeline Throughout the Year (€m) Continued Net Growth 130 129** **130** **130 114** **26** **20** **21** **5.3% 35** **23** **28** **29 16 (7.5)% 80** **82** **80 Strong Customer Retention Rates 95.8%** **95.9% 93.6%** **94.4% 92.5% Sep-17** **Mar-18** **Sep-18** **Mar-19** **Jun-19 Sep-17** **Mar-18** **Sep-18 Mar-19** **Jun-19 Sep-17** **Mar-18** **Sep-18** **Mar-19** **Jun-19 Losses ARO** **Gains ARO** **Net Growth Negotiation** **Agreed** **Signed
Subsubsection Text: Our route-based business model benefits from the significant increases in productivity resulting from our dense network of PoS and depots, and we are continuously optimizing route density through professional route planning. We thereby leverage our focus on technology and innovation to further improve our operational excellence. For example, the installation of telemetry capabilities in our PoS allows for dynamic route planning and increased efficiency of our refillers by reducing preparation time and enabling the refiller to visit more PoS. Density optimization is also a key consideration in our bolt-on acquisition program, and one of the key drivers of synergy achievement. Our operational excellence is also driven by our success in acquiring and integrating companies, such as Pelican Rouge, Argenta and Express Vending. Led by an integration office reporting to the Board of Directors of the Group, we have identified approximately €75 million in annualized procurement, SG&A and operational synergies that are at being implemented and that we expect to be fully realized by the end of 2020, resulting in a strong margin uplift. In terms of procurement, we expect to achieve up to €30 million of annualized synergies from equipment, ingredients, bought-in goods, disposables, packaging and spares and the in-sourcing of coffee production. SG&A synergies in an amount of up to €13 million include the consolidation of country and group headquarters and the optimization of overhead and corporate costs. We expect to achieve up to €33 million of operational synergies from the transfer of best practices within our group and from an increase in density as a result of depot, merchandizer and technician network optimization and increase in utilization of telemetry capabilities, which drives route efficiency for our refillers.

Subsubsection Title: Continued Roll Out and Focus on Our Technology and Innovation Capabilities
Subsubsection Text: We deem technology and innovation to be a competitive differentiator for our current operations and business going forward. We continue to commit resources and make the necessary investments to be at the forefront of technology and innovation in our industry. Currently, we are managing three footprint-wide key enablers that contribute to an improvement in daily revenue per PoS and operational efficiency. Firstly, we are expanding and upgrading our current PoS base with telemetry technology, a remote PoS monitoring allowing for optimization of cost-to-serve and product availability while leading the transformation toward an end-to-end operating model. Approximately 29% of our eligible PoS park has already been upgraded as of June 30, 2019, while we aim to roll-out telemetry to all eligible PoS across the footprint. Secondly, we are also upgrading our PoS to support cashless technology to enhance check-out experience at the point of sale by providing access to non-cash payment methods, i.e. credit cards and proprietary apps. Approximately 20% of our eligible PoS park has already been upgraded as of June 30, 2019. Thirdly, our MicroMarket concept allows us to introduce an innovative, unique, and attractive format bringing together technology, brands, and operational capabilities while 7 ----- combining the classic vending model (convenience) with the cafeteria model (premium and healthy). While the concept is already established in the UK, Italy, Switzerland and, recently, the Netherlands, we plan to roll-out the format across our other markets to further expand our current footprint of 104 MicroMarkets as of June 30, 2019. For example, we have launched our MicroMarket concept in Spain, where we have already entered into agreements to install MicroMarkets, and in Germany, where we have started discussions with potential customers.

Subsubsection Title: Pursuing Growth Through a Disciplined Capital Expenditure Program
Subsubsection Text: We intend to continue to pursue growth through a disciplined capital expenditure program that provides an attractive return on investment period, while also optimizing the capital intensity of our operations. We have a structured and consistent governance with respect to capital expenditures across our group, with pre-investments business cases and post-investment appraisals and tracking of outcomes. At the same time, we are working to optimize the capital intensity of our operations by refurbishing existing PoS to increase their life and maximizing our refurbishment capabilities and re-siting underperforming PoS. We also intend to continue exploring off-balance sheet funding options, such as our alternative arrangements with Lavazza and other leasing companies, to finance PoS investments for our customers, thereby reducing our initial investment cost for new client contracts. Innovative route-based solutions such as MicroMarkets also have lower capital expenditure requirements than classic impulse purchase offerings, while generating two to three times the revenue of a classic self-service retail site, with each MicroMarket generating an approximate turnover of €50,000 annually. Through these and other initiatives, we intend to reduce our PoS related cash capital expenditures to under €100.0 million per year.

Subsubsection Title: Engaging in Bolt-On Acquisition Opportunities in Our Fragmented Industry
Subsubsection Text: Our reference markets present a fragmented structure with significant bolt-on M&A opportunities, which would allow us to further strengthen our position as the leading unattended self-service coffee and convenience food provider in Europe. Given our scale and market knowledge, we continue to see ourselves as a natural market consolidator. We intend to continue to selectively undertake accretive bolt-on acquisition opportunities to continue our growth, improve our density and improve our technical as well as service capabilities. The Unattended SSR Market is characterized by a large number of operators, which on average tend to be very small in terms of revenue. The following table shows the competitor fragmentation in certain of our key markets:

Subsection Title: Number of** **Average Size of Vending Operators** **Tail [(1)]
Subsubsection Text: **~100–150** **5.7 ~200–250** **0.7 ~1000–1200** **1.7 600–700** **2.2 ~3,000** **0.4 ~100-200** **3.5 1,600–1,900** **0.6 1,000–1,500** **2.1** (1) Average size of tail refers to the average size of our competitors. This fragmentation, and our position as the leader in the Unattended SSR Market, provide us with a large number of bolt-on acquisition opportunities. We have completed five bolt-on acquisitions over the past two years. Each acquisition we make is underpinned by a clear strategy, whether it be to increase density in existing regions, develop market shares, expand our portfolio of offerings, improve technical capabilities in specialized services or some combination of the foregoing. We aim to purchase companies at mid-single-digit EV/EBITDA multiples, and to extract at least a turn of synergies from those acquisitions. Underpinning our success in bolt-on 8 ----- acquisitions is a disciplined execution and integration program that has been proven through our track record of identifying, purchasing at attractive multiples and successfully integrating these bolt-on acquisition opportunities.

Subsection Title: Number of** **Average Size of Vending Operators** **Tail [(1)]
Subsubsection Text: Our people underlie our success, and we believe that our employees are an integral part in successfully executing our strategies. To that end, we are undertaking initiatives related to performance management, sales and operational capabilities, employee engagement and employer branding to ensure we maximize the potential of our talent across our organization. Included among these initiatives are talent reviews of all teams to provide improved management of the talent pools within each of our markets. We have developed a sales and operations academy in order to train and develop our team with the right programs to drive customer satisfaction and efficiencies. We have also worked to improve our employee on-boarding and performance management for our field force, with a focus on developing first-line manager capabilities. In terms of employee engagement, we have created a baseline employee survey in partnership with GALLUP, and plan to implement a tailored action plan based on the survey results for each team. We are also focused on improving our internal communication strategy, with improvement of our intranet, implementation of a new ethics program and the publishing of our first CSR report. We believe that continued implementation of these initiatives, and a focus on the continued development of our people, will support the execution of our strategies.

The Issuer is a private limited liability company (besloten vennootschap met beperkte aansprakelijkheid) incorporated under the laws of the Netherlands. The Issuer is registered with the trade register of the Dutch Chambers of Commerce (Handelsregister van de Kamer van Koophandel) under the number 34256233. The Issuer’s registered business address is Overschiestraat 61-5, 1062 XD Amsterdam, the Netherlands.

Since our founding in Switzerland in 1957, we have grown both organically as well as through acquisitions. Following our first acquisition in Switzerland in 1959, we expanded into Germany in 1986, Sweden and France in 1990, Austria, Slovakia and the Baltic countries in 1995, Belgium in 1997, Spain in 1998, the United Kingdom and Ireland in 2001 and the Netherlands in 2004. In 1985, we were acquired by the Valora group, and, in 1997, we listed on the SIX before de-listing in 2001. In 2001, we were acquired by the Compass group before becoming part of Allianz Capital Partners through its acquisition of our business in 2007. We were acquired by KKR in 2015. In September 2017, we acquired the Pelican Rouge Group, previously known as Autobar Group Ltd, a company incorporated in London in 1925, which engages in roasting and blending, packaging, and self-service retail of coffee in the United Kingdom and internationally. In 2014, Autobar Group changed its name to Pelican Rouge and relocated to Dordrecht, the Netherlands. The coffee brand Pelican Rouge (Roode Pelikaan) was originally founded in 1863 in Antwerp. In February 2018, we acquired the Argenta Group. Since its founding in Carpi, Modena, Italy in 1968, the Argenta Group has grown organically as well as through acquisitions to become the second largest food and beverage self-service retail operator in the Italian market. In 2016, the Argenta Group expanded into southern Italy through the acquisition of Somed, and into the food retail business under the Foodie’s brand and through agreements with 365 Retail Market with its MicroMarket concept. In August 2018, we acquired Express Vending, a leading UK supplier of premium self-service retail services with a focus on London and its neighboring counties. Express Vending’s offering of products and services includes table top coffee machines and MicroMarkets. Express Vending was established in 1992 and is headquartered in Hemel Hempstead, Hertfordshire, Great Britain. We also made three smaller acquisitions in Italy in 2018.

KKR is a leading global investment firm with a long history of investing in Europe. Founded in 1976 and led by Henry Kravis and George Roberts, KKR had $205.7 billion in assets under management as of June 30, 2019. With offices around the world, KKR manages assets through a variety of investment funds and accounts covering multiple asset classes. KKR seeks to create value by bringing operational expertise to its portfolio 9 ----- companies and through active oversight and monitoring of its investments. KKR complements its investment expertise and strengthens interactions with investors through its client relationships and capital markets platforms.

On the Issue Date, we will use the proceeds of the Offering to: (i) repay all amounts outstanding under the Revolving Credit Facility, (ii) fund excess cash on balance sheet for general corporate purposes, and (iii) pay estimated fees and expenses in connection with the foregoing (collectively, the “Refinancing”). See “Use of _Proceeds.”_

We currently estimate our revenue, Adjusted EBITDA and free cash flow for the year ended September 30, 2019, to be in line with our financial guidance publicly disclosed in our quarterly noteholder presentation for the nine months ended June 30, 2019. As of the date of such noteholder presentation, we expected our revenue, Adjusted EBITDA and free cash flow to be between €1,615 million and €1,635 million, between €270 million and €275 million and between €70 million and €80 million, respectively, in each case for the year ended September 30, 2019. We may not, and do not assume any obligation to, update the current, or issue future, financial guidance. These preliminary results, estimates, and guidance have not been audited or reviewed by our auditors, are derived from internal management accounts and are subject to our financial closing procedures. These procedures have not been completed. While we believe these preliminary results and estimates to be reasonable, our actual results could vary from these estimates and these differences could be material and such results are not indicative of our full year results. As such, you should not place undue reliance on this information. This information may not be indicative of the remainder of the quarter or any future period. Financial guidance is inherently uncertain and subject to significant business, economic, currency exchange, financial, regulatory and competitive risks and our actual financial results could different materially from such financial guidance, and in any case should not be relied upon in making your investment decision with respect to the Additional Notes. See “Forward-Looking Statements,” “Risk Factors,” and “Management’s Discussion and _Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations” in this Offering Memorandum for a more complete_ discussion of certain of the factors that could affect our future performance. 10 -----

Interest on the Additional Floating Rate Notes will accrue from October 1, 2019. Form and Denomination . . . . . . . . . .** The Additional Notes will be issued in global form in denominations of €100,000 and integral multiples of €1,000 in excess thereof. The Additional Notes sold outside the United States pursuant to Regulation S of the U.S. Securities Act (the “Regulation S

Subsection Title: Additional Notes”) will initially be issued bearing a temporary ISIN
Subsubsection Text: and common code that different from the ISIN and common code of the applicable Existing Notes sold in reliance on Regulation S. See “Description of the Notes.” On and from the consolidation date, the Regulation S Additional Notes will be consolidated and fully fungible with the Existing Notes sold outside the United States pursuant to Regulation S. The consolidation date for Regulation S Additional Notes will be 40 days after the later of the date of the original issuance of these Regulation S Additional Notes and the last date on which we or any of our affiliates were the owner of Regulation S Additional Notes. 13 ----- Ranking of the Additional Notes . . . .** The Additional Notes will, upon issuance: - be general, senior obligations of the Issuer, secured as set forth under “Description of the Notes—Security”; - rank pari passu in right of payment with all of the Issuer’s existing and future debt that is not subordinated in right of payment to the Additional Notes (including, the obligations of the Issuer under the Existing Notes, the Revolving Credit Facility, certain hedging obligations, if any, and certain other future indebtedness permitted to be incurred under the Indenture); - rank senior in right of payment to all of the Issuer’s future debt that is subordinated in right of payment to the Additional Notes; - be guaranteed by the Guarantors, in each case on a senior secured basis, which also guarantee the Existing Notes and the Revolving Credit Facility, as described below under “—Guarantees”; - be effectively subordinated to any existing and future indebtedness or obligation of the Issuer and its subsidiaries (including obligations to trade creditors) that is secured by property or assets that do not constitute Collateral, to the extent of the value of the property or assets securing such obligation or indebtedness; and - be structurally subordinated to any existing or future indebtedness of subsidiaries of the Issuer (including obligations to trade creditors) that do not guarantee the Notes. Guarantors . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** AB Servicios Selecta España SLU, Acorn Spain 1 SLU, Argenta, Pelican Rouge Coffee Roasters B.V., Selecta AB, Selecta AG, Selecta Belgium N.V., Selecta Nordic Holding AB, Selecta Holding SAS, Selecta Netherlands B.V., Selecta SAS, Selecta TMP AG, Selecta U.K. Limited and Selecta UK Holding Limited. Guarantees . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** On the Issue Date, the Additional Notes will be guaranteed on a senior secured basis by the Guarantors (the “Guarantees”). The Guarantors also guarantee the Existing Notes and the Revolving Credit Facility on a senior secured basis. As of and for the twelve months ended June 30, 2019, the Guarantors accounted for approximately 97.7% of the consolidated total assets of the Group, approximately 89.8% of the consolidated revenue (before the impact of vending fee harmonization) of the Group and approximately 88.8% of the Adjusted EBITDA. Each Guarantee is subject to the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement and certain contractual and legal limitations. See “Description of _Other Indebtedness—Intercreditor Agreement,” “Certain Insolvency Law_ _Considerations_ _and_ _Limitations_ _on_ _the_ _Validity_ _and Enforceability of the Guarantees and the Security Interests.” By_ virtue of these limitations, a Guarantor’s obligation under its Guarantee could be significantly less than amounts payable with respect to the Additional Notes, or a Guarantor may have effectively no obligation under its Guarantee. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related _to the Notes—Corporate benefit, financial assistance laws, capital maintenance and other limitations on the Guarantees and the Collateral may adversely affect the validity and enforceability of the Guarantees and the Collateral.” In addition, the Guarantees may be_ released under certain circumstances. See “Description of the Notes— _Brief Description of the Notes and the Guarantees—The Guarantees”_ and “Certain Insolvency Law Considerations and Limitations on the 14 ----- _Validity and Enforceability of the Guarantees and the Security Interests.”_ Ranking of the Guarantees . . . . . . . .** Each Guarantee will: - be a general senior obligation of the relevant Guarantor; - rank pari passu in right of payment with all of such Guarantor’s existing and future debt that is not subordinated in right of payment to its Guarantee (including, its Guarantee granted in favor of the Existing Notes, the Revolving Credit Facility, and certain hedging obligations, if any); - rank senior in right of payment to all of such Guarantor’s future debt that is subordinated in right of payment to its Guarantee; - rank effectively senior to any existing and future unsecured debt of such Guarantor, to the extent of the value of the Collateral that is available to satisfy the obligations under the Guarantees; - rank effectively senior to any existing and future debt of such Guarantor secured on a second-ranking basis by property or assets that secure the Guarantee on a first-ranking basis; - be effectively subordinated to any existing and future debt of that Guarantor (including obligations to trade creditors) that is secured by property or assets that do not constitute Collateral, to the extent of the value of the property and assets securing such obligations or indebtedness; and - be structurally subordinated to any existing and future debt of such Guarantor’s subsidiaries (including obligations to trade creditors) that do not guarantee the Notes. Security . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** On the Issue Date, subject to certain agreed security principles, certain perfection requirements and Permitted Collateral Liens (as defined under “Description of the Notes—Certain Definitions— Permitted_ _Collateral_ _Liens”),_ the Additional Notes and the Guarantees will be secured by: - Dutch law share pledge over the shares in the Issuer; - Dutch law intra-group receivables pledge or assignment by way of security in respect of loans or other receivables owed by the Issuer to MidCo; - Dutch law bank account pledge of the material bank accounts of the Issuer; - bank account pledges of the material bank accounts of certain Guarantors; - intra-group receivables pledges or assignments by way of security in respect of loans or other structural intragroup receivables of certain Guarantors and certain security providers; and - share pledges over the shares in the Guarantors, (together, the “Collateral”). The Collateral also secures, on an equal and ratable basis, but subject to the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement, the liabilities under the Existing Notes, the Revolving Credit Facility, certain hedging obligations, and certain other future indebtedness permitted to be incurred and secured on the Collateral. Under the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement, in the event of enforcement of the security 15 ----- interests over the Collateral, holders of Additional Notes will receive proceeds from the Collateral only after the Revolving Credit Facility, certain hedging obligations and certain other indebtedness permitted to be incurred on a priority basis under the Indenture, if any, have been repaid in full. See “Description of Other Indebtedness— _Intercreditor Agreement.”_ The security interests may be limited by applicable law or subject to certain defenses that may limit their validity and enforceability. For more information on the security interests granted, see “Description _of the Notes—Security” and for more information on potential_ limitations to the security interests, see “Certain Insolvency Law _Considerations and Limitations on the Validity and Enforceability of the Guarantees and the Security Interests” and “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Notes.” In addition, the security interests in the_ Collateral may be released under certain circumstances. Subject to the Indenture and the Intercreditor Agreement, the Collateral may be pledged to secure future indebtedness. For more information on the security interests granted, see “Description of the Notes—Security” and for more information on potential limitations to the security interests, see “Certain _Insolvency_ _Law_ _Considerations_ _and _Limitations on the Validity and Enforceability of the Guarantees and the Security Interests” and “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Notes.”_ Use of Proceeds . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** On or around the Issue Date, we will use the proceeds of the Offering to: (i) repay all amounts outstanding under the Revolving Credit Facility, (ii) fund excess cash on balance sheet for general corporate purposes and (iii) pay estimated fees and expenses in connection with the foregoing. See “Use of Proceeds.”

Euro Fixed Rate Notes . . . . . . . . . . . . The Issuer may redeem all or part of the Euro Fixed Rate Notes on or after February 1, 2020, at the redemption prices set forth under “Description _of_ _the_ _Notes—Optional_ _Redemption—Optional _Redemption of the Euro Fixed Rate Notes,” plus accrued and unpaid_ interest and additional amounts, if any, to the date of redemption. Prior to February 1, 2020, the Issuer may on any one or more occasions redeem up to 40% of the original principal amount of the Euro Fixed Rate Notes issued under the Indenture (including the original principal amount of any additional Notes), using the net proceeds from certain equity offerings at a redemption price equal to 105.875% of the principal amount of the Euro Fixed Rate Notes so redeemed, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but not including, the applicable date of redemption; provided that at least 50% of the original principal amount of the Euro Fixed Rate Notes (including any additional Euro Fixed Rate Notes), issued under the Indenture (excluding Euro Fixed Rate Notes held by the Issuer and its subsidiaries) remains outstanding after each such redemption. Prior to February 1, 2020, the Issuer may redeem up to 10% of the aggregate principal amount of the Euro Fixed Rate Notes originally issued (including the aggregate principal amount of any additional Notes issued) in each calendar year, commencing on the Issue Date, at a redemption price equal to 103% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, up to the redemption date. See “Description of the Notes—Optional _Redemption—Optional Redemption of the Euro Fixed Rate Notes.”_ 16 ----- In addition, prior to February 1, 2020, the Issuer may redeem all or, from time to time, part of the Euro Fixed Rate Notes at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount of the Euro Fixed Rate Notes plus the applicable “make-whole” premium described in this Offering Memorandum and accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but not including, the applicable date of redemption. Floating Rate Notes . . . . . . . . . . . . . . The Issuer may at any time redeem all or part of the Floating Rate Notes, at the redemption prices set forth under “Description of the _Notes—Optional Redemption—Optional Redemption of the Floating Rate Notes,” plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts,_ if any, to the date of redemption.

Redemption . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** All payments made by the Issuer or any Guarantor under or with respect to the Notes or the Guarantees will be made without withholding or deduction for taxes or other governmental charges in any Relevant Taxing Jurisdiction (as defined in “Description of the _Notes—Withholding Taxes”), except to the extent required by law. If_ any such withholding or deduction is required by law, the Issuer or the relevant Guarantor will pay additional amounts so that the net amount you receive is no less than that which you would have received in the absence of such withholding or deduction, subject to certain exceptions. See “Description of the Notes—Withholding _Taxes.”_ If certain changes in the law of any Relevant Taxing Jurisdiction become effective that would impose withholding taxes or other deductions on the payments on the Notes, the Issuer may redeem the Notes in whole, but not in part, at any time, at a redemption price of 100% of the principal amount, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to the date of redemption. See “Description of the Notes—Redemption for Taxation Reasons.” Qualified Reopening** . . . . . . . . . . . . For U.S. federal income tax purposes, the Issuer intends to treat the Additional Notes offered hereby as issued pursuant to a “qualified reopening” of the Existing Notes. If the issuance of the Additional Notes offered hereby is so treated, then the Additional Notes offered hereby will be deemed to have the same issue date, the same issue price and the same adjusted issue price as the Existing Notes. Accordingly, the Additional Notes offered hereby will be considered to be issued at par, even though, considered separately, the Additional Notes offered hereby might be considered to be issued at a premium or a discount. See “Certain Taxation Considerations—Certain U.S. _Federal_ _Income_ _Tax_ _Considerations—Qualified_ _Reopening_ _and Fungibility with the Existing Notes.”_ Change of Control . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** Upon the occurrence of certain change of control events, the Issuer will be required to offer to repurchase all outstanding Notes at a purchase price equal to 101% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest to the date of the purchase (subject to the right of holders of record on the relevant record date to receive interest due on the relevant interest payment date). A change of control, however, will not be deemed to have occurred if a specified consolidated total net leverage ratio is not exceeded in connection with such event. See “Description of the Notes—Change of Control.” 17 ----- Tender Offers . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** In connection with certain tender offers for the Notes, if holders of not less than 90% in aggregate principal amount of the applicable outstanding Notes validly tender and do not withdraw such Notes in such tender offer and the Issuer, or any third party making such a tender offer in lieu of the Issuer, purchases, all of the Notes validly tendered and not withdrawn by such Holders, the Issuer or such third party will have the right to redeem the Notes that remain outstanding in whole, but not in part, following such purchase at a price equal to the price offered to each other holder of Notes. See “Description of _the Notes—Optional Redemption.”_ Certain Covenants . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** The Indenture limits, among other things, the ability of the Issuer to: - incur or guarantee additional indebtedness and issue certain preferred stock; - pay dividends on, redeem or repurchase our capital stock; - make certain restricted payments and investments; - transfer or sell assets; - enter into transactions with affiliates; - create or incur certain liens; - impose restrictions on the ability of our subsidiaries to pay dividends or make other payments to us; - merge or consolidate with other entities, or make certain asset sales; and - impair the security interests in the Collateral for the benefit of the holders of the Notes. Certain of the covenants and events of default will be suspended if and for as long as we achieve investment grade ratings. See “Description _of_ _the_ _Notes—Certain_ _Covenants—Suspension_ _of _Covenants on Achievement of Investment Grade Status.”_ Each of the covenants in the Indenture is subject to significant exceptions and qualifications. See “Description of the Notes—Certain _Covenants.”_ Transfer Restrictions . . . . . . . . . . . .** The Additional Notes and the Guarantees have not been registered under the Securities Act or the securities laws of any other jurisdiction and will not be so registered. The Additional Notes are subject to restrictions on transferability and resale. See “Notice to _Investors.” Holders of the Additional Notes will not have the benefit_ of any exchange or registration rights. Listing . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** Application will be made to The International Stock Exchange Authority Limited (the “Authority”) for the listing of and permission to deal in the Additional Notes on the Official List of The International Stock Exchange (the “Exchange”). There can be no assurance that the Additional Notes will be listed on the Official List of the Exchange, that such permission to deal in the Additional Notes will be granted or that such listing will be maintained. Accordingly, we cannot assure you that an active trading market for the Additional Notes will be maintained. Risk Factors . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** Investing in the Additional Notes involves substantial risks. You should consider carefully all the information in this Offering Memorandum and, in particular, you should evaluate the specific risk factors set forth in the “Risk Factors” section before making a decision whether to invest in the Additional Notes. 18 ----- Governing Law . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** The Additional Notes will be and the Indenture is governed by New York law. The Intercreditor Agreement and the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement are governed by English law. The Security Documents (as defined in “Description of the Notes”) are governed by the laws of the Netherlands, Belgium, England and Wales, France, Italy, Spain, Sweden, and Switzerland. Transfer Agent . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** Elavon Financial Services DAC, UK Branch. Listing Agent** . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . Carey Olsen Corporate Finance Limited. 19 -----

Subsubsection Text: (a) These items represent restructuring and redundancy costs relating to headcount reductions and efficiency programs. For the nine months ended June 30, 2019, this item mainly includes restructuring and reductions in France (€3.0 million), Germany (€0.9 million), Italy (€0.7 million) and Sweden (€0.6 million). For the nine months ended June 30, 2018, this item mainly includes restructuring and reductions in Spain (€4.8 million), France (€2.2 million), the Netherlands (€2.3 million), Norway (€0.7 million) and our headquarters (€0.7 million). For the year ended September 30, 2018, this item mainly includes restructuring and reductions in Spain (€5.2 million), France (€4.9 million), the Netherlands (€2.7 million), Norway (€1.1 million) and our headquarters (€2.0 million). For the year ended September 30, 2017, this item mainly includes restructuring and reductions in personnel expenses in Sweden (€1.1 million), France (€0.7 million), Switzerland (€0.6 million) and in the United Kingdom (€0.4 million). For the year ended September 30, 2016, this item mainly includes restructuring and reductions in personnel expenses in the United Kingdom (€1.0 million), France (€8.0 million) and Switzerland (€1.3 million). (b) For the nine months ended June 30, 2019, this item mainly represents growth development projects of €3.4 million to enhance our market share and reduce costs in Switzerland, sales and pricing projects of €1.3 million and smaller development projects across a range of countries. For the nine months ended June 30, 2018, this item mainly represents growth development projects to enhance our market share and reduce costs in Switzerland, Group IT and infrastructure projects as well as smaller fees for financial experts and software developments. For the year ended September 30, 2018, this item mainly represents growth development projects of €1.7 million to enhance our market share and reduce costs in Switzerland, Group IT and infrastructure projects of €0.9 million and smaller fees for financial experts and software developments. For the year ended September 30, 2017, this item represents €6.0 million relating to outsourcing of Selecta’s IT infrastructure, €3.1 million relating to ERP development expenses, €0.7 million in connection with the consolidation of our headquarters in Switzerland, and €4.2 million in connection with various strategic initiatives across the Group. For the year ended September 30, 2016, this item mainly represents €9.0 million of consultancy costs relating to strategic initiatives across the Group. (c) This item represents transaction costs incurred in connection with the acquisition and integration of Pelican Rouge, Argenta and Express Vending for each relevant period. (d) This item represents the net (profit)/loss of the disposals of our operations in Eastern Europe for the year ended September 30, 2016, in three Baltic countries for the year ended September 30, 2017, in Finland and the disposal of Custompack Ltd. for the year ended September 30, 2018, and a true up of accruals compared to invoiced amounts for the cost of disposal of Custompack Ltd. for the nine months ended June 30, 2019. (e) For the nine months ended June 30, 2019, this item mainly represents transaction costs incurred in connection with strategic transactions and this Offering. For the year ended September 30, 2018, this item mainly represents transaction costs incurred in connection with the offering of the Existing Notes. (f) For the nine months ended June 30, 2019, this item primarily related to one-off expenses in connection with telemetry upgrades across the group (€7.5 million), consulting and legal expenses related to merger and acquisitions activity (€2.8 million) and other one-off expenses in connection with certain projects in France, Belgium (warehouse consolidation) and the Netherlands (logistic and efficiency initiatives). For the nine months ended June 30, 2018, this item primarily related to one-off expenses in connection with telemetry upgrades and expenses related to merger and acquisition activity. For the year ended September 30, 2018, this item primarily related to various one-off expenses incurred by our acquired businesses and consulting expenses. For the year ended September 30, 2017, this item primarily relates to non-recurring costs including costs in connection with a VAT settlement payment in Germany. For the year ended September 30, 2016, this item primarily related to one-time adjustments relating to PoS rebates, revenues and inventory. (3) Adjusted EBITDA margin for a given period represents Adjusted EBITDA for that period divided by revenue net of vending fee for that period. 24 ----- (4) Net capital expenditures consist of gross capital expenditures, less the book value of total disposals of self-service retail equipment (which includes old PoS sold in such period).

Section Title: SUMMARY HISTORICAL FINANCIAL AND OTHER INFORMATION
SUMMARY HISTORICAL FINANCIAL AND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: (a) Represents estimated annualized run-rate cost savings and synergies, which we expect to realize as a result of the Pelican Rouge Acquisition and the Argenta Acquisition. In total, we expect to realize approximately €75 million of annualized run-rate cost synergies from these acquisitions by the end of 2020. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2019, we estimate that we have realized approximately €52 million of these cost synergies, which represents 69% of our total expected cost synergies. See “Risk Factors— _Risks Related to Our Business—We may not be able to realize the anticipated operational efficiencies and cost savings in connection with acquisitions (including the Pelican Rouge Acquisition, the Argenta Acquisition and the Express Vending Acquisition)” and “Forward-Looking Statements.” Our total estimated cost synergies include the following:_ - Operating cost savings relating to logistics and footprint optimizations of approximately €33 million, of which we had realized €18 million as of June 30, 2019. These savings are currently being realized by (i) combining operations in areas with fewer PoS to reduce the number of employees required to maintain and refill these PoS, (ii) implementing Selecta’s refiller planning program, which is based on actual sales of each PoS rather than a theoretical model, (iii) cost savings by increasing the use of telemetry for PoS in France, Spain and the UK (iv) headcount reductions following the assessment of productivity of our technicians and through the integration of corporate, IT and other central functions, (v) footprint optimization by concentrating warehouses in the countries where both Selecta and Pelican Rouge operate, and (vi) logistics network synergies, including planning denser and more cost-effective routes. - Procurement savings of approximately €30 million, of which we had realized €22 million as of June 30, 2019. These savings are currently being realized by (i) obtaining better prices on ingredients through in-sourcing of our own brand coffee from Pelican Rouge’s roaster facility and international tender of raw materials used across the countries in which we operate, such as sugar, (ii) harmonizing prices of products we purchase for our PoS (such as snacks or cold drinks) by leveraging our scale and negotiating prices through strategic relationships at the Group level, (iii) savings on disposables, such as cups for our PoS, and packaging through leveraging our increased purchasing volume at the Group level, (iv) streamlining purchases of spare parts for our machines, (v) indirect cost savings on our fleet, IT, marketing, and warehouses, and (vi) real estate savings as a result of terminating redundant leases and renegotiating existing leases. - Selling, general, and administrative cost savings of approximately €13 million, of which we had realized €12 million as of June 30, 2019. These savings are currently being realized through (i) headcount reductions as a result of integrating management teams in countries where both Selecta and Pelican Rouge operate and re-sizing our sales force, (ii) savings in connection with headcount reductions in the research and development department of the Group by leveraging Argenta’s research and development expertise, (iii) reductions in employee benefit expenses, such as cars, travel, and mobile phones, in connection with headcount reductions, (iv) combining headquarters in countries where both Selecta and Pelican Rouge operate, and (v) additional productivity gains in sales, general and administrative costs. As of June 30, 2019, we estimate that we have incurred approximately €25 million in costs and capital expenditures to implement the foregoing synergies, and estimate that we will incur approximately €28 million in further costs and capital expenditures to 25 ----- realize our total targeted cost synergies. In particular, we expect to incur (i) total estimated severance costs of approximately €24 million, of which approximately €10 million have already been incurred as of June 30, 2019, and (ii) estimated integration costs of approximately €29 million, of which approximately €14 million have already been incurred as of June 30, 2019. Although it is our objective to reach the levels of projected synergies reflected above, no assurance can be given that such levels will be achieved in the timeframe indicated or at all or that additional unanticipated costs will not arise. We currently estimate the majority of the cost to achieve the anticipated synergies to be personnel reductions and related costs that may be required under the laws of the various countries where we operate, which we expect to continue incurring over the course of the next one to two years. As part of our reorganization plan, we are required to negotiate severance payments with worker representatives (labor unions) for FTEs being made redundant pursuant to a collective dismissal procedure provided under applicable regulations in various of the countries where we operate. While we fully intend to observe the relevant legal procedures and requirements and to negotiate in good faith, if we cannot reach an agreement on severance payments with such worker representatives or the employees, they may choose to bring administrative or judicial challenges, which could delay the achievement of our synergies and/or increase costs incurred in order to achieve such synergies. Our synergy estimates are based on a number of assumptions made in reliance on the information available to us and our judgments based on such information. The assumptions used in estimating synergies are inherently uncertain and are subject to significant business, economic and competitive risks and uncertainties that could cause our actual results to differ materially from those contained in the synergy benefit estimates, including those described in “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Business—We may not be _able to realize the anticipated operational efficiencies and cost savings in connection with acquisitions (including the Pelican Rouge Acquisition, the Argenta Acquisition and the Express Vending Acquisition).” See also “Forward-Looking Statements.”_ (6) Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA margin for a given period represents Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA for that period divided by revenue net of vending fee for that period.

See “Use of Proceeds.” As adjusted net debt assumes the Revolving Credit Facility was undrawn as of June 30, 2019. (2) As adjusted cash interest expense represents the estimated cash interest expense of the Group for the twelve months ended June 30, 2019, adjusted to give effect to the Offering and the application of the proceeds therefrom, as if they had occurred on July 1, 2018, assuming the Revolving Credit Facility was undrawn and excluding cash interest payments made under finance leases, bilateral lending facilities, factoring agreements and payments under operating lease agreements not recorded on the balance sheet. As adjusted cash interest expense has been presented for illustrative purposes only and does not purport to represent what our cash interest payments would have actually been had the Offering occurred on the date assumed, nor does it purport to project our cash interest payments for any future period or our financial condition at any future date. 28 -----

Section Title: SUMMARY HISTORICAL FINANCIAL AND OTHER INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: _The following tables summarize certain of our historical consolidated financial information, Unaudited Non-GAAP Aggregated Financial Information and certain other information for the periods ended on and as of the dates indicated below. We have extracted the Group’s summary financial information set forth below (i) with respect to the historical summary consolidated financial information of the Issuer as of and for the financial years ended September 30, 2016, 2017 and 2018, and for the nine months ended June 30, 2018 and 2019, from our Historical Financial Statements and (ii) with respect to the unaudited aggregated financial information for the years ended September 30, 2016, 2017 and 2018, the nine months ended June 30, 2018 and 2019, and the twelve months ended June 30, 2019 from the Unaudited Non-GAAP Aggregated Financial Information, each included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. For a detailed description of the basis of presentation with respect to the historical financial information and Unaudited Non-GAAP Aggregated Financial Information, see “Presentation of Financial and Other Information” and “Unaudited Non-GAAP Aggregated Financial Information.” The Unaudited Non-GAAP Aggregated Financial Information and any other non-GAAP measures presented below have not been prepared in accordance IFRS or any generally accepted accounting standards nor with the requirements of Regulation S-X of the Securities Act, the Prospectus Regulation, or any other regulations of the Securities Exchange Commission, or any other regulator. See “Presentation of Financial and Other Information—Non-GAAP Financial Information.” They are not, and do not purport to be, pro forma financial data that has been prepared, audited, or reviewed in accordance with any generally accepted accounting or auditing standards, and they should not be read as such. These non-GAAP measures have been derived by applying adjustments to the Historical Financial Statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum and do not purport to represent what our results of operations or financial position actually would have been if the events had occurred on the dates assumed, and to project our results of operations or financial condition for any future period. Neither the assumptions underlying our adjustments nor the resulting Unaudited Non-GAAP Aggregated Financial Information have been audited or reviewed in accordance with any generally accepted auditing standards. Any differences between the summary Unaudited Non-GAAP Aggregated Financial Information and our future results of operations and financial position may be material. The summary Unaudited Non-GAAP Aggregated Financial Information should be read in conjunction with our Historical Financial Statements and the notes and the section “Unaudited Non-GAAP Aggregated Financial Information.” You should read the information set forth below in conjunction with the sections “Presentation of Financial and Other Information,” “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations,” “Selected Historical Financial Data,” “Use of Proceeds,” and “Capitalization” and the Historical Financial Statements and the notes thereto included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. Our historical results do not necessarily indicate results that may be expected for any future period._ 20 -----

Subsubsection Title: Changes in general economic conditions, consumer confidence and consumer spending could have an adverse effect on our business.
Subsubsection Text: Demand for snacks, hot and cold beverages and in-between meals correlates with consumer confidence and employment levels. Changes in general economic conditions directly impact consumer confidence and consumer spending, as well as the general business climate. Therefore, our results of operations and financial performance are subject to changes in the general economic conditions of the markets in which we sell our products. In particular, changes in consumer confidence and consumer spending as a consequence of changes to general economic conditions could have a material adverse impact on our business. Moreover, consumer confidence, consumer spending and general economic conditions may deteriorate significantly and remain depressed for an extended period. A negative development in general economic conditions or consumer confidence and consumer spending could have a negative effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. Downturns in general economic conditions and uncertainties regarding future economic prospects, which affect consumers’ disposable income, pose a risk to our business because consumers and businesses may adjust their spending in response to tighter credit markets, unemployment, negative financial news or declines in income or asset values, which could have a material adverse effect on demand for our products. Many factors affect discretionary spending, including general business conditions, inflation, interest rates, consumer debt levels, unemployment rates, foreign currency exchange rates and availability of consumer credit. These and other such macroeconomic factors are outside our control. Recessionary conditions and uncertainty in the macroeconomic environment may also adversely influence our customers’ decision to contract for a self-service PoS on their premises as well as consumers’ discretionary consumption patterns. A majority of our PoS are located in office environments or other private self-service retail locations. Consequently, the majority of our sales from such PoS occur during the working week. There is therefore a correlation between the total number of items sold through our PoS and work force levels and the total number of hours worked which tend to suffer during recessionary periods. Additionally, general strikes by employees, particularly temporary halts in public transport, would reduce the exposure of our PoS to consumers and decrease our sales volume. For example, during the railway strikes in France we estimate our revenue from those points of sale declined by approximately €3 million between March and July 2018 compared to the same period in 2017. Employee retrenchment, strikes, or uncertain economic prospects may lead customers to decide against investing in PoS and may lead consumers to make fewer beverage, snack and impulse purchases from our PoS, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsubsection Title: The success of our business depends on consumer preferences, technological innovations and the consumer’s experience with the self-service PoS we operate.
Subsubsection Text: We are a route-based unattended self-service coffee and convenience food provider operating in the highly competitive segments of the food and beverage market serving hot and cold beverages, in-between meals, snacks, and confectionary products. Changes in consumer preferences could affect both the demand for new PoS and the volume of products we sell from our PoS. Any significant changes in consumer preferences or our inability to anticipate or react to such changes could result in reduced demand for our products and erosion of our competitive and financial position. Our success depends on our ability to respond to consumer trends, including 29 ----- changing tastes, food fads and concerns of consumers regarding health and wellness, obesity, and product attributes and ingredients, as well as our ability to address special dietary requirements or preferences. In addition, changes in product category consumption or consumer demographics could result in reduced demand for our products. Consumer preferences may shift due to a variety of factors, including a preference for healthy eating, sustainable packaging, the aging of the general population, changes in social trends, changes in travel, workplace, vacation or leisure activity patterns, weather, or negative publicity arising from environmental concerns, or resulting from regulatory action or litigation against companies in the snack food and beverage industries. Furthermore, as millennials begin to form larger portions of the consumer pool, adapting our sales and marketing strategies to complement their purchasing habits will become increasingly important to our business. Any of these or other changes may reduce consumers’ willingness to purchase the products we sell and may require us to incur unplanned costs to respond to these changes, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. In addition, existing technologies may develop further in the fields where we operate, which could impact our business and require significant investments. For example, wireless technology has developed as a practical medium through which cashless payments can be made.
