Subsubsection Title: The Additional Notes sold pursuant to Regulation S of the Securities Act (the “Regulation S Additional Notes”) will be initially issued with a temporary ISIN and common code. In the event that we are unable to transfer the Regulation S Additional Notes to the permanent ISIN and common code, the Regulation S Additional Notes will continue to trade under an ISIN and common code different from the ISIN and common code of the applicable Existing Notes sold pursuant to Regulation S of the Securities Act (the “Regulation S Existing Notes”), which may adversely affect the liquidity of the Regulation S Additional Notes and cause the Regulation S Additional Notes to trade at different prices than the Regulation S Existing Notes.
Subsubsection Text: Once the Regulation S Additional Notes offered hereby have become freely tradeable upon the expiration of the restrictive period under Regulation S, we expect that the Additional Notes will share a single ISIN and common code with the Regulation S Existing Notes and the Regulation S Additional Notes and the Regulation S Existing Notes will thereafter be fungible. However, in the event that we are unable to transfer the Regulation S Additional Notes to the permanent ISIN and common code, the Regulation S Additional Notes will continue to trade under separate ISIN and common codes to the Regulation S Existing Notes, which may adversely affect the liquidity of the Regulation S Additional Notes and cause the Regulation S Additional Notes to trade at different prices than the Regulation S Existing Notes. 60 -----

Subsection Title: Participations”) which aggregate more than 50% of the total Senior Secured Credit Participations at that time
Subsubsection Text: (the “Majority Senior Secured Creditors”) (in each case acting through their respective creditor representatives). If the Majority Senior Secured Creditors do not instruct the Security Agent to enforce, or instruct the Security Agent to cease enforcing the transaction security, then creditors holding more than 50% of the total second lien credit participations (or, in certain cases, creditors holding 50% of the total topco credit participations) may instruct the Security Agent to enforce. Following the Designation Date, the Security Agent is not required to take enforcement action unless instructed to do so by an instructing group that may consist of either (i) the Majority Senior Secured Creditors or (ii) creditors holding more than 50% of the total participations in Super Senior Liabilities at that time (the “Majority Super Senior Creditors”). The Security Agent is required to act in accordance with instructions received from the Majority Senior Secured Creditors, however: (i) if and to the extent the obligations under the Super Senior Liabilities have not been fully discharged in cash within six months of enforcement instructions first being issued by either the Majority Senior Secured Creditors or the Majority Super Senior Creditors; or (ii) if Security Agent has not commenced enforcement action within three months of enforcement instructions first being issued by either the Majority Senior Secured Creditors or the Majority Super Senior Creditors, then the enforcement instructions provided by the Majority Super Senior Creditors will prevail. Following the transaction security having become enforceable, a creditor representative acting on behalf of the Majority Super Senior Creditors or the Majority Senior Secured Creditors may at any time provide immediate enforcement instructions to the Security Agent if the Majority Super Senior Creditors or the Majority Senior 51 ----- Secured Creditors determine in good faith that to delay the taking of any enforcement action could reasonably be expected to have a material adverse effect on the Security Agent’s ability to enforce any transaction security or the realization of enforcement proceeds. In such circumstances, the Security Agent shall act only with respect to the relevant asset or debtor that is the subject of such determination, in accordance with the first such notice of such determination and instructions as to enforcement received by the Security Agent, provided in each case that they are consistent with certain security enforcement principles. If at any time an insolvency event has occurred with respect to any debtor (other than an insolvency event which is the direct result of any action taken by the Security Agent acting on the instructions of the Majority Super Senior Creditors or the Majority Senior Secured Creditors), the Security Agent shall act (i) prior to the Designation Date, in accordance with the instructions of the Majority Senior Secured Creditors (without any requirement to first consult with any junior creditors) or (ii) after the Designation Date and to the extent the Majority Super Senior Creditors have provided such instructions, in accordance with the instructions received from the Majority Super Senior Creditors. The Security Agent may also refrain from acting in accordance with any instructions until it has been indemnified and/or secured to its satisfaction that it may in its discretion require for any cost, loss or liability which it may incur in complying with those instructions. To the extent we incur additional indebtedness that is secured on a pari passu basis with the Notes, the voting interest of holders of Notes in an instructing group will be diluted commensurate with the amount of indebtedness we incur. The creditors of any Super Senior Liabilities may have interests that are different from the interests of holders of the Notes and they may, subject to the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement, elect to pursue their remedies under the Security Documents at a time when it would be disadvantageous for the holders of the Notes to do so. In addition, if the Security Agent sells Collateral consisting of the shares of any of the Issuer’s subsidiaries as a result of an enforcement action in accordance with the Intercreditor Agreement, claims under the Guarantees and the liens over any other assets of such entities securing the Notes and the Guarantees may be released. See “Description of Other Indebtedness—Intercreditor Agreement” and “Description of the Notes— _Security—Release of Liens.”_ Delays in enforcement could decrease or eliminate recovery values. In addition, the holders of the Notes will not have any independent power to enforce, or have recourse to, any of the Security Documents or to exercise any rights or powers arising under the Security Documents, except through the Security Agent as provided in the Intercreditor Agreement. By accepting the Notes, you will be deemed to have agreed to these restrictions. As a result of these restrictions, holders of the Notes have limited remedies and recourse against the Issuer and the Guarantors in the event of a default. See “Description of Other Indebtedness—Intercreditor _Agreement.”_

_An investment in the Additional Notes involves a high degree of risk. In addition to the other information contained in this Offering Memorandum, you should carefully consider the following risk factors before purchasing the Additional Notes. The risks and uncertainties that we describe below are not the only ones we face. Additional risks and uncertainties that we are not aware of or that we currently believe are immaterial could also have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations or financial condition. If any of the possible events described below occurs, our business, financial condition or results of operations could be materially and adversely affected. If that happens, we may not be able to pay interest or principal on the Additional Notes when due and you could lose all or part of your investment. This Offering Memorandum also contains forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. Our actual results may differ materially from those anticipated in these forward-looking statements as a result of various factors, including the risks described below and elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. See “Forward- Looking Statements.”_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We are the leading route-based unattended self-service coffee and convenience food provider in Europe by revenue with more than 475,000 PoS in 16 countries as of June 30, 2019, covering approximately 95% of European GDP and approximately 78% of the European population. We held the number one or number two market position based on revenue in 2017 in our ten core markets of Belgium, France, Finland, Italy, the Netherlands, Norway, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland and the United Kingdom. We served over ten million consumers per day via more than 3,800 routes as of June 30, 2019. We operate in a highly fragmented market, which provides growth opportunities, both organically and through accretive acquisitions. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2019, we generated a revenue of €1,580.8 million and an Adjusted EBITDA of €267.7 million, and we would have generated an Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) of €1,604.7 million and an Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) of €271.2 million, achieving 3.8% Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) growth compared to the twelve months ended June 30, 2018, and 18.9% Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) margins.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We report our revenue and certain other financial data by geographic segment. The geographic segments in which we operate correspond to our reporting segments under IFRS and consist of the following for the year ended September 30, 2018, and the nine months ended June 30, 2018 and 2019: - _South, UK & Ireland includes operating entities in Ireland, Italy, Spain and the UK; - _Central includes operating entities in Austria, France, Germany, Liechtenstein, and Switzerland; and - _North includes operating entities in Belgium, Denmark, Finland, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Norway, and Sweden. As of October 1, 2017, one operating entity in Finland was classified as held for sale and excluded from this segment; it was subsequently sold in March 2018. In addition to the segments identified above, we report separately on our Headquarters (HQ), which includes corporate center functions in Switzerland and certain functions of former Pelican Rouge entities in the Netherlands and in the UK. For comparative purposes, we also presented our revenue and certain other financial data for the year ended September 30, 2017, in line with the above geographic segments in our 2018 Consolidated Financial Statements. For the years ended September 30, 2016 and 2017, we reported our revenue by the following geographic segments: - _France included operating entities in France; - _West included operating entities in Belgium, Ireland, the Netherlands and the UK; 65 ----- - _Central included operating entities in Austria, Germany, Spain, and Switzerland; and - _North included operating entities in Denmark, Finland, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Norway, and Sweden. As of October 1, 2016, operating entities in Estonia, Latvia, and Lithuania were classified as held for sale and excluded from this segment; they were subsequently sold in March 2017. In addition to the segments identified above, we reported separately on our Headquarters (HQ), which included corporate center functions in Switzerland.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We also report our revenue and certain other financial data by business channel. Our business channels consist of the following for the year ended September 30, 2018, and the nine months ended June 30, 2018 and 2019: - The workplace channel, which includes revenue from (i) private self-service retail, consisting of PoS placed and serviced in various private locations, such as large corporate customers, in various businesses and industries and including in corporate offices, manufacturing and logistics sites, and (ii) OCS, which is comprised of table-top coffee machines rented out to corporate customers (mainly small and medium-sized enterprises) for office use along with the provision of technical services and coffee and related supplies for the PoS; - The on-the-go channel, which includes revenue from PoS placed and serviced in semi-public areas, such as hospitals, universities and entertainment venues, or public areas, such as train stations, airports and gas stations, following a successful bidding process with relevant government authorities to place our PoS in a given location; and - The trading channel, which includes revenue from sales of machines and products, including coffee roasted in our roasting facility and the provision of technical and hygienic support to customers. We did not report our revenue by the above business channels in our financial statements for prior periods, including for the years ended September 30, 2016 and 2017. However, for comparative purposes, we presented our revenue for the year ended September 30, 2017, by business channels in our 2018 Consolidated Financial Statements.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations and Financial Condition
Subsubsection Title: General Economic Conditions, Consumer Spending and Consumer Preferences
Subsubsection Text: Demand for our PoS and products is affected by general economic conditions and consumer spending. Changes in general economic conditions directly impact consumer spending as well as the investment levels of our customers in non-essential services, such as PoS and services. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2019, we derived 47.0% of our revenue from workplace points of sale, which include OCS. As PoS in such privately placed points of sale are generally located on companies’ premises in office environments and similar locations, macroeconomic factors such as GDP and employment levels, among others, affect the number of items sold through these PoS. For example, reductions in workforce numbers or hours worked during times of economic downturn (including the effects of reduced overtime, layoffs and increased reliance on part-time versus full-time workers) means that our PoS on companies’ premises and in office environments are available to fewer consumers or consumers with lower purchasing power due to reduced income or more conservative spending habits. On the other hand, economic growth may have a positive impact on our ability to generate new business if companies invest in non-essential services, such as the decision to contract for the placement of a PoS on their premises. Variations in consumer spending or consumer purchasing power can also affect revenue generated from our PoS in public locations, but macroeconomic conditions generally have less impact on our public selfservice retail operations compared to our private operations. In addition, our revenues in any given period are affected by our ability to maintain the appeal of our PoS to existing consumers and attract new consumers, which depends on continuous development and improvement of our range of products and services offering that are responsive to evolving trends and consumer preferences. For instance, our increasing focus on premium coffee brands and the introduction of touchscreen technology and 66 ----- cashless payment options for our PoS, including our mobile phone app, Selecta eWallet, are driven by changing consumer behaviors. Specific factors affecting consumer spending in our PoS include our ability to maintain and improve an attractive product assortment, including through partnerships with Starbucks and Lavazza, the location and overall aesthetic appeal of our PoS, the accessibility and integration of our on-the-go PoS channels, and our ability to effectively predict and respond to quickly changing consumer demands and preferences.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations and Financial Condition
Subsubsection Text: Our vends of certain products have historically been affected by seasonal variation during the year. Many of our PoS include cold drinks, which have historically generated increased sales during the summer months. Coffee sales generally exhibit less variation, but may also be affected by seasonal factors, especially for our PoS inside offices or in other private locations, where sales are lower during holiday seasons. In addition, severe weather can influence consumer traffic patterns in high-traffic areas such as gas stations, train and subway stations, and airports. If, for example, transportation services are closed due to heavy snow or rain, our PoS in such locations may be accessible by significantly fewer consumers and vends lost on a particular business day typically cannot be recouped in the future.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations and Financial Condition
Subsubsection Text: We incur capital expenditures in connection with the purchase of new PoS and the refurbishment of existing PoS in the ordinary course of business. We own approximately 78% of the PoS that we service, which we fund through cash on balance sheet or finance leases, with the remaining PoS being owned or leased directly by our customers. In addition, we incur capital expenditures in connection with the development of new technologies for the retail industry, such as the ability to transmit sales and stock data remotely. We divide our capital expenditures into gross capital expenditures, net capital expenditures, and cash capital expenditures. Gross capital expenditures consist of self-service retail equipment purchased; net capital expenditures consist of gross capital expenditures less the book value of total disposals of self-service retail equipment (which includes old PoS sold); and cash capital expenditures consist of net capital expenditures net of self-service retail equipment bought through finance lease arrangements during the same period. Capital expenditures excludes purchase of PoS where alternative arrangements are made through third parties, such as Lavazza, to finance PoS investments. We have launched a capital intensity program in order to reduce our total cash capital expenditure. A part of our capital intensity program is to focus on refurbishing our PoS rather than purchasing new PoS, with a view of expanding the life cycle of our PoS from 6 to 18 years, which in turn decreases the number of new PoS required to maintain our PoS park. As part of this capital intensity program, we have also established two PoS upgrade centers in Madrid and Milan.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations and Financial Condition
Subsubsection Text: We believe that we have stable relationships with our customers, many of whom are longstanding customers. For example, the average length of our top ten customer contracts is over 15 years. In addition, our customer base is highly fragmented, which limits our dependence on any single customer. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2019, our top ten customers accounted for 9.0% of our revenue and our largest customer by revenue accounted for 1.5% of our revenue. Nevertheless, the gain or loss of significant customers or a large number of customers in the same period would affect our results of operations. We manage our customer relationships differently depending on the market segment. With our workplace customers, our contractual relationships have a shorter duration, typically between three and five years, but such contracts often renew automatically. Customers in our on-the-go business channel (like train stations, gas stations, public institutions and hospitals) will typically organize periodic tenders for the assignment of multiyear contracts, sometimes lasting five to over ten years. Larger customers will also generally charge us a vending fee to place our PoS on their premises. Vending fees are negotiated according to formulas related to past or expected traffic in the relevant location and number of vends; vending fees can be either variable (based on total sales from the applicable PoS) or fixed (based on the number of PoS installed pursuant to the relevant contract). Our considerable experience in the self-service retail industry provides us with extensive datasets that we can use to calculate acceptable vending fees that will allow us to submit competitive bids on commercially viable pricing terms.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations and Financial Condition
Subsubsection Title: PoS Density, Concept and Product Mix
Subsubsection Text: Our results of operations and profit before interest and income tax are affected by a combination of factors, including the number of PoS in a given area, the type of PoS, the product mix in our PoS and the level of services 67 ----- we provide. In both workplace and on-the-go channels, PoS density is one of the primary drivers of profitability and a key strategy in our acquisition program. PoS that are closer together can be more quickly and efficiently managed by the same personnel, which reduces transport time and the relative costs associated with labor, restocking, fuel, and maintenance. In contrast, single PoS in isolated locations may not generate sufficient gross profit to cover the costs of visits to clean, restock, or perform scheduled or unscheduled maintenance. Our revenue and margins are also driven by our mix of workplace and on-the-go services. Because the margins on our products may vary, changes in the mix of our product sales have a direct impact on our total revenue and profitability. Workplace self-service retail is our largest self-service concept by revenue and is primarily driven by sales of coffee and other hot beverages. Workplace self-service retail margins vary based on the type of PoS located in a particular area as well as the extent to which a customer agrees to subsidize the cost of products for its employees, or alternatively wants to receive a vending fee on it. Consumers generally consume more products and beverages when the cost is subsidized by their employers, leading to larger volumes of vends and higher margins. On-the-go self-service retail margins vary primarily based on the combination of the volume of vends and the price points for the products sold, which depend on the locations of the PoS and the number of other locations in close proximity to our PoS that sell the same or similar products, as well as the level of vending fee paid to the customer. Our partnerships with premium coffee brands such as Starbucks and Lavazza also provide us with the platform to offer a compelling product mix. Therefore, the combination of location, PoS density, product mix, prices and contributions paid to the customer are among the key factors which determine profitability of our PoS.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations and Financial Condition
Subsubsection Title: Prices of Self-service Retail Stock and Procurement Initiatives
Subsubsection Text: Prices of certain commodities, such as green bean coffee, cocoa and sugar, affect our cost of materials. For example, for our own coffee brands, we estimate we require approximately 7,400 tons of arabica green bean coffee and approximately 4,100 tons of robusta green bean coffee annually to regularly stock our hot drinks selfservice PoS or supply our customers with coffee beans. Overall, we purchase more than 20,000 tons of green bean coffee annually for our Pelican Rouge and Miofino brands, half of which we sell to third parties. Prices for green bean coffee have fluctuated significantly in recent years. For example, the price of arabica green bean coffee increased considerably from November 2013 to April 2014 and, alternatively, prices ranged from U.S.$2.30 per pound in October 2011 to U.S.$1.09 per pound in October 2018 (based on the ICE ‘C’ New York index). In order to manage risks from fluctuations in commodities prices, we secure the green bean requirements for periods of up to twelve months by instructing the relevant supplier to source the required green beans to cover certain production lots at a specific price. With certain strategic suppliers, we enter into longer-term agreements with agreed price adjustment mechanisms that reflect developments in commodity prices. For our other ingredients such as milk powders, cocoa, and sugar, we have quarterly price contracts with our suppliers ranging between six to twelve months. Following the completion of the acquisitions of Pelican Rouge and Argenta, we have strengthened our corporate procurement department to leverage our scale and obtain better prices. We have started to harmonize prices of products we purchase for our PoS (such as snacks or cold drinks), which are traditionally sourced at the country level, by leveraging our scale and negotiating prices with large suppliers (such as Coca-Cola) through strategic relationships at the Group level. While certain products, such as confectionary items and other stock items that cater to local or regional tastes, continue to be sourced on a country level, we source our own brand green bean coffee as well as cups, sugar, and stirrers, among other supplies, through our corporate procurement department, which allows us to secure more competitive pricing based on larger volume orders.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations and Financial Condition
Subsubsection Title: Operations and Maintenance of Our Roasting Facility
Subsubsection Text: We operate a roasting facility in Dordrecht, Netherlands, with an annual capacity of approximately 27,000 metric tons from which we supply the Group and third parties with coffee. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2019, our roasting operations accounted for 4% of our revenue. We sell coffee to businesses, such as restaurants, coffee shops and self-service retail operators, and, in limited quantities, directly to consumers. Our roasting operations have primarily focused on the roasting, blending, packaging and sale of our own coffee brands, Pelican Rouge and Miofino. The results of our roasting operations are primarily affected by the level of marketing and pricing competition from existing or new competitors in the coffee industry, our ability to retain existing customers and attract new customers for our coffee and fluctuations in the selling prices of Pelican Rouge-branded coffee. In addition, investments required to maintain or repair our roasting facility have a material impact on our capital expenditures. 68 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations and Financial Condition
Subsubsection Title: Anticipated Cost Savings and Synergies Resulting from Acquisitions
Subsubsection Text: To evaluate cost savings and synergies that we have realized and expect to achieve as a result of the Pelican Rouge Acquisition and the Argenta Acquisition we have worked with consultants and advisors, including experienced industry professionals, to examine the profile of our combined businesses and operations. The synergies resulting from these acquisitions primarily fall into three categories: (i) logistics and footprint optimizations, (ii) consolidation of procurement, and (iii) selling, general, and administrative costs across the entire organization. The integration process requires changes to our purchasing practices to improve margins, while also implementing our own systems and best practices and adjusting our combined organizational structure and management footprint to maximize synergies. In order to supervise this integration process, we have created an integration office at the group level led by a dedicated project manager with extensive experience in integrations and operational turnaround reporting to the Executive Chairman of the Group and supported by our senior management team and dedicated specialists. We expect to realize approximately €75 million of estimated annualized run-rate cost synergies from the Pelican Rouge Acquisition and the Argenta Acquisition by the end of 2020. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2019, we estimate that we have realized approximately €52 million of these cost synergies, which represents 69% of our total expected cost synergies. See “Summary—Summary _Historical Financial and Other Information—Historical Consolidated Financial Information—Other Financial Data and Operating Information” and “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Business—We may not be able to realize the anticipated operational efficiencies and cost savings in connection with acquisitions (including the Pelican Rouge Acquisition, the Argenta Acquisition and the Express Vending Acquisition).” See also “Forward- Looking Statements.”_ Our total estimated cost synergies described above include the following: - Operating cost savings relating to logistics and footprint optimizations of approximately €33 million, of which we had realized €18 million as of June 30, 2019. These savings are currently being realized by (i) combining operations in areas with fewer PoS to reduce the number of employees required to maintain and refill these PoS, (ii) implementing Selecta’s refiller planning program, which is based on actual sales of each PoS rather than a theoretical model, (iii) cost savings by leveraging data from telemetry technology already in place in the Argenta Group’s PoS and by increasing the use of telemetry for PoS in France, Spain and the UK (iv) headcount reductions following the assessment of productivity of our technicians and through the integration of corporate, IT and other central functions, (v) footprint optimization by concentrating warehouses in the countries where both Selecta and Pelican Rouge operate, and (vi) logistics network synergies, including planning denser and more cost-effective routes. - Procurement savings of approximately €30 million, of which we had realized €22 million as of June 30, 2019. These savings are currently being realized by (i) obtaining better prices on ingredients through in-sourcing of our own brand coffee from Pelican Rouge’s roaster facility and international tender of raw materials used across the countries in which we operate, such as sugar, (ii) harmonizing prices of products we purchase for our PoS (such as snacks or cold drinks) by leveraging our scale and negotiating prices through strategic relationships at the Group level, (iii) savings on disposables, such as cups for our PoS, and packaging through leveraging our increased purchasing volume at the Group level, (iv) streamlining purchases of spare parts for our PoS, (v) indirect cost savings on our fleet, IT, marketing, and warehouses, and (vi) real estate savings as a result of terminating redundant leases and renegotiating existing leases. - Selling, general, and administrative cost savings of approximately €13 million, of which we had realized €12 million as of June 30, 2019. These savings are currently being realized through (i) headcount reductions as a result of integrating management teams in countries where both Selecta and Pelican Rouge operate and re-sizing our sales force, (ii) savings in connection with headcount reductions in the research and development department of the Group by leveraging Argenta’s research and development expertise, (iii) reductions in employee benefit expenses, such as cars, travel, and mobile phones, in connection with headcount reductions, (iv) combining headquarters in countries where both Selecta and Pelican Rouge operate and (v) additional productivity gains in sales, general and administrative costs. As of June 30, 2019, we estimate that we have incurred approximately €25 million in costs and capital expenditures to implement the foregoing synergies, and estimate that we will incur approximately €28 million in further costs and capital expenditures to realize our total targeted cost synergies. In particular, we expect to incur (i) total estimated severance costs of approximately €24 million, of which approximately €10 million have 69 ----- already been incurred as of June 30, 2019, and (ii) estimated integration costs of approximately €29 million, of which approximately €14 million have already been incurred as of June 30, 2019. Although it is our objective to reach the levels of projected synergies reflected above, no assurance can be given that such levels will be achieved in the timeframe indicated or at all or that additional unanticipated costs will not arise. We currently estimate the majority of the cost to achieve the anticipated synergies to be personnel reductions and related costs that may be required under the laws of the various countries where we operate, which we expect to continue incurring over the course of the next one to two years. As part of our reorganization plan, we are required to negotiate severance payments with worker representatives (labor unions) for FTEs being made redundant pursuant to a collective dismissal procedure provided under applicable regulations in various of the countries where we operate. While we fully intend to observe the relevant legal procedures and requirements and to negotiate in good faith, if we cannot reach an agreement on severance payments with such worker representatives or the employees, they may choose to bring administrative or judicial challenges, which could delay the achievement of our synergies and/or increase costs incurred in order to achieve such synergies. Our synergy estimates are based on a number of assumptions made in reliance on the information available to us and our judgments based on such information. The assumptions used in estimating synergies are inherently uncertain and are subject to significant business, economic and competitive risks and uncertainties that could cause our actual results to differ materially from those contained in the synergy benefit estimates, including those described in “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Business—We may not be able to realize the anticipated _operational efficiencies and cost savings in connection with acquisitions (including the Pelican Rouge Acquisition, the Argenta Acquisition and the Express Vending Acquisition).” See also “Forward-Looking Statements.”_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Comparability of Our Financial Statements
Subsubsection Text: The comparability of our results of operations is affected by acquisitions and disposals. On August 17, 2018, we completed the Express Vending Acquisition; on February 2, 2018, we completed the Argenta Acquisition; and on September 7, 2017, we completed the Pelican Rouge Acquisition. We have included the operations of each of these entities in our audited consolidated financial information as of each of their respective acquisition dates. As a result, our audited consolidated financial information as of and for the year ended September 30, 2018, includes the operations of Express Vending from August 17, 2018 to September 30, 2018, the operations of the Argenta Group from February 2, 2018 to September 30, 2018, and the full year results of operations of the Pelican Rouge Group. Since our financial statements as of and for the year ended September 30, 2018 do not include the full year results of operations of the Express Vending Group and the Argenta Group, the comparability of our financial statements as of and for the year ended September 30, 2018 and as of and for the nine months ended June 30, 2019, with our financial statements as of and for the year ended September 30, 2017, and as of and for the nine months ended June 30, 2018, respectively, is significantly limited. In addition, in connection with the Pelican Rouge Acquisition, in March 2018 we disposed of our Selecta operations in Finland (“legacy Selecta Finland”) to comply with antitrust requirements. For the year ended September 30, 2017, legacy Selecta Finland generated €13.9 million in revenue. As a result of applying IFRS 5 to our financial statements for the year ended September 30, 2017, the assets and liabilities relating to legacy Selecta Finland are presented separately in dedicated lines in our consolidated balance sheet as of September 30, 2017. The assets presented separately as “assets classified as held for sale” in our consolidated balance sheet as of September 30, 2017, are valued at the lower of their carrying amount and fair value less costs to sell. The corresponding liabilities are presented separately as “liabilities associated with assets held for sale” in the consolidated balance sheet as of September 30, 2017. On September 19, 2018, we sold Custompack to PortionPack Europe Group. Custompack focuses on the provision of single portion items such as wet sauces, dry products, and portion packing to its customers. Given Selecta’s strategy around strengthening its leading position as unattended self-service convenience food and beverage operator in Europe, Custompack was divested as a non-core business. The net disposal accounting gain recorded on the sale amounted to €0.6 million. We also disposed of our operations in the Baltic countries (Lithuania, Latvia, and Estonia) in March 2017. 70 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Comparability of Our Financial Statements
Subsubsection Title: Categorization of Reporting Segments and Business Channels
Subsubsection Text: _Geographic Segments_ Following the Pelican Rouge Acquisition and the Argenta Acquisition, we have recategorized our geographic areas and the countries in each area for our financial statements. As a result, our audited consolidated financial information as of and for the year ended September 30, 2018, includes financial data for three new geographic segments (South, UK & Ireland, Central, and North), which significantly differ from our previous four geographic areas (France, West, Central, and North). See “—Our Segments and Business Channels— _Geographic Segments.” For comparative purposes, our 2018 Consolidated Financial Statements include our_ results according to the three new geographic segments for the year ended September 30, 2017. Therefore, the comparability of our results of operations by geographic segments as of and for the years ended September 30, 2017 and 2018, with our financial statements as of and for the year ended September 30, 2016, is significantly limited. _Business Channels_ Beginning October 1, 2017, we categorized our revenue by business channels for our financial statements. As a result, our subsequent financial statements include our revenue by workplace, on-the-go, and trading channels. For comparative purposes, our 2018 Consolidated Financial Statements include our results according to such categorization for the year ended September 30, 2017. This categorization did not exist for our financial statements for previous years and therefore our revenue by business channel for the years ended September 30, 2017 and 2018, cannot be compared with information in our financial statements for the year ended September 30, 2016. See “—Our Segments and Business Channels—Business Channels.”

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Comparability of Our Financial Statements
Subsubsection Text: IFRS 16 (Leases) was published on January 13, 2016 and became effective on January 1, 2019. As our financial year begins on October 1[st] each year, we will apply IFRS 16 to our financial statements beginning from October 1, 2019. IFRS 16 introduces a single accounting model for lessees that principally obligates lessees to account for right-of-use assets and lease liabilities for lease contracts with a term of more than twelve months. The significant impact of IFRS 16 is the elimination of the classification according to IAS 17 (Leases) of lease contracts as operating leases and finance leases. As a result, leases, which were shown off-balance sheet according to IAS 17, will be recognized as a right-of-use asset and lease liability on the balance sheet as of October 1, 2019. We intend to apply the modified retrospective approach to adopt IFRS 16, and will not restate comparative amounts for the year prior to first adoption. IFRS 16 will primarily affect the accounting for our operating leases. We currently expect that IFRS 16 will lead to an increase in total assets and total liabilities of approximately €150 million from the effect of recognizing existing operating leases on the balance sheet. Additionally, annual operating lease expenses of approximately €40 million are expected to be presented as depreciation and interest expenses in the future, with a reduction for a similar amount in rent expenses, as part of our operating expenses. As a result of the implementation of IFRS 16, the comparability of our results presented in our future financial statements will be significantly limited compared to our Historical Financial Statements.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Items
Subsubsection Text: Revenue means our gross revenue from our publicly accessible PoS, our privately placed PoS and from trade sales of machines and products, including sale of our private coffee brands, Pelican Rouge and Miofino, to businesses, such as restaurants, coffee shops and self-service retail operators and in limited quantities directly to consumers. It also includes revenue from the rendering of technical services and rental income from PoS placed at customer sites under a rental contract and rental of advertising space. Revenue from the sale of goods is recognized when the goods are delivered to the customer’s site or when goods are purchased from a PoS by a consumer, depending on the contract terms. Revenue may be received directly in the form of cash from the consumer, or may be invoiced to a customer periodically. Where revenue is received in the form of cash, the amount recognized is the amount of cash received until the last date on which the cash was collected from the PoS, plus an estimate of the sales between this date and the period end. This estimate is calculated based on historical trends of sales from PoS in similar areas. Where the sale of goods is invoiced to the customer, the amount recognized is based either on the amounts delivered to the customer or on the consumption in the PoS, depending on the specific contractual terms. 71 -----

Subsubsection Title: Comparison of the Year Ended September 30, 2017 to the Year Ended September 30, 2018

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _Revenue_ Revenue increased by €129.3 million, or 11.9%, from €1,084.4 million for the nine months ended June 30, 2018, to €1,213.7 million for the nine months ended June 30, 2019. This increase was primarily due to the acquisitions of Argenta and Express Vending, which collectively contributed €111.3 million to our revenue for the nine months June 30, 2019, compared to the nine months ended June 30, 2018. This increase was partly offset by the disposal of Custompack Ltd., which had a negative impact of €13.2 million on our revenue over the same period. Without giving effect to acquisitions and disposals, our revenue for the nine months ended June 30, 2019, would have increased by €31.3 million compared to the nine months ended June 30, 2018, primarily due to an increase of €19.6 million in revenue from our public business channel in Belgium, Luxembourg, the Netherlands and in the Central region, and an increase of €16.1 million in trade machine sales, primarily in the North region. This increase was partly offset by our results of operations in France and the United Kingdom where we are currently implementing our turnaround plans. _Vending Fee_ Vending fee increased by €17.4 million, or 16.0%, from €108.6 million for the nine months ended June 30, 2018, to €126.0 million for the nine months ended June 30, 2019. This increase was primarily due to the acquisition of Argenta, which contributed €7.3 million to our vending fee expenses for the nine months June 30, 2019, compared to the nine months ended June 30, 2018. The acquisition of Express Vending and the disposal of Custompack Ltd. did not impact our vending fees as they had no on-the-go business during these periods. Without giving effect to the acquisition of Argenta, our vending fees for the nine months June 30, 2019, would have increased by €10.2 million compared to the nine months ended June 30, 2018, primarily due to the increase in revenue in our public segment, which has associated vending fees. _Materials and Consumables Used_ Expenses for materials and consumables used increased by €31.2 million, or 8.4%, from €372.2 million for the nine months ended June 30, 2018, to €403.4 million for the nine months ended June 30, 2019. This increase was primarily due to the acquisitions of Argenta and Express Vending, which collectively contributed €34.9 million to materials and consumables used for the nine months June 30, 2019, compared to the nine months ended June 30, 2018. This increase was partly offset by the disposal of Custompack Ltd., which reduced 73 ----- materials and consumables used by €10.3 million over the same period. Without giving effect to acquisitions and disposals, material and consumable expenses for the nine months ended June 30, 2019, would have increased by €6.5 million compared to the nine months ended June 30, 2018, primarily due to the increase in revenue across the Group. _Employee Benefits Expense_ Employee benefits expense increased by €32.7 million, or 10.2%, from €322.0 million for the nine months ended June 30, 2018, to €354.7 million for the nine months ended June 30, 2019. This increase was primarily due to the acquisitions of Argenta and Express Vending, which collectively contributed €34.0 million to employee benefit expenses for the nine months June 30, 2019, compared to the nine months ended June 30, 2018. This increase was partly offset by the disposal of Custompack Ltd., which reduced employee benefit expenses by €3.1 million over the same period. Without giving effect to acquisitions and disposals, our employee benefit expenses for the nine months June 30, 2019, would have increased by €1.8 million compared to the nine months ended June 30, 2018. This increase was primarily due to growth projects in certain countries, such as Switzerland, and expenses incurred in connection with investments in capabilities related to strategic transactions, which were largely offset by cost savings in connection with our synergy program and rightsizing our operations in Austria, Belgium, Denmark, Finland, Germany, Netherlands, Norway, and Spain. _Depreciation and Amortization Expense_ Depreciation and amortization expense increased by €16.7 million, or 12.6%, from €132.4 million for the nine months ended June 30, 2018, to €149.1 million for the nine months ended June 30, 2019. This increase was primarily due to the acquisitions of Argenta and Express Vending, which collectively contributed €8.3 million to our depreciation and amortization expense, mainly through depreciation expenses, for the nine months June 30, 2019, compared to the nine months ended June 30, 2018. Without giving effect to acquisitions and disposals over the period, our depreciation and amortization expense for the nine months ended June 30, 2019, would have increased by €8.4 million compared to the nine months ended June 30, 2018, primarily due to amortization of customer contracts at a Group level. _Other Operating Expenses_ Other operating expenses increased by €23.8 million, or 14.3%, from €166.9 million for the nine months ended June 30, 2018, to €190.7 million for the nine months ended June 30, 2019. This increase was primarily due to the acquisitions of Argenta and Express Vending, which collectively contributed €13.7 million to other operating expenses for the nine months June 30, 2019, compared to the nine months ended June 30, 2018. Without giving effect to acquisitions and disposals over the period, our other operating expenses for the nine months ended June 30, 2019, would have increased by €10.1 million compared to the nine months ended June 30, 2018, primarily due to operating expenses, such as consulting expenses of €7.2 million incurred at our headquarters and mainly related to strategic transactions. _Net Finance Costs_ Net finance costs decreased by €40.7 million, or 37.2%, from €109.5 million for the nine months ended June 30, 2018, to €68.8 million for the nine months ended June 30, 2019. The acquisitions of Argenta and Express Vending contributed €10.5 million of net finance costs for the nine months June 30, 2019. Without giving effect to acquisitions and disposals over the period, our net financing costs for the nine months June 30, 2019, would have decreased by €51.2 million compared to the nine months ended June 30, 2018, primarily due to foreign exchange gains on intercompany investments that are not eliminated upon consolidation of intra-group balances. _Income Taxes_ Income taxes decreased by €5.6 million, or 76.7%, from €7.3 million for the nine months ended June 30, 2018, to €1.7 million for the nine months ended June 30, 2019. This was primarily due to higher income tax expenses in Sweden, driven by accruals for non-deductible tax relating to previous years, and higher tax expenses in Italy primarily driven by differences in timing of accrued taxes, which decreased our income tax benefits. 74 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Revenue in our South, UK & Ireland region increased by €369.1 million, or 375.9%, from €98.2 million for the year ended September 30, 2017, to €467.3 million for the year ended September 30, 2018. This increase was primarily due to the impact of the Pelican Rouge Acquisition in Spain, the Argenta Acquisition in Italy and to a lesser extent the Express Vending Acquisition in the UK. This increase was partly offset by the results of Selecta’s legacy operations in the UK where we are currently implementing our turnaround plans. Revenue in our Central region increased by €111.6 million, or 23.4%, from €477.9 million for the year ended September 30, 2017 to €589.5 million for the year ended September 30, 2018. This increase was primarily driven by the impact of the Pelican Rouge Acquisition in France, and organic growth in Germany, Austria and Switzerland. This increase was partly offset by the results of Selecta’s legacy operations in France where we are currently implementing our turnaround plans. Revenue in our North region increased by €230.2 million, or 124.1%, from €185.4 million for the year ended September 30, 2017, to €415.5 million for the year ended September 30, 2018. This increase was primarily 75 ----- due to the Pelican Rouge Acquisition driving growth in the Netherlands, Belgium, Norway and Finland. Excluding the Pelican Rouge Acquisition, we achieved organic growth in all countries, in particular in Belgium, Norway and Denmark. _Vending Fee_ Vending fee increased by €66.8 million, or 75.1%, from €88.9 million for the year ended September 30, 2017 to €155.7 million for the year ended September 30, 2018. This increase was primarily due to the acquisitions of Pelican Rouge, Argenta, and Express Vending. _Materials and Consumables Used_ Expenses for materials and consumables used increased by €245.4 million, or 100.6%, from €244.0 million for the year ended September 30, 2017 to €489.4 million for the year ended September 30, 2018. This increase was primarily due to the acquisitions of Pelican Rouge, Argenta, and Express Vending, which was partly offset by €4.7 million due to the disposal of legacy Selecta Finland. _Employee Benefits Expense_ Employee benefits expense increased by €188.0 million, or 82.2%, from €228.6 million for the year ended September 30, 2017, to €416.6 million for the year ended September 30, 2018. This increase was primarily due to the acquisitions of Pelican Rouge, Argenta, and Express Vending, which was partly offset by the disposal of legacy Selecta Finland. _Depreciation and Amortization Expense_ Depreciation and amortization expense increased by €89.6 million, or 96.1%, from €93.2 million for the year ended September 30, 2017, to €182.8 million for the year ended September 30, 2018. This increase was primarily due to the acquisitions of Pelican Rouge, Argenta, and Express Vending, which was partly offset by the disposal of legacy Selecta Finland. _Other Operating Expenses_ Other operating expenses increased by €81.5 million, or 57.6%, from €141.5 million for the year ended September 30, 2017, to €223.0 million for the year ended September 30, 2018. This increase was primarily due to the acquisitions of Pelican Rouge, Argenta, and Express Vending, coupled with integration related advisory costs. _Finance Costs_ Finance costs increased by €38.7 million, or 37.3%, from €103.7 million for the year ended September 30, 2017 to €142.4 million for the year ended September 30, 2018. This increase was primarily due to an increase in interest on other loans and refinancing costs, partly offset by lower foreign exchange losses in the year September 30, 2018 as compared with the year ended September 30, 2017. _Finance Income_ Finance income increased by €14.8 million, or 197.3%, from €7.5 million for the year ended September 30, 2017 to €22.3 million for the year ended September 30, 2018. This increase was primarily due to a change in the fair value of derivative financial instruments, and currency translation effects. _Income Taxes_ Income taxes increased by €3.8 million, or 95.0%, from €4.0 million for the year ended September 30, 2017 to €7.8 million for the year ended September 30, 2018. This increase was related to a change in deferred tax relating to customer contracts amortization. 76 -----

This increase was primarily due to the Pelican Rouge Acquisition, which contributed €36.6 million to our revenue from September 7, 2017, to September 30, 2017. Without giving effect to the Pelican Rouge Acquisition and the disposal of our Baltics operations in 2016 (€13.3 million), revenue would have increased by €1.7 million, or 0.2%. Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Revenue in our Central region increased by €14.3 million, or 4.7%, from €304.2 million for the year ended September 30, 2016 to €318.5 million for the year ended September 30, 2017. This increase was primarily due to the effects of the Pelican Rouge Acquisition in Spain, and an increase of 21.7% in Germany compared to the previous year as a result of the increased sales from the Deutsche Bahn contract, and trade sales from Shell gas stations. This increase was partially offset by a decrease of €4.7 million in private sales in Switzerland where new business gains were below expectation. Sales in the Swiss public segment, however, increased slightly due to the upgrades implemented in PoS, which were fitted with telemetry, cashless payment options, and brighter new displays. Revenue in our North region decreased by €10.8 million, or 7.7%, from €140.0 million for the year ended September 30, 2016, to €129.2 million for the year ended September 30, 2017. This decrease was primarily due to the disposal of our operations in the Baltic countries, which contributed €13.3 million of revenue to the Group in 2016. This decrease was partially offset by the positive performance of our Starbucks on-the-go locations in gas stations in Denmark. Revenue in our France region increased by €7.3 million, or 3.9%, from €184.3 million for the year ended September 30, 2016, to €191.6 million for the year ended September 30, 2017. This increase was primarily due to 77 ----- an increase in sales from PoS in public spaces, specifically train stations. This growth was partially offset by a decline in the private sales due to the removal of low-performing PoS from the PoS park. Revenue in our West region increased by €14.4 million, or 13.3%, from €107.9 million for the year ended September 30, 2016, to €122.3 million for the year ended September 30, 2017. This increase was primarily due to additional revenue resulting from the Pelican Rouge Acquisition. Consistent sales growth throughout the year at gas stations in the Netherlands also contributed to this increase, which were partially offset by decreased private sales in the UK. _Materials and Consumables Used_ Expenses for materials and consumables used increased by €12.9 million, or 5.6%, from €231.1 million for the year ended September 30, 2016 to €244.0 million for the year ended September 30, 2017. This increase was primarily due to the Pelican Rouge Acquisition, which contributed €15.7 million to our material and consumables used from September 7, 2017 to September 30, 2017. Without giving effect to the Pelican Rouge Acquisition, expenses for materials and consumables would have decreased by €2.8 million, or 1.2%, driven by the disposal of Selecta’s operations in three Baltic countries completed on March 14, 2017, which accounted for €6.2 million of this expense in the previous year. _Employee Benefits Expense_ Employee benefits expense decreased by €5.5 million, or 2.3%, from €234.1 million for the year ended September 30, 2016, to €228.6 million for the year ended September 30, 2017. This decrease was primarily due to a reduction in the number of FTEs in all four regions (other than Germany in the Central region), which contributed to employee expense savings. FTE reductions were implemented for both field-force and administrative staff, notably IT as a consequence of the outsourcing of the IT infrastructure. The Pelican Rouge Acquisition accounted for €12.6 million of employee benefits expense from September 7, 2017, to September 30, 2017, and Selecta’s operations in the Baltics countries accounted for €1.8 million for the year ended September 30, 2016. Without giving effect to the Pelican Rouge Acquisition and the Baltics disposal, employee benefit expense decreased by 7.0%. _Depreciation and Amortization Expense_ Depreciation and amortization expense increased by €1.2 million, or 1.3%, from €92.0 million for the year ended September 30, 2016, to €93.2 million for the year ended September 30, 2017. This increase was primarily due to the Pelican Rouge Acquisition, which contributed €4.1 million to our depreciation and amortization expense from September 7, 2017, to September 30, 2017. Without giving effect to the Pelican Rouge Acquisition and the Baltics disposal, depreciation and amortization expense would have decreased by €2.9 million, or 3.1%, primarily as a result of a reduction to the PoS park, compared to the previous year. _Other Operating Expenses_ Other operating expenses increased by €24.2 million, or 11.7%, from €206.2 million for the year ended September 30, 2016, to €230.4 million for the year ended September 30, 2017. This increase was primarily due to the Pelican Rouge Acquisition and integration related advisory costs. In addition, IT outsourcing and ERP development expenses contributed €5.3 million to our other operating expenses. Additionally, vending fees also increased by €3.4 million to €88.9 million for the year ended September 30, 2017, due to an increase in public sales. Vending fees, as a percentage of public revenue, increased by 0.5%. _Finance Costs_ Finance costs increased by €17.9 million, or 20.9%, from €85.8 million for the year ended September 30, 2016 to €103.7 million for the year ended September 30, 2017. This increase was primarily due to a €4.9 million increase in non-cash interest charge on shareholder loans, financing transaction costs directly attributable to the Pelican Rouge Acquisition, and foreign exchange losses. _Finance Income_ Finance income increased by €3.1 million, or 70.5%, from €4.4 million for the year ended September 30, 2016, to €7.5 million for the year ended September 30, 2017. This increase was primarily due to a change in fair value of derivative financial instruments. 78 ----- _Income Taxes_ Income taxes decreased by €1.1 million, or 21.6%, from €5.1 million for the year ended September 30, 2016, to €4.0 million for the year ended September 30, 2017. This decrease was primarily due to the consolidation of Selecta headquarters in Switzerland, which led to lower income taxes and higher tax savings.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our principal sources of funds have been cash generated from our operating activities and borrowings under the Revolving Credit Facility. Our principal uses of cash are to fund debt service obligations, working capital and capital expenditures. As of June 30, 2019, we had cash and cash equivalents of €77.8 million. Our principal source of liquidity on an ongoing basis is expected to be our operating cash flows. Our ability to generate cash depends on our future operating performance, which, in turn, depends to some extent on general economic, financial, industry and other factors, many of which are beyond our control. See “Risk Factors.” In addition, we have access to the Revolving Credit Facility to service our working capital and general corporate needs. The continued availability of the Revolving Credit Facility is dependent upon certain conditions, including ongoing compliance with a maintenance covenant tested quarterly as described further under “Description of Other Indebtedness—Revolving Credit Facility Agreement.” Although we believe that our expected cash flows from operations, together with available borrowings under the Revolving Credit Facility, will be adequate to meet our anticipated liquidity and debt service needs, we cannot assure you that our business will generate sufficient cash flows from operating activities or that future debt financing will be available to us in an amount sufficient to enable us to pay our debts when due, or to fund our other liquidity needs.

Subsubsection Text: Cash outflow from movements in working capital amounted to €59.8 million for the nine months ended June 30, 2019, and was primarily attributable to the timing of payment of supplier invoices. Cash outflow from movements in working capital amounted to €89.4 million for the nine months ended June 30, 2018, and was primarily attributable to the transaction and integration costs relating to the Pelican Rouge Acquisition as well as the timing for payment of supplier invoices. For the financial years ended September 30, 2016, 2017, and 2018, we experienced structurally negative working capital as our receivables tend to outpace our creditor payments due to the historical phasing impact of working capital in the first half of the financial year and integration costs in connection with our various acquisitions, which are typically paid out in the second half of the year. Subsubsection Title: Net Cash Flows from Operating Activities
Subsubsection Text: _Comparison of the Nine Months Ended June 30, 2018 and 2019_ Net cash flows from operating activities increased by €40.4 million, or 129.1%, from €31.3 million for the nine months ended June 30, 2018 to €71.7 million for the nine months ended June 30, 2019. This increase was partially due to the acquisitions of Argenta and Express Vending, which contributed €11.5 million to operating cash flows for the nine months June 30, 2019, compared to the nine months ended June 30, 2018. This increase was partly offset by the impact of the disposal of Custompack Ltd. Without giving effect to acquisitions and disposals over the periods, the increase in operating cash flows for the nine months June 30, 2019, was primarily due to a decrease in losses before income tax combined with a decrease in cash outflow due to changes in working capital. _Comparison of the Years Ended September 30, 2017 and 2018_ Net cash flows from operating activities increased by €43.2 million, or 43.2%, from €99.9 million for the year ended September 30, 2017 to €143.1 million for the year ended September 30, 2018. This increase was primarily due to the acquisitions of Pelican Rouge, Argenta, and Express Vending, including synergies achieved in employee expenses and overall operating expense. _Comparison of the Years Ended September 30, 2016 and 2017_ Net cash flows from operating activities increased by €19.7 million, or 24.6%, from €80.2 million for the year ended September 30, 2016 to €99.9 million for the year ended September 30, 2017. This increase was primarily due to lower employee expenses driven by headcount reductions and overall operating expense, partly offset by the Pelican Rouge integration costs.

Subsubsection Title: Net Cash Flows Used in Investing Activities
Subsubsection Text: _Comparison of the Nine Months Ended June 30, 2018 and 2019_ Net cash flows used in investing activities increased from €101.8 million for the nine months ended June 30, 2018 to €116.0 million for the nine months ended June 30, 2019. This increase was primarily due to higher capital expenditures following the acquisitions of Pelican Rouge and Argenta. This increase was partly offset by proceeds from the sales of property, plant and equipment. This increase was also impacted by the proceeds from the sale of Selecta Finland in the nine months ended June 30, 2018. _Comparison of the Years Ended September 30, 2017 and 2018_ Net cash flows used in investing activities increased from €134.3 million for the year ended September 30, 2017 to €186.2 million for the year ended September 30, 2018. This increase was primarily due to the increased capital expenditure for property, plant, and equipment following the Pelican Rouge Acquisition and the Argenta Acquisition while the cash outflow for acquisition of subsidiaries net of proceeds from sale of subsidiaries remained relatively stable at €75.0 million. 80 ----- _Comparison of the Years Ended September 30, 2016 and 2017_ Net cash flows used in investing activities increased from €45.7 million for the year ended September 30, 2016 to €134.3 million for the year ended September 30, 2017. This increase was primarily due to the cash consideration of €119.2 million paid for the Pelican Rouge Acquisition, partially offset by cash acquired from Pelican Rouge.

Subsubsection Title: Net Cash Flows Used in Financing Activities
Subsubsection Text: _Comparison of the Nine Months Ended June 30, 2018 and 2019_ Net cash flows used in financing activities decreased from an inflow of €53.6 million for the nine months ended June 30, 2018, to an outflow of €47.0 million for the nine months ended June 30, 2019. This decrease was primarily due to (i) cash overfunding following the refinancing in the nine months ended June 30, 2018, (ii) the phasing of cash interest payments with interest incurred during the year ended September 30, 2018, being paid in the nine months ended June 30, 2019, which were partially offset by cash from additional drawings on our Revolving Credit Facility in the nine months ended June 30, 2019. _Comparison of the Years Ended September 30, 2017 and 2018_ Net cash flows used in financing activities decreased from €107.2 million for the year ended September 30, 2017 to €75.7 million for the year ended September 30, 2018. Cash inflows in 2017 were driven by the capital contribution by KKR while the cash inflows in 2018 were mainly due to the refinancing activities in February 2018, offset by cash outflows for the repayment under factoring arrangements and higher interest payments. _Comparison of the Years Ended September 30, 2016 and 2017_ Net cash flows used in financing activities increased to €107.2 million for the year ended September 30, 2017 from nil for the year ended September 30, 2016. This increase was primarily due to a capital contribution by KKR of €179.7 million to finance the Pelican Rouge Acquisition.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Net capital expenditures increased by €23.1 million, or 27.2%, from €85.0 million for the nine months ended June 30, 2018, to €108.1 million for the nine months ended June 30, 2019. This increase was primarily due to the acquisition of Argenta, which contributed €10.0 million of additional net capital expenditure for the nine months ended June 30, 2019, compared to the nine months ended June 30, 2018. Without giving effect to acquisitions and disposals over the period, our net capital expenditure for the nine months ended June 30, 2019, would have increased by €13.1 million compared to the nine months ended June 30, 2018, primarily due to increased investments in France following a period of underinvestment in the legacy Pelican Rouge entities, as well as ERP development expenses and new business gains in the on-the-go segments, predominantly in the Netherlands and Belgium. 81 ----- Net capital expenditures increased by €43.0 million, or 61.0%, from €70.5 million for the year ended September 30, 2017, to €113.5 million for the year ended September 30, 2018. This increase was primarily attributable to growth in the business in line with our investment strategy. Net capital expenditures decreased by €1.1 million, or 1.5%, from €71.6 million for the year ended September 30, 2016, to €70.5 million for the year ended September 30, 2017. This decrease was primarily attributable to various small and medium acquisitions in 2016. We estimate that we will require gross capital expenditures of approximately €100 million per year on PoS to support our current PoS park and revenue levels, in addition to capital expenditure for vehicles, IT and other equipment, of which approximately €20 million are expected to be financed through finance leases. In addition, we believe that we will require approximately €6 million of PoS gross capital expenditures to support each additional per cent of revenue growth. Our estimates with respect to future capital expenditure requirements may vary based on changes in our product, concept and segment mix. As our capital expenditure requirements vary from year to year based on different capital intensity in different business segments, specific reinvestment requirements in relation to new business, levels of capital expenditure funded through new PoS versus refurbished PoS and specific initiatives to develop telemetry and cashless payment technologies, among other factors, we cannot assure you that our level of capital expenditure will not increase significantly in the future. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Business—Our business _requires capital expenditures that may divert significant cash flow from other investments or uses, including debt servicing.”_
