Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our off-balance sheet liabilities relate primarily to land, buildings and vehicles under various operating lease agreements. As of June 30, 2019, we recorded expenses of €37.3 million for payments under operating lease agreements not recorded on our balance sheet and expenses in relation to property, plants, equipment and vehicles (excluding vending fees). As a result of the implementation of IFRS 16 beginning October 1, 2019, such agreements will have to be recognized on the balance sheet. Except as described above, we are not party to any off-balance sheet arrangements that have, or are reasonably likely to have, a current or future material effect on our financial condition, revenue or expenses, results of operations, liquidity, capital expenditure or capital resources.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: Interest rate risk is the risk that the fair value or future cash flows of a financial instrument will fluctuate because of changes in market interest rates. Our exposure to the risk of changes in market interest rates relate primarily to our long-term debt obligations with floating rate interests. 82 ----- The Revolving Credit Facility and the Floating Rate Notes bear interest at variable rates. While we may enter into hedging agreements in the future, we may also elect not to do so or the terms on which we hedge may not be satisfactory or may fail to adequately protect us from changes in market interest rates.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: Credit risk is the risk of financial loss resulting from counterparty failure to repay or service debt owed to us according to the contractual terms or obligations. We are exposed to credit risk on our trade receivables, non-current other financial assets and cash and cash equivalents. Trade receivables are subject to credit limits and ongoing credit evaluations in all of our subsidiaries. Due to our large geographic presence and large base of customers, we are not exposed to material concentrations of credit risk on our trade receivables and have no significant exposure to credit risk with any single counterparty. In addition, due the nature of our operations, a significant portion of our revenue is received in cash. We do not believe we are exposed to significant credit risk on our cash and cash equivalents as these are spread over several financial institutions in different countries.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: Liquidity risk is the risk of not being able to fulfill present or future obligations if we do not have sufficient funds available to meet such obligations at the time they become due. Liquidity risk arises mostly in relation to cash flows generated and used in working capital and from financing activities, particularly by servicing our debt, in terms of both interest and capital, and our payment obligations relating to our ordinary business activities. We manage liquidity risk by continuously monitoring our expected cash flows and working capital levels and ensuring that adequate borrowing facilities are maintained. We have several thresholds and approval requirements for borrowing and investing as well as for using derivative financial instruments. In general, subsidiaries may not borrow in their respective local currency without the approval of our Chief Financial Officer. The subsidiaries may also not hedge their foreign currency exposures without the approval of our Chief Financial Officer. Wherever possible, we require that subsidiaries repatriate all their excess cash and bank balances to Group finance companies to allow the Group to ensure that adequate funds are made available across the Group as necessary.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: Since each of our subsidiaries invoices its customers in the functional currency in which that subsidiary operates, and since the significant part of its cost base is also denominated in its functional currency, our exposure to currency risk is not significant. Translation exposure arises from the consolidation of operations whose functional currency is not the euro in our financial statements which are presented in euro. Previously, in order to minimize our exposure to translation risk, we had established the borrowings and related interest payments in the four main currencies in which we operate, namely EUR, CHF, GBP and SEK, in order to effect a natural hedge between our income and interest expenses. As of June 30, 2019 €1,163 million of our Existing Notes and our borrowings under the Revolving Credit Facility were denominated in EUR, 225 million in CHF and 34 million in GBP, and changes in foreign exchange rates will therefore give rise to foreign exchange exposure. While we may enter into hedging agreements in the future, we may also elect not to do so or the terms on which we hedge may not be satisfactory or may fail to adequately protect us from fluctuations in foreign exchange rates.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: We are exposed to commodity price risk because of coffee price fluctuations. Some of these fluctuations can be passed on to customers through price increases in line with contractual conditions. In order to manage risks from fluctuations in commodities prices, we secure the requirements for green bean for periods of up to six months by instructing the relevant supplier to source the required green beans to cover certain production lots at a specific price. With certain strategic suppliers, we enter into longer-term agreements with agreed price adjustment mechanisms that reflect developments in commodity prices. We periodically assess the economic impact of hedging coffee bean prices but consider the hedging cost too high to make hedging financially attractive. However, while we do not enter into hedging instruments with respect to coffee prices, coffee volumes are committed with suppliers between one and six months in advance depending on current green bean coffee prices and expectations of future price development. 83 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: In the ordinary course of business, we are exposed to a variety of market risks including credit risk, interest rate risk and liquidity risk. We monitor and manage these risks as a part of our overall risk management. The following section discusses the significant financial risks to which we are exposed. This discussion does not address other risks to which we are exposed in the ordinary course of business, such as operational risks. See “Risk Factors” and note 30 to our 2018 Consolidated Financial Statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Goodwill and Intangible Assets with Indefinite Useful Lives
Subsubsection Text: The cash-generating unit to which goodwill is allocated and other intangible assets with indefinite useful lives are tested for impairment annually and whenever there is an indication that they may be impaired. The recoverable amounts of cash generating units and intangible assets with indefinite useful lives are determined based on their values in use. These calculations require the use of estimates and assumptions consistent with the most up-to-date business plans that have been formally approved by management.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Intangible assets resulting from the acquisition of customer contracts in a business combination have a finite useful life and are amortized over the determined life of 10 or 15 years. We actively monitor retention rates on customer contracts and consider other relevant factors which may provide an indication of impairment.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The present value of the pension obligations depends on a variety of factors that are estimated annually by independent actuaries using a number of assumptions, including the discount rate to be applied to determine the present value of defined benefit obligations. In determining the appropriate discount rate, we consider the interest rates of high-quality corporate bonds that are denominated in the currency in which the benefits will be paid, and that have terms to maturity approximating the terms of the related pension liability.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Deferred income tax assets on unused tax losses carried forward are recognized to the extent it is probable that there will be future taxable profits against which the losses can be offset. The assessment of recoverability of the recognized deferred income tax assets is based on assumptions regarding future profits and is derived from the latest budgets and business plans of the Group.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Provisions are recognized when the Group has a present obligation (legal or constructive) as a result of a past event, it is probable that an outflow of resources will be required to settle the obligation, and a reliable estimate can be made of the amount of the obligation. The amount recognized as a provision is based on management’s best estimate of the consideration required to settle the obligation at the end of the reporting period, taking into account the risks and uncertainties surrounding the obligation. Provisions for warranties are ordinarily determined by product line and are based on statistics including the likelihood of a breakdown occurring and the average cost of repair or replacement.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Where sales are based on consumption in the PoS, there may be a timing difference between the date on which the cash was last collected from the PoS and the date on which the sales readings were taken. In this case, an estimate of the sales between the date of the last cash collection or the last PoS reading and the end of the period is made. The estimate is based on historical sales trends in respect of the specific customer sites and PoS. The estimated amount of sales which have been neither collected in cash nor invoiced to customers are recorded as accrued income and uncollected cash in points-of-sale. 84 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Food and beverage inventories which have passed their sell by date are fully provided against. Similarly, where the level of food and beverage inventories held exceeds the sales expected to be achieved before the sell by date, a provision is made for the excess inventory held. Provisions for equipment in inventory are recorded against PoS in inventory according to the age of the PoS. Provisions for spare parts held in inventory are calculated according to the inventory turnover ratio. 85 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our Historical Financial Statements and the accompanying notes contain information that is pertinent to the discussion and analysis of our results of operations and financial condition set forth above. The preparation of our Historical Financial Statements requires management to make judgments, estimates and assumptions that affect the application of policies and reported amounts of assets and liabilities, income and expenses and the disclosure of contingent liabilities at the reporting date. These estimates and assumptions are based on historical experience and other factors that are believed to be reasonable under the circumstances. However, actual results may differ from these estimates and assumptions. The estimates and assumptions that have a significant risk of causing a material adjustment to the carrying value of assets and liabilities in future periods are summarized below. For a more detailed description of our significant accounting policies, see note 3 of our 2018 Consolidated Financial Statements.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _The following is a discussion and analysis of our financial condition and results of operations and should be read in conjunction with the Selecta Financial Statements which were prepared in accordance with IFRS, as well as with “Selected Historical Financial Data,” and “Presentation of Financial and Other Information,” included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. For purposes of this section, all references to “Selecta,” “we,” “us,” “our” or the “Group” in respect of historical financial information are to Selecta Group B.V. and its subsidiaries on a consolidated basis. The following discussion and analysis contains forward-looking statements which, although based on assumptions that we consider reasonable, are subject to risks and uncertainties which could cause our actual results or conditions to differ materially from those expressed or implied by the forward-looking statements. For a discussion of risks and uncertainties facing us as a result of various factors, see “Forward-Looking Statements” and “Risk Factors.” The following discussion of our results of operations also makes reference to certain non-GAAP financial measures. Prospective investors should bear in mind that these Non-GAAP Measures are not financial measures defined in accordance with IFRS, may not be comparable to other similarly titled measures of other companies, have limitations as analytical tools and should not be considered in isolation or as a substitute for analysis of our operating results as reported under IFRS. See “Presentation of Financial and Other Information— Non-GAAP Financial Information—Non-GAAP Financial Measures.”_

Subsection Title: Description of Adjustments to the Unaudited Aggregated Non-GAAP Financial Information
Subsubsection Text: The Unaudited Non-GAAP Aggregated Financial Information has been adjusted to give effect to the transactions described below, as if they had occurred on October 1, 2015, to the extent they were not already reflected in the relevant period: - the acquisition by Selecta AG of Pelican Rouge Group, which occurred on September 7, 2017, and contributes to the adjustments for the period from October 1, 2015, to September 6, 2017; - the acquisition by TopCo of Argenta Group, which occurred on February 2, 2018, and contributes to the adjustments for the period from October 1, 2015, to February 1, 2018; 86 ----- - the acquisition by Selecta AG of Express Vending Group, which occurred on August 17, 2018, and contributes to the adjustments for the period from October 1, 2015, to August 16, 2018; - the disposal of Pelican Rouge subsidiaries in Sweden, which occurred in March 2016, and contributes to the adjustments for the period from October 1, 2015, to the date of disposal in March 2016; - the disposal of Pelican Rouge subsidiaries in Germany, which occurred in March 2016, and contributes to the adjustments for the period from October 1, 2015, to the date of disposal in March 2016; - the disposal of Selecta subsidiaries in Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia, which occurred in March 2017, and contributes to the adjustments for the period from October 1, 2015, to September 30, 2016; - the disposal of a Selecta subsidiary in Finland, which occurred in March 2018, and contributes to the adjustments for the period from October 1, 2015, to September 30, 2017; and - the disposal of Custompack Ltd., which occurred on September 19, 2018, and contributes to the adjustments for the period from October 1, 2015, to September 18, 2018. While the Unaudited Non-GAAP Aggregated Financial Information has been adjusted to reflect acquisitions that we consider significant, it does not reflect all acquisitions we have completed during the relevant period. We categorize acquisitions of businesses with less than €3.0 million in gross sales for the twelve months preceding such acquisition as part of our organic growth. Consequently, transactions involving such acquisitions are not included in the constant scope adjustments to our Historical Financial Statements. In addition to the above, adjustments have been made to align the fiscal period of acquired companies with Selecta’s financial year and also as a result of accounting policy differences and reclassifications, as further detailed below under “—Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) and Adjusted Net Revenue (CS & CC)” and “—Adjusted _EBITDA (CS & CC).”_

Subsection Title: Description of Adjustments to the Unaudited Aggregated Non-GAAP Financial Information
Subsubsection Text: We are a geographically diversified business with operations in 16 countries across Europe and accordingly we undertake transactions in various currencies. Many of our subsidiaries report their financial results in currencies other than the euro, the reporting currency used in our Historical Financial Statements. See “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Quantitative and _Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk—Foreign Currency Risk.” To enhance the comparability of our_ financial results, such results are presented using a constant exchange rate across all periods presented. Measures calculated using constant exchange rates are not required by, or presented in accordance with, IFRS. The exchange rates used for the calculation of constant exchange rate measures presented in this Offering Memorandum have been derived from the European Central Bank as of September 2017, which constitute our budget exchange rates for the financial years 2018 and 2019 as set out in the following table:

Subsection Title: Description of Adjustments to the Unaudited Aggregated Non-GAAP Financial Information
Subsubsection Text: The Unaudited Non-GAAP Aggregated Financial Information has been derived by applying certain adjustments to each of our Historical Financial Statements and the financial statements of the Pelican Rouge Group, the Argenta Group and the Express Vending Group for the relevant periods in order to aid in their comparability. Such adjustments fall within two categories, adjusting for the scope of the financial information included (constant scope adjustments) and the exchange rates used in respect of the financial information recorded in currencies other than euro (constant currency adjustments), as described in detail below.

Subsection Title: Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) and Adjusted Net Revenue (CS & CC)
Subsubsection Text: The following table presents a reconciliation from our revenue to our Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) and our Adjusted Net Revenue (CS & CC) for the years ended September 30, 2016, 2017 and 2018, the nine months ended June 30, 2018 and 2019, and the twelve months ended June 30, 2019:

(1) Represents the gross revenue of Selecta for the periods presented based on our Historical Financial Statements for each period. (2) Represents the revenue contribution of Pelican Rouge to illustrate the addition of Pelican Rouge’s revenue to the Group’s revenue for each period presented prior to the Pelican Rouge Acquisition, based on Pelican Rouge’s financial statements for each period, and to exclude Pelican Rouge revenue for the 24-day period from the closing of the Pelican Rouge Acquisition through September 30, 2017. The constant scope adjustments include adjustments made in respect of aligning Pelican Rouge’s financial year with Selecta’s financial year, based on Pelican Rouge’s audited financial statements for the years ended March 31, 2016 and 2017, interim financial statements for the six months ended September 30, 2016 and 2017, and management accounts for the six months ended September 30, 2015. (3) Represents the revenue contribution of the Argenta Group to illustrate the addition of Argenta’s revenue to the Group’s revenue for each period presented prior to the Argenta Acquisition, based on Argenta’s financial statements for each period. Because the Argenta Acquisition occurred prior to Argenta’s preparation of its interim financial results, the calculation of Argenta’s revenue between October 1, 2017, and February 2, 2018, is based on management records. (4) Represents the revenue contribution of the Express Vending Group to illustrate the addition of Express Vending’s revenue to the Group’s revenue for each period presented prior to the Express Vending Acquisition, based on Express Vending’s management accounts. Express Vending’s revenue is converted from pound sterling to euro for each period at the applicable exchange rates used by Selecta in its Historical Financial Statements. (5) Represents the revenue contribution of the following businesses, prior to the date of their disposal: (i) Pelican Rouge German entities (October 1, 2015, to the date of disposal in March 2016), (ii) Pelican Rouge Swedish entities (October 1, 2015, to the date of disposal in March 2016), (iii) Selecta subsidiaries in Lithuania, Latvia, and Estonia (October 1, 2015, through September 30, 2016), (iv) Selecta subsidiaries in Finland (October 1, 2015, through September 30, 2017), and (v) Custompack Ltd. (October 1, 2015, through September 18, 2018). (6) Represents (i) certain IFRS and accounting policy adjustments in respect of vendor leases that are capitalized into the purchase price of machinery, (ii) certain reclassifications representing differences in accounting policy at Argenta in respect of revenue recognition relating to marketing contribution, transportation costs, and non-recurring income, and (iii) adjustments to convert the revenue from Pelican Rouge’s subsidiaries in the UK and Norway to euro for each period under review at the exchange rates used in the relevant Historical Financial Statements. (7) Other adjustments include, among others, revenues of Selecta Finland that were classified as intercompany revenues in Selecta’s accounting records and that are reclassified as third party revenue to give effect to the disposal of our subsidiary in Finland in March 2018. (8) Represents adjustments to exclude the effects of changes in currency value in the relevant periods based on a constant currency rate, as set out under “—Description of Adjustments to the Unaudited Aggregated Non-GAAP Financial Information—Constant Currency _Adjustments.”_ (9) Represents the vending fees for each of Selecta, Pelican Rouge and Argenta, adjusted for scope and reconciliation, reclassification, and constant currency adjustments, each as detailed above. (10) Adjusted Net Revenue (CS & CC) is defined as Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) less vending fees for each of Selecta, Pelican Rouge and Argenta, adjusted for scope and reconciliation, reclassification, and constant currency adjustments. 88 ----- In addition, the following table illustrates our Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) per geographic segment for the years ended September 30, 2016, 2017 and 2018, the nine months ended June 30, 2018 and 2019, and the twelve months ended June 30, 2019. See “Presentation of Financial and Other Information—Non-GAAP Financial _Information—Unaudited Non-GAAP Aggregated Financial Information” for an explanation of our categories of_ geographic markets’ financial performance.

Subsection Title: Year ended** **Nine months ended Twelve September 30,** **June 30, months ended (in € million)** **2016** **2017** **2018** **2018** **2019** **June 30, 2019 Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC)

Subsubsection Title: Comparison of Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) for the Nine Months Ended June 30, 2019, to the Nine Months Ended June 30, 2018
Subsubsection Text: Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) for the nine months ended June 30, 2019, amounted to €1,217.7 million, an increase of €40.4 million, or 3.4% compared to Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) of €1,177.3 million for the nine months ended June 30, 2018. Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) for the nine months ended June 30, 2019, increased in all the countries in which we operate, except in France and the UK due to customer retention challenges and a decrease in the size of the machine park related to the legacy Pelican Rouge business. However, Adjusted Revenue (CS &CC) in the UK for the three months ended June 30, 2019, increased compared to the three months ended June 30, 2018, due to a new contract with Coca Cola. - _South, UK & Ireland. Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) in the South, UK & Ireland region for the nine months ended June 30, 2019, increased by €17.0 million compared to the nine months ended June 30, 2018. This increase was primarily due to successful bolt-on acquisitions in Italy and organic revenue growth and bolt-on acquisitions in Spain, where we won a new contract with the Madrid airport driving significantly higher revenue from our public business channel. In addition, the revenue of Express Vending in the UK grew by 13.7% for the nine months ended June 30, 2019, compared to the nine months ended June 30, 2018. - _North. Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) in the North region for the nine months ended June 30, 2019, increased by €25.2 million compared to nine months ended June 30, 2018, primarily due an increase in revenue from our public business channel in the Netherlands and in Belgium following a new contract with Euro Garages in these countries, and from our trade business channel in Sweden, the Netherlands, Belgium and Norway. - _Central. Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) in the Central region for the nine months ended June 30, 2019, decreased by €1.8 million compared to nine months ended June 30, 2018. This decrease was due to a €10.3 million decrease in Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) in France. Excluding our results of operations in France, Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) in our region Central increased by €8.5 million or 3.8%, driven by organic growth in our public business channel in Switzerland, as well as revenue growth in our trade business due to bolt-on acquisitions. Our Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) for the nine months ended June 30, 2019, also increased by €1.2 million or 2.7% in Germany due to Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) growth in our private business channel, mainly related to our new contract with Daimler.

Subsubsection Title: Comparison of Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) for the Year Ended September 30, 2018, to the Year Ended September 30, 2017
Subsubsection Text: Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) for the year ended September 30, 2018, amounted to €1,564.3 million, an increase of €58.7 million, or 3.9% compared to Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) of €1,505.5 million for the year ended September 30, 2017. This increase was primarily due to the harmonization of vending fees across the 89 ----- Group, which was completed during the year ended September 30, 2018, and resulted in an alignment of reporting practices between legacy Selecta entities and the integrated entities of Pelican Rouge and Argenta. We harmonized our reporting practices based on reporting standards applicable to our business models. This harmonization of vending fees resulted in an increase in Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) for the year ended September 30, 2018, of €25.8 million compared to the year ended September 30, 2017, with a positive impact on our Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) in certain countries, mainly in Switzerland, France and the UK, which was partly offset by a negative impact on our Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) in Italy. Without giving effect to the harmonization of vending fees, Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) for the year ended September 30, 2018, amounted to €1,538.5 million, an increase of €32.9 million, or 2.2%, compared to Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) of €1,505.5 million for the year ended September 30, 2017. Our Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) for the year ended September 30, 2018, increased in all our markets, except in the UK, compared to the year ended September 30, 2017. - _South, UK & Ireland. Our Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) in the South, UK & Ireland region for the year ended September 30, 2018, increased by €13.7 million (without giving effect to harmonization of vending fees) compared to the year ended September 30, 2017, primarily due to growth in Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) in Italy and Spain. Our operations in Spain benefitted from the development of new concepts and higher daily revenue per PoS across all business channels, whereas growth in sales in Italy was supported by the development of new concepts, bolt-on acquisitions and improved daily revenue per PoS in the workplace channel. This increase was partially offset by lower sales in the UK due to the legacy Pelican Rouge business and customer retention challenges in the first part of the year ended September 30, 2018. - _North. Our Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) in the North region for the year ended September 30, 2018, increased by €14.4 million (without giving effect to harmonization of vending fees) compared to the year ended September 30, 2017, primarily due to Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) growth in Sweden, Belgium, Norway and Denmark, mainly from an increase in trading sales and, to a lesser extent, successful rollouts in our semi-public business in Sweden and Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) growth in or public business in Belgium and Denmark. - _Central. Our Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) in the Central region for the year ended September 30, 2018, increased by €5.6 million (without giving effect to harmonization of vending fees) compared to the year ended September 30, 2017. This increase was primarily due to Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) growth in Austria and, to a lesser extent, in Switzerland and Germany. We also benefitted from an increase in Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) in France in our public business channel, partly offset by lower sales in the workplace and semi-public channels due to a decrease in sales from legacy Pelican Rouge entities and customer retention challenges in France.

Subsubsection Title: Comparison of Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) for the Year Ended September 30, 2017, to the Year Ended September 30, 2016
Subsubsection Text: Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) for the year ended September 30, 2017, amounted to €1,505.5 million, an increase of €4.9 million, or 0.3% compared to Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) of €1,500.7 million for the year ended September 30, 2016. - _South, UK & Ireland. Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) in the South, UK & Ireland region for the year ended September 30, 2017, decreased by €1.9 million compared to the year ended September 30, 2016. This increase was primarily due to revenue growth in Italy, driven by revenue from new contracts as well as positive pricing effects and acquisitions, and in the UK due to an increase of 13.6% in Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) from Express Vending. This increase was partly offset by a decrease in revenue from the legacy Pelican Rouge business in the UK driven by the loss of key contracts. - _North. Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) in the North region for the year ended September 30, 2017, increased by €8.0 million compared to the year ended September 30, 2016. This increase was primarily due to the introduction of the Starbucks concept in gas stations in the Netherlands and in Denmark, which led to significant gains in our public business channel. We also benefitted from an increase of 4.9% in Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) from our roaster over the periods. - _Central. Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) in the Central region for the year ended September 30, 2017, decreased by €2.2 million compared to the year ended September 30, 2016. This increase was primarily due to lower revenue from the Pelican Rouge entities in France driven by the loss of key contracts. This 90 ----- decrease was partly offset by Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) increase in Germany driven by higher revenue in our public business channel due to new contracts with Deutsche Bahn and Frankfurt Airport.

(1) The UK contributed €200.7 million, €190.4 million, and €189.2 million, to our Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) for the years ended September 30, 2016, 2017, and 2018 respectively, and €186.2 million for the twelve months ended June 30, 2019. (2) France contributed €298.2 million, €287.9 million, and €295.6 million, to our Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) for the years ended September 30, 2016, 2017, and 2018 respectively, and €285.3 million for the twelve months ended June 30, 2019.

The constant scope adjustments include adjustments made in respect of aligning Pelican Rouge’s financial year with Selecta’s financial year, based on Pelican Rouge’s audited financial statements for the years ended March 31, 2016 and 2017, interim financial statements for the six months ended September 30, 2016 and 2017, and management accounts for the six months ended September 30, 2015. (7) Other adjustments include, among others, adjustments required to align the accounting methods of the management accounting software used by Pelican Rouge (Hyperion) with the software used by Selecta (Cognos). Subsubsection Text: (a) Represents expenses related to external consulting fees and expenses incurred as a result of internal projects for Selecta and Express Vending, such as upgrading our PoS park and IT outsourcing projects. For the years ended September 30, 2016 and 2017, such expenses related to assessing the business and implementing new strategies and planning the Pelican Rouge Acquisition. For the financial year ended September 30, 2018, such expenses related to fees incurred in connection with the Express Vending Acquisition. (b) Represents costs associated with implementing integration plans following acquisitions such as the Pelican Rouge Acquisition or the Argenta Acquisition. Such costs include expenses in each period including costs for design, implementation, and continuous updates of the synergies tracking tool, and external advisor fees in relation to the implementation of Pelican Rouge into the Group. (d) Represents costs related to the roll out of telemetry across our markets. (e) Strategic transactions costs relate to external fees incurred in connection with the investments in capabilities related to certain strategic transactions and the offering of Existing Notes in the year ended September 30, 2018. (f) Represents costs in relation to external advisor fees in relation to our acquisition strategy in the year ended September 30, 2018. (g) Profit/(loss) on the sale of non-trading assets and subsidiaries consists of the gains or losses on asset sales, including assets owned by disposed business units and exited warehouses and the disposal of the Eastern European countries (disposed of in financial year 2015, with an EBITDA impact in financial year 2016), the Baltics (Lithuania, Latvia, and Estonia) and Finland and Custompack Ltd. in the years ended September 30, 2016, 2017 and 2018, respectively. (h) Other adjustments in the year ended September 30, 2016, primarily relate to our antitrust fine from the Italian Competition Authority and restructuring costs. See “Business—Legal, Arbitral and Administrative Proceedings.” In the year ended September 30, 2017, these adjustments primarily include costs related to restructuring and external consulting fees in connection with the issuance of the Existing Notes. (10) Represents estimated annualized run-rate cost savings and synergies, which we expect to achieve as a result of the Pelican Rouge Acquisition and the Argenta Acquisition but have not yet realized. In total, we expect to realize approximately €75 million of annualized run-rate cost synergies from these acquisitions by the end of 2020. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2019, we estimate that we have realized approximately €52 million of these cost synergies, which represents 69% of our total expected cost synergies. See “Risk _Factors—Risks Related to Our Business—We may not be able to realize the anticipated operational efficiencies and cost savings in connection with acquisitions (including the Pelican Rouge Acquisition, the Argenta Acquisition and the Express Vending Acquisition)”_ and “Forward-Looking Statements.” For additional information on our expected cost savings and synergies, see “Management’s _Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations and Financial Condition—Anticipated Cost Savings and Synergies Resulting from Acquisitions.”_ In addition, the following table illustrates our Adjusted EBITA (CS & CC) and Adjusted EBIT (CS & CC) for the years ended September 30, 2016, 2017 and 2018, for the nine months ended June 30, 2018 and 2019, and for the twelve months ended June 30, 2019:

Subsection Title: Twelve Year ended** **Nine months months ended September 30,** **ended June 30, June 30, (in € million)** **2016** **2017** **2018** **2018** **2019** **2019 Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC)

Subsubsection Title: Comparison of Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) for the Nine Months Ended June 30, 2019, to the Nine Months Ended June 30, 2018
Subsubsection Text: Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) for the nine months ended June 30, 2019, amounted to €201.0 million, an increase of €17.8 million, or 9.7% compared to Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) of €183.2 million for the nine months ended June 30, 2018. We achieved synergies and cost savings of €24 million for the nine months ended June 30, 2019, compared to the nine months ended June 30, 2018. We also undertook significant growth investments over the period, primarily consisting of investments in (i) our sales force to drive organic growth; (ii) innovation, mainly new concepts and digitalization; (iii) infrastructure and (iv) our support functions such as legal, finance and human resources, to activate strategic business partnership; and (v) off-balance sheet financing projects to implement our strategy of optimizing capital expenditures. This increase was also due to an increase of €2.4 million in Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) for the nine months ended June 30, 2019, compared to the nine months ended June 30, 2018, due to bolt-on acquisitions, mainly in Italy, Switzerland, Spain, Germany and the UK. Below is a discussion of drivers for the increase in our Adjusted EBITDA (CS &CC) for the nine months ended June 30, 2019 compared to the nine months ended June 30, 2018: - _South, UK & Ireland. Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) in the South, UK & Ireland region for the nine months ended June 30, 2019, increased by €5.3 million compared to the nine months ended June 30, 2018, primarily due to an increase in revenue in Spain and from Express Vending, as well as cost savings and rightsizing personnel and overhead expenses reductions in the UK. - _North. Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) in the North region for the nine months ended June 30, 2019, increased by €15.8 million compared to nine months ended June 30, 2018, primarily due to higher revenue across the region over the period, including from our roaster business which benefitted from favorable coffee prices. - _Central. Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) in the Central region for the nine months ended June 30, 2019, decreased by €4.7 million compared to nine months ended June 30, 2018. This decrease was due to our results of operations in France, where our Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) for the nine months ended June 30, 2019, declined by €8.5 million compared to the nine months ended June 30, 2018. This decrease was partly offset by our results in Switzerland driven by higher revenue and operational excellence initiatives. - _Headquarters. Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) at our Headquarters for the nine months ended June 30, 2019, increased by €1.5 million compared to nine months ended June 30, 2018, primarily due to our leaner corporate structure. Our Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) margin for the nine months ended June 30, 2019 (calculated as Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) divided by Adjusted Net Revenue (CS & CC)), remained stable compared to the nine months ended June 30, 2018, due to the usually low margin in trade sales being offset by procurement synergy savings as well as pricing and category managements initiatives. 93 -----

Subsubsection Title: Comparison of Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) for the Year Ended September 30, 2018, to the Year Ended June 30, 2017
Subsubsection Text: Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) for the year ended September 30, 2018, amounted to €253.3 million, an increase of €13.3 million, or 5.5% compared to Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) of €240.0 million for the year ended September 30, 2017. We achieved reduction of operating expenses for the year ended September 30, 2018, compared to the year ended September 30, 2017, as a result of our cost savings initiatives. These savings were partly reinvested in operational capabilities, mainly in sales, and to develop technology and off-balance sheet financing projects to optimize capital expenditures. - _South, UK & Ireland. Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) in the South, UK & Ireland region for the year ended September 30, 2018, increased by €9.1 million compared to the year ended September 30, 2017. This increase was primarily due to the performance of our business in Spain across all business channels and synergies achieved in Spain and in the UK through rightsizing personnel and overhead expenses reductions. - _North. Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) in the North region for the year ended September 30, 2018, increased by €1.3 million, compared to the year ended September 30, 2017. This increase was due to the performance of our business in the region, partly offset by higher sales from our trade business channel, which is less profitable, and investments in operational capabilities and off-balance sheet financing projects to optimize capital expenditures, which impacted operating expenses. - _Central. Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) in the Central region for the year ended September 30, 2018, decreased by €8.8 million compared to the year ended September 30, 2017, mainly due to significant one-time income in the year ended September 30, 2017 that did not recur in the year ended September 30, 2018 related to, among others, pension adjustments in Switzerland, partly offset by the performance of our business in France. - _Headquarters. Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) at our Headquarters for the year ended September 30, 2018, increased by €11.7 million compared to the year ended September 30, 2017, driven by a €12 million benefit from a one-off reset of pension plans in a legacy Pelican Rouge headquarter entity in the UK. Our Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) margin for the year ended September 30, 2018 (calculated as Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) divided by Adjusted Net Revenue (CS & CC)) remained stable compared to the year ended September 30, 2017, due to the usually low margin in trade sales being offset by procurement synergy savings as well as pricing and category managements initiatives.

Subsubsection Title: Comparison of Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) for the Year Ended September 30, 2017, to the Year Ended September 30, 2016
Subsubsection Text: Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) for the year ended September 30, 2017, amounted to €240.0 million, an increase of €5.9 million, or 2.5%, compared to Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) of €234.1 million for the year ended September 30, 2016. - _South, UK & Ireland. Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) in the South, UK & Ireland region for the year ended September 30, 2017, decreased by €2.5 million compared to the year ended September 30, 2016. This decrease was primarily due to higher personnel costs following machine park increases in Italy and higher national labor contract rates, which offset the performance of our business in Italy. To a lesser extent, this decrease was also attributable to the performance of our business in the UK, which was largely offset by personnel and operating costs savings with respect to Selecta and Pelican Rouge entities in the UK. - _North. Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) in the North region for the year ended September 30, 2017, increased by €0.9 million compared to the year ended September 30, 2016, primarily due to the performance of our business in the Netherlands and Denmark, which was largely offset by a decrease in profit in Sweden due to the increased use of customer-owned machines which lead to lower service fees. - _Central. Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) in the Central region for the year ended September 30, 2017, increased by €6.0 million compared to the year ended September 30, 2016. This increase was primarily due to the profitability of our business in Switzerland, driven by savings in personnel expenses and increases in non-operating income, and, to a lesser extent, lower cost of sales in the region due to the 94 ----- termination of low-margin contracts and procurement and costs savings initiatives. This increase was partially offset by a decrease in profits in France due to the legacy Pelican Rouge entities. - _Headquarters. Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) at our Headquarters for the year ended September 30, 2017, increased by €1.5 million compared to the year ended September 30, 2016, primarily due to lower expenditures at Pelican Rouge headquarters. Our Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) margin for the year ended September 30, 2017 (calculated as Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) divided by Adjusted Net Revenue (CS & CC)) remained stable compared to the year ended September 30, 2016, due to the usually low margin in trade sales being offset by procurement synergy savings as well as pricing and category managements initiatives.

Subsection Title: INDUSTRY Leading Route-Based Unattended Self Service Coffee and Convenience Food Provider in Europe
Subsubsection Text: We are the leading route-based unattended self-service and convenience food provider in the European region, with an installed base of over 475,000 PoS. We operate in 16 countries, covering approximately 95% of European GDP and approximately 78% of the population. According to OC&C and our internal estimates, we have the number one or number two market position in the Unattended SSR Market (as defined below) in all but one of the Focus Countries (as defined below). Overall, we have the number one or number two market position in ten of our markets. Moreover, we are number one in Europe with approximately 10% market share. We believe that our adjusted revenue (on a constant scope and constant currency basis) for the year ended September 30, 2018, was approximately 3.5 times higher than the second largest competitor.

Subsection Title: Market Opportunity of the Convenience Market
Subsubsection Text: According to OC&C, the total out-of-home food and drink market is €845 billion. This includes all spend at restaurants, cafes and bars, and unattended self-service retail items. Within the total out-of-home food and beverage market, we operate in the Addressable Market (as defined below) of €42 billion, consisting of all convenience spend on hot and cold beverages, and snacks. The Unattended Self Service Retail Market is a subset of the Addressable Market, and is estimated to be €15 billion. It includes both Unattended Self Service Retail (at work and on-the-go) and capsule coffee at the office.

Subsubsection Title: Definition and Overview of the Core Unattended Self-Service Retail and Addressable Markets
Subsubsection Text: We operate within the Unattended SSR Market, which can be categorized into two main segments: Workplace which includes private segment and OCS, and on-the-go which includes public and semi-public segment. We estimate that the Unattended SSR Market is a €15 billion market in the Focus Countries. Through the continued development and expansion of new concepts, such as MicroMarkets, we are increasingly involved in the broader addressable convenience market (the “Addressable Market”), which spans the Unattended SSR Market, as well as the broader convenience market with other retail formats (e.g. street stalls, kiosks and convenience stores), and has a market size of €42 billion in the Focus Countries. The Addressable Market can also be categorized into the two segments of workplace and on-the-go. Within the Addressable Market, in addition to Unattended SSR Market, the workplace segment includes cafeterias and the on-the-go segment includes convenience foodservice and packaged foods. The workplace segment aims at improving the experience of people at work, for example by enhancing employee engagement, satisfaction, and productivity in the work environment. Through vending and office coffee services, unattended self-service retailers, such as us, service private businesses and corporate offices in places generally not accessible by other retail formats. Unattended self-service retailers that enter into three to five year contacts with corporate customers receive proceeds through sale of goods from impulse and coffee machines, servicing fees and revenues from sales of coffee beans and other consumables. We pay rent to selected large private customers based on percentage of sales, a flat fee, or a combination thereof. The workplace segment accounted for approximately 36% (by value) of the Addressable Market in the Focus Countries in 2017. In addition to self-service PoS, this segment includes cafeteria and capsules, whereby cafeterias include hot drinks and snacks, but exclude warm lunches, and capsules include machines and capsules provided by the employer in small and medium office environments. The on-the-go segment aims to enhance the consumer experience by providing tailored coffee and snacking offerings in public (e.g. train and gas stations or airports) and semi-public locations (e.g. hospitals and public schools). Contracts typically range between five to ten years. We receive proceeds from the sales of goods from PoS and pay rent to customers based on a percentage of sales, a flat fee, or a combination thereof. The on-the-go segment accounted for approximately 64% (by value) of the Addressable Market in the Focus Countries in 2017. In addition to self-service PoS, this segment includes convenience foodservice and packaged food retailing. Convenience foodservice includes products prepared for take-away/ready-to-eat, hot drinks (especially coffee), as well as value-add drinks sold in street stalls, kiosks and specialized coffee shops. Packaged food retailing includes packaged food, confectionary items, snacks and soft drinks sold in convenience stores and forecourt retailers. Within the Unattended SSR Market, approximately 85% (by value) is in the workplace segment in the Focus Countries in 2017. This segment includes PoS located in private businesses and is comprised of (i) fully operated PoS offering hot drinks and impulse items (cold drinks and snacks) (i.e., private self-service retail), and (ii) coffee machines (often table-top) operated (cleaned and refilled) by the employer located in private businesses (i.e., OCS). The remainder of the Unattended SSR Market (approximately 15% by value) in the Focus Countries in 2017 lies in the on-the-go segment. This segment includes the sale of hot drinks and impulse items at public locations (e.g. train stations, gas stations) and semi-public locations (e.g. hospitals, universities). The trade segment provides a full suite of services and coffee and coffee related products to customers. Selecta receives proceeds from the sales of roasted coffee beans, PoS, other goods, and third party technical servicing. 97 -----

Subsection Title: Overview of the Self-service Retail Value Chain
Subsubsection Text: Self-service retail operators distribute food and drink products to consumers through their PoS portfolio. While consumers consume the products, self-service retail operators contract primarily with the facility management functions of private entities (e.g. offices, factories) and infrastructure functions of public entities (e.g. rail stations, airports). Through contractual agreements, customers compensate the self-service retail operators for providing a full or partial service. The value chain for the self-service retail industry includes several key participants and areas:

Subsection Title: Machine manufacturing and consumables End consumer** **production
Subsubsection Text: Employees, students, commuters, Machine or automated coffee passengers, etc. machine manufacturing, as well as snack / beverage / coffee production (roaster)

Subsection Title: Financing and provision of B2B contractors** **machines
Subsubsection Text: Private entities (at Buying, owning and leasing / workplace), and selling machine portfolio, infrastructure functions of installation at site and public entities, e.g. rail technical service / repair stations, airports (on-the-go)

Restocking of products, Provision of Products, including cleaning and maintenance coffee, snacks and cold beverages, as well as ware housing and logistics Our offering spans sourcing and roasting of coffee, provision of self-service PoS, product supply and restocking, and hygiene services. Our operations span across the value chain of the Unattended SSR Market. We purchase machines for our customers, install them at their premises and manage sourcing and stocking of the food and beverages on behalf of our customers. We provide quality coffee brands and convenient food and beverage concepts, including premium coffee concepts through our own brand Pelican Rouge and our Starbucks and Lavazza partnerships. We also offer cleaning, maintenance and technical support services, which can be customized to individual customers’ preferences. In addition to our self-service retail operations, we sell machines, machine parts and products independently of service arrangements. 98 -----

Subsection Title: Overview of Self-service Retail Business Models
Subsubsection Text: Business models can be differentiated depending on the level of services provided. Additionally, some selfservice retail operators offer the sale of ingredients (such as coffee beans, ground coffee, milk (powder) and sugar), machines and machine parts as well as technical services. The provided level of service typically varies with PoS density which determines profitability levels. The workplace segment with larger companies (with more than 250 employees) typically provides for large scale full-service contracts. Self-operated PoS are typically prevalent in smaller companies (with 250 or fewer employees) in the workplace segment, as well as at gas stations in the on-the-go segment that are too remote to be fully operated by a self-service retail operator. The detailed overview of business models is as follows: Full Service Model** The self-service retail operator owns or leases and is responsible for the procurement and placement of PoS, stocking and restocking of items, and ongoing maintenance. The self-service retail operator pays a fee (e.g. based on sold cups, or a flat fee) to the B2B contractor. End consumers typically pay for convenience food and beverage at the PoS, with sales directly collected from the self-service retail operator on a consumption basis. Partial Service Model** The self-service retail operator provides the PoS and ingredients and receives a monthly fee, with customers responsible for cleaning and refilling the PoS themselves. Supply/Technical Model** The self-service retail operator sells machines (both replacements and to new customers) and ingredients to customers without any service element and offers technical service contracts for machines. As these business models all require self-service retail operators to make regular visits to customer sites, maintaining dense clusters of customers in conjunction with dynamic route-planning for merchandizers and technicians visiting those sites are key for profitability. Telemetry devices installed in PoS provide self-service retail operators with real-time data from the PoS, which is then used to plan bespoke routes to PoS that require a visit, ensure no stock-outs and reduce time needed for merchandisers as with telemetry they already have pre-kitted sets. We operate across all three types of business models described above with a focus on the full service model, which together with the partial service model accounted for 84% of our revenue for the year ended September 30, 2018, and the supply/technical model accounted for the remaining 16%. Self-service retail services are typically provided to private, public and semi-public customers. Private customers generally operate within private or relatively restricted locations such as offices and factories. Public customers have properties that are generally located in more widely accessible locations such as railway stations, and airports. PoS are also provided to customers in semi-public locations such as universities, schools, health clubs, and hospitals. We focus on three types of PoS: (i) hot beverages (predominantly coffee, hot chocolate, tea) free standing PoS and table top machines; (ii) cold beverages (cans and bottles) in closed front PoS; and (iii) snacks, cold drinks, fresh foods and non-food products in glass front PoS. While all of these products are available through several other distribution channels (e.g. supermarkets, coffee shops), PoS offer a value proposition focused around convenience for both consumers and customers at locations where other distribution channels might not be available. Specifically, we provide consumers with “24/7” access to products at particularly convenient points of sale in private, public and semi-public locations. Furthermore, in the workplace segment we also operate MicroMarkets with an enlarged product portfolio on a much larger area which provide us with an additional route to market which is gaining traction across Europe. Self-service retail operators such as Selecta typically earn revenue from their customers via long-term contracts which provide a high degree of revenue visibility due to stable consumption patterns of consumers. While the term of each contract varies, private contracts are typically for a period of three to five years, and public contracts are typically for a period of five to ten years. Self-service retail operators generate revenue based on their specific business models and the range of services offered. Illustratively, a self-service retail provider operating within a private setting with a full service business model would earn revenues from the sale of products with prices agreed at the outset of the contract and adjusted based on a mechanism such as a price index. 99 ----- Operators generally also generate fixed service/maintenance fees from their public and private customers. Volume-based rebates are typically agreed with larger multi-site customers. PoS in private settings operate either on a free vend or pay vend basis. On a free vend basis, the customer subsidizes the cost for consumers which then do not need to make payments themselves. Alternatively, on a pay vend basis, consumers purchase items using cash or a form of cashless payment system without any subsidies from the customer. Products are sold in public settings on a pay vend basis and providers are typically free to set and adapt product selling prices, but a provider typically pays a fee (rent) to the customer for occupying the customer’s premises.

We operate in a market where future growth is fueled by positive underlying mega trends such as increasing share of out-of-home food and beverage consumption, premiumization, and convenience. We also benefit from overall GDP growth, although lower than our own market growth. _Macroeconomic conditions: Selecta benefits from the supportive macro-economic conditions driving_ consumer spending growth, particularly out-of-home Food & Beverages. Furthermore, the increase in workforce and hours-spend-at-work is driving overall consumption at the workplace. _Premiumization: The premium coffee growth in coffee on-the-go and at the workplace drives pricing above_ inflation. Additionally, the shift towards healthy products supports higher prices in snacks and cold drinks. _Shift toward convenience: As consumers desire convenience, we are poised to benefit from preferences for_ fast and local consumption. With an increasing focus on mobility, consumers prefer convenience formats while spending more time and money on-the-go.

We believe that the key drivers and trends impacting market growth in the Unattended SSR Market include the following: _Increased Workforce and Hours Spent In the Office_ The workplace segment is supported by growth in employment statistics, with all but one of the following countries seeing an increase in total workforce numbers between 2012 and 2017: France, Germany, Italy, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, the Netherlands and the United Kingdom (the “Focus Countries”). Specifically, according to OC&C, total workforce has grown at a CAGR of 1.4% in Sweden, 1.4% in the UK and 1.3% in France, Spain, and Switzerland between 2012 and 2017. Collectively across all Focus Countries, the number of hours spent at the office has grown at a CAGR of 0.9% between 2012 and 2017.

Subsection Title: Total Time Spent in the Office
Subsubsection Text: (in billion hours per week) **% CAGR +0.9%** **12-17 5.4 5.2** 0.2 **1.3%** 0.2 0.20.2 **0.2% 0.2 0.2 **1.0% 0.7 0.6 **1.1% 1.1 **1.6% 1.0 0.8 **0.4% 0.8 1.3 1.4 **0.7% 0.9 0.9 **0.9% _Source: OC&C_ 2012 2017 100 ----- _Time Spent On-the-Go_ Due to overall mobility trends (rise in number of business and leisure commuters), consumers spend more time (and money) on-the-go and prefer formats that offer desired products and quality fast (e.g. no lines, easy payment options). The rise in domestic trips per capita is leading to increased number of encounters with PoS and stores selling convenience products at public locations, increasing the demand for on-the-go convenience products. Across all product categories and countries, surveys indicate that consumers on-the-go value the quick transaction nature and convenient location of self-service retail vis-à-vis other retailing formats. _Increased Consumer Spend on Out-of-Home Food and Beverage_ Out-of-home consumer spending on food and beverage items has been rising across each of the Focus Countries. Between 2012 and 2014, out-of-home consumer spending increased at a CAGR of 1.8%. This growth has intensified between 2014 and 2017 to 4.2%, driven primarily by large increases across the Focus Countries. OC&C estimates that this spending growth will continue between 2018 and 2022. Increases in impulse purchases, in particular from public points of sale have predominantly contributed to this growth. _Available Locations_ Although the number of public locations has remained stable, there has been an increase in the number of locations where operators can place self-service PoS, including offices. This increased availability also increases consumer exposure to self-service retail points of sale, which drives growth in impulse purchases. _Premiumization_ An increase in premium coffee drinking culture is driving on-the-go and workplace segment growth. Furthermore, the premiumization trend (especially in coffee), in combination with a trend toward customized products are driving average prices of premium food and beverages. Thus, increasing prices per vend and rising share of premium coffee PoS underline the premiumization trend and consumers’ willingness to pay for it despite the availability of free alternatives at work. The chart below illustrates the increase in the percentage of PoS serving bean-to-cup coffee in each Focus Country.

The Addressable Market is expected to benefit from a growing demand for healthy 101 ----- food and drinks, with the average expenditures for health and wellness food and beverage in France, Germany, Italy, the Netherlands, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, and the UK, increasing by 4.2%, 3.8%, 3.9%, 2.4%, 3.3%, 1.6%, 1.9%, and 4.9%, respectively, from 2017 to 2022. _Technology_ The introduction of cashless payments, telemetry, and special features is positively impacting the Unattended SSR Market sales. The ongoing trend toward cashless payments is expected to drive further growth in both on-the-go and workplace segments, catering to consumers’ need of “service speed” and convenience. The share of cashless payments has grown across Europe and is expected to continue in the future.

Subsubsection Text: The Addressable Market in the Focus Countries is valued at approximately €42.4 billion (€40.5 billion excluding capsules). Excluding capsules, for which there is limited historical data, the Addressable Market has grown steadily at a CAGR of approximately 2.1% over 2012-2017 (1.4% over 2012-2014 and 2.6% over 20142017), which is driven by strong growth in foodservice, which grew at a CAGR of 4.2% over 2012-2014 and 5.4% over 2014-2017. Despite remaining flat over 2012-2014, the workplace segment grew at a CAGR of 2.7% between 2014-2017. Going forward, we expect the Addressable Market in the Focus Countries to grow at a CAGR of approximately 3.1% over 2017-2022, with both workplace and on-the-go segments growing at a CAGR of 2.2% and 3.3%, respectively, over the same time period, on the back of secular favorable trends.

In addition, other technological advancements such as digital user interface are expected to further boost Unattended SSR Market sales through attractive product presentation. _Regulation_ The industry is also impacted by developments in regional, national and EU-wide regulation, for example with regards to the display of ingredients, technical specifications of machines, ability to operate in certain locations, recycling and waste disposal to name a few. It is our belief that larger operators such as the Group are better positioned to understand, influence and react to such changes than smaller regional operators. 102 -----

Canteens (excl. Lunch)

Subsection Title: Unattended SSR at Workplace Unattended SSR On-the-Go
Subsubsection Text: Foodservice Packaged Food **(0.3%)** **(0.8%)** **1.5%** |Col1|Due to limited data availability we have not included capsules in growth, but data indicates this is grown from 0 to c.12% of the market in 20 years (Nespresso Pro was launched in 1999)| |---|---| |22 %|| **(0.2%)** **2.7% 2.3% 12–14 0.1% % CAGR 14–17 17–22 2.6%** **2.4% 1.9% 2.4%** **3.3% 4.2%** **5.4%** **4.4% 1.4%** **1.6%** **3.1%** _Source: OC&C_ Evolving consumer preferences and positive macroeconomic trends have generally been driving growth in the Addressable Market. New trends and economic conditions in most Focus Countries have contributed to increased consumer spending particularly on out-of-home food and beverages, an overall increased workforce, and increased average working hours. Consumer trends toward premium coffee experiences and premium healthy cold drinks have also contributed to driving average prices for such products above the inflation rate. Moreover, the continuing shift toward convenience in most markets and the overall increase in time spent in transit (e.g. commuting, business trips) have contributed to expanding the Addressable Market. The Unattended SSR Market in the Focus Countries, which is made up of on-the-go self-service retail, workplace self-service retail, and capsules, is valued at approximately €15.3 billion (€13.4 billion excluding capsules). Excluding capsules, for which there is limited historical data, the Unattended SSR Market has grown at a CAGR of 1.6% over the period 2012-2017 (remaining relatively flat during 2012-2014 and growing at a CAGR of 2.6% during 2014-2017). Following a return to growth between 2015 and 2017, largely due to improvements in the European economy, the Unattended SSR Market is expected to grow at a rate of 2-3% per year, with slightly higher growth in the on-the-go segment. The growth in the following years is expected to be driven by an array of favorable trends. The following table illustrates the historical and projected growth for each of the Focus Countries between 2014 and 2022. 103 -----
_Source: OC&C_

We are well positioned to take advantage of continued volume growth driven by an increase of hours spent at work, time spent on-the-go, customer spend out-of-home food and beverage, technology, number of travelers, and regulation. Additionally, as consumers shift toward more premium hot beverages and healthier cold drinks, we will be able to take advantage of price increases that will ultimately drive margin expansion. The Unattended SSR Market is expected to grow at 3.3% per annum for on-the-go and 2.3% per annum for workplace between 2017-22. The Addressable Market is expected to grow at 3.1% per annum through 2022. Overall, the Unattended SSR Market is expected to grow by 2-3% per annum. This represents considerable upside potential just from a market growth perspective.

Subsection Title: Served Unattended Self Service Retail Market Growth 2012-22 (in € billion) Premiumization (2012-14)** **Return to Norms (2015-17)** **Continued Stable Growth (2018+) On-the-go At work
Number one in Europe with Leading Market Positions Across Key Markets
Subsubsection Text: Selecta operates in a very fragmented market environment. In five out of the eight Focus Countries, we claim the number one market position (Switzerland, Sweden, France, UK and Spain). We have a typical 10% to 15% market share in our core markets, while the remaining market is shared among a wide group of other operators. This fragmented market in Europe continues to present real opportunities for us, including through selective acquisitions.

The Unattended SSR Market is highly fragmented, with only 5 to 7 larger operators in each country, in addition to over 200 to 1,000 highly localized operators. Therefore, we typically compete with local small operators, and 4 to 6 larger operators in each country for large scale contracts. The chart below demonstrates the number of self-service retail operators in each of the Focus Countries:
_Source: OC&C_ 105 -----

Subsection Title: Top 5 share concentration by country, 2017 (%)** **Estimated total vending operators by country, 2017 (#)
Subsubsection Text: We offer a wide variety of products, which range from coffee and hot drinks, cold drinks, snacks, to fresh food. We have a diversified portfolio of attractive coffee brands across all price points. These include premium global brands such as Starbucks and Lavazza, local specialties such as Pelican Rouge, and other third party private labels. Through these products, we have the ability to offer a suite of three main service capabilities: full service, partial service, and supply/technical. Selecta’s full service includes a comprehensive package that includes installations of Selecta PoS, regular filling and cleaning, and technical maintenance. Partial service targets smaller office environments, and offers machines, ingredients, and consumables. Clients are responsible for cleaning and refilling. In supply/technical, we provide the machines, ingredients and consumables. We offer technical support services under separate contracts that are negotiated with the client. The machines are sold to the customer in this case.

Subsection Title: Top 5 share concentration by country, 2017 (%)** **Estimated total vending operators by country, 2017 (#)
Subsubsection Text: Although there is no directly comparable competitor, we face competition from other similar traditional self-service retail operators (both on a local / regional and national / international level), including those run by contract caterers and facility management companies, fast-moving consumer goods, capsule, coffee bars, as well as coffee tower companies and providers of alternative formats. Groups of key competitors in the Unattended SSR Market are elaborated on below. 106 ----- _Traditional Self-service Retail Specialists_ Our main competitors are traditional self-service retail operators. The European Unattended SSR Market is largely mature and is characterized by a large number of industry participants. The industry is fragmented with few players of national scale and a long tail of small players per market, indicating the relatively low barriers to entry at a local level but high barriers to scale. Self-service retail operators offer their services across workplace and on-the-go segments. In the workplace segment, they focus on larger businesses (blue and white collar) with high throughput and multiple PoS at one location given the high density required for efficiency in refilling. In the on-the-go segment, self-service retail operators offer convenience products at locations where footfall for laborintensive formats is too low, retail space is insufficient, or opening hours limit other formats. Given the high density required to operate PoS portfolio profitably, the Unattended SSR Market has relatively high barriers to scale. There is a limited set of players comparable to us in terms of brand, scale, product width and multi-regional presence. Regional specialists are competitive locally, but have a limited ability to serve national/international customers (e.g. gas stations, public train stations) or offer a full product range. We believe that the domestic key competitors in the Focus Countries include local players, such as IVS (mainly in Italy), Daltys (only in France) and Maas (only in the Netherlands). _Contract Caterers and Facility Management Providers_ Contract caterers and facility management providers can offer a one-stop service at a cost advantage, with PoS typically being operated by a customer’s own cafeteria staff. However, complex machine operations typically require trained technicians, leading to the credibility of caterers being increasingly questioned, e.g. in terms of refilling fresh food and of costs and expenses. As a result, increasingly more, contract caterers and facility management providers are partnering with self-service retail specialists to provide these services for a fee. Key players include Aramark in Belgium and Germany, Compass in the UK and Elior in Spain. _Vertically Integrated Self-service Retail Providers_ Vertically Integrated self-service retail providers represent a small group of mostly coffee and soft drinks producers, who as an extension to their core drinks production operations also ventured into Unattended SSR Market. However, they did so mostly as a brand extension and as a means of direct access and communication with final consumers. As a result their product offering is usually limited or in some cases strictly restricted to their own product portfolio (e.g. coffee or soft drinks). While they occupy a portion of the market, Vertically Integrated self-service retail providers cannot fully compete as traditional self-service retail specialists, who provide a considerably wider portfolio of brands, product offering and capabilities. Key players include JDE, Dallmayr and Lavazza Professional (former Mars drinks). Coffee towers are also in this group and are operated by coffee shop chains like Costa. Competitive pressures on traditional self-service retail specialists from coffee towers is limited to urban areas. One of the key competitors is Costa Express in the United Kingdom (now part of Coca-Cola, which is a competitor for our coffee offering in the UK, but we are still servicing their machines and distributing their cold beverages in our PoS). _Other Formats_ Other formats typically offer a wider range of food and beverages, including healthy and fresh options. These formats typically require high footfall to be profitable and compensate for high fees. Compared to these formats, self-service retail operators can maintain better proximity to consumers, in particular during short changing times (e.g. train station platforms). Key competitors include Tesco Express, REWE to Go, 7-Eleven, and Relay. 107 -----
