Subsubsection Text: c.20%–40% 31% 27% 43% 45% 21% c.15% 60% c.60%–70% 69% 73% 57% 55% 79% c.85% 40% |Vast majority of companies in all geographies are local vending specialists, often operating in specific areas with a small number of machines|Col2| |---|---| ||| 3,000 1,600–1,900 Top 5 Others _Source: OC&C 1._ _Market sizes used to calculate shares do not include capsules data as this is not available over time 2._ _Switzerland market includes adjustments for Dallmayr and Lyreco_ Given the large number of operators in the Unattended SSR Market, there are opportunities for consolidation, especially for the top five operators in each Focus Country. Between 2015 and 2017, six of the eight Focus Countries saw increased consolidation. In Sweden, for example, consolidation in the top five operators between 2015 and 2017 increased by 5% due to acquisitions of the regional operators by the larger, international operators.

We are the leading route-based unattended self-service coffee and convenience food provider in Europe by revenue with more than 475,000 PoS in 16 countries as of June 30, 2019, covering approximately 95% of European GDP and approximately 78% of the European population. We held the number one or number two market position based on revenue in 2017 in our ten core markets of Belgium, France, Finland, Italy, the Netherlands, Norway, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland and the United Kingdom. We served over ten million consumers per day via more than 3,800 routes as of June 30, 2019. We operate in a highly fragmented market, which provides growth opportunities, both organically and through accretive acquisitions. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2019, we generated a revenue of €1,580.8 million and an Adjusted EBITDA of €267.7 million, and we would have generated an Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) of €1,604.7 million and an Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) of €271.2 million, achieving 3.8% Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) growth compared to the twelve months ended June 30, 2018, and 18.9% Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) margins. The following map illustrates the countries in which we operate, our geographical segments as of June 30, 2019, and our market positions in the Focus Countries (as defined below) for the year ended December 30, 2017. _Source: OC&C. Market data as of 2017. Our market share in Italy consists of the 2017 market share of Argenta, which we acquired in February 2018. Our market share in the UK consists of the 2017 market share of Selecta combined with (i) the 2017 market share of the UK operations of Pelican Rouge, which we acquired in September 2017, and (ii) the 2017 market share of Express Vending, which we acquired in August 2018._ Our diversified product offering includes both coffee and hot drinks, and we have entered into strong partnerships with global premium coffee brands such as Starbucks and Lavazza, which allow us to benefit from consumers’ increasing preference for premium products, especially coffee, and result in higher margins. We also cater to the impulse-based consumer purchases with offerings of snacks, including healthy options, cold drinks and fresh food sold through traditional impulse PoS as well as our recently introduced MicroMarkets concept. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2019, our Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) as a percentage of the types of items we sell amounted to 56% for coffee and hot drinks, 29% for impulse items, and 15% for other. 108 ----- We serve customers and generate revenue in the workplace/private, on-the-go/public and trading business channels further discussed below: (*) Adjusted Revenue (CS & CS) for the twelve months ended June 30, 2019. Our business model covers the full value chain of the coffee and convenience food Unattended SSR Market, from green bean roasting to brewing to the consumer’s cup, and we have developed industry leading coffee know-how, capabilities, and expertise in connection with these processes. We roast and produce both instant and full bean coffee, which we use in our own PoS, our customers’ PoS and also sell to third parties, and as such, our roaster in Dordrecht, the Netherlands, is an important driver of our coffee expertise. We have created a strong portfolio of high-quality coffee brands, such as our in-house developed Pelican Rouge brand and its craftsmanship image that caters for growing number of consumers increasingly looking for this attribute. Our Pelican Rouge brand complements our premium coffee offering in partnership with Lavazza and Starbucks. We leverage our technology capabilities and data collection from PoS to provide relevant products, gauge consumer preferences and maximize revenue opportunities, which improve consumer experience and customer satisfaction. We also provide cleaning, maintenance, and technical support services which can be customized based on individual customer needs and preferences, even when we do not enter into a full self-service retail service arrangement with the customer. In addition to our unattended self-service and coffee roasting operations, we also sell coffee and machines, including to hotels, restaurants and cafés, and machine parts and products independent of self-service retail service arrangements. Due to the predictable nature of our business and the length of our customer contracts, we believe we are able to achieve high revenue visibility. We benefit from diversified revenue streams secured by multi-year contracts derived from a large and loyal customer base across private and public sector in 2018 and a 100% retention rate with our top ten customers over that period. As of June 30, 2019, we estimate that our average private customer contract term is three to five years, and our average public customer contract term is five to ten years. Moreover, the maintenance and cleaning services we offer as part of our self-service retail services provide us with an additional source of high margin revenues. Innovation and technology are also key drivers of our success, and we benefit from our track record of innovation leadership both in terms of technology upgrades such as cashless payment, touchscreen user interfaces and telemetry, as well as in terms of unattended self-service retail concepts, such as MicroMarkets, to drive daily revenue per PoS and open new routes-to-market. Since our founding in Switzerland in 1957, we have grown organically as well as through acquisitions. On September 7, 2017, we completed the acquisition of the Pelican Rouge Group, which increased our presence in nine of the 15 markets in which we operated at that time, making us the market leader by revenue in France, Spain, the United Kingdom, and Belgium. In addition, on February 2, 2018, we completed the acquisition of the 109 ----- Argenta Group, a leading unattended self-service retail operator in Italy, which became our 16[th] market. On August 17, 2018, we acquired Express Vending, a leading UK supplier of premium unattended self-service retail services, bolstering our position as the leading European provider of route-based unattended self-service coffee and impulse and convenience food offerings, including MicroMarkets, and further consolidated our leading position in the United Kingdom. Express Vending is at the forefront of MicroMarket design and deployment in the UK. Express Vending’s Express HUB brand stores, with open plan refreshment areas, an extensive product range and self-scan kiosks. As a result of these acquisitions, our innovation and technology leadership, and through upgrades of our business, operating systems and corporate culture, we have achieved a leading position in Europe as a routebased unattended self-service retail provider with strong know-how and capabilities in providing coffee and impulse offerings across a range of workplace/private, on-the-go/public and trading business channels. We had average market shares ranging between 10% and 15% in our core markets for the year ended December 30, 2017, compared to approximately 6% of the European market over the same period in 2016, and we served over ten million consumers for the twelve months ended June 30, 2019, compared to approximately 6 million for the year ended September 30, 2016. We see significant opportunities for further organic growth and accretive acquisition-led growth in our highly fragmented markets.

We offer consumers a wide variety of on-the-go food products for everyday consumption and impulse purchases, with a strong focus on coffee, at all hours of the day and every day of the year thanks to our unattended, 24/7, fully automated, convenience retail concept. Our concept targets captive environments and is economically viable even in low footfall locations due to our minimal operational costs compared with traditional retail concepts. Our ability to sell products in convenient retail locations and our high level of customer service has led to an average overall customer retention based on revenue of approximately 95.9% for the twelve months ended June 30, 2019, and approximately 92.5% and 94.4% for each of the years ended September 30, 2017 and 2018, respectively. We believe that the quality of our service levels and our customer relationship management contribute to customer loyalty, leading to an average relationship of approximately 15 years with our 10 largest customers. In addition, contract renewals with our existing long-term customers are typically more profitable than entering into a contract with a new customer, due to savings on equipment and other capital expenditures and customer acquisition costs. Our costs associated with new customers are followed by predictable revenue streams and we usually recoup these costs within two years. We have a scalable routebased business model that we are able to apply across the 16 countries in which we operate with the same key success factors, to drive growth in customers, daily revenue per PoS and profitability. For example, following the Argenta Acquisition in 2018, we have replicated Argenta’s MicroMarkets operating model in other countries such as Switzerland and the Netherlands. Our focus on out-of-home impulse consumption limits our exposure to competition from online retailers and offerings.

Subsubsection Title: Well Positioned to Take Advantage of Premium Coffee and Out-of-Home Consumption Growth
Subsubsection Text: We operate in our Addressable Market, estimated at €42 billion in 2017, in our Focus Countries. Within the Addressable Market, we focus on the Unattended SSR Market which has a market size of approximately €16 billion in our 16 countries of operations, of which approximately €15 billion arises in the Focus Countries. Our Addressable Market has grown at a CAGR of 2.1% between 2012 and 2017, reaching a total value of approximately €40.5 billion in the Focus Countries and is expected to grow at a CAGR of 3.1% reaching €47.1 billion by 2022. This trend has been driven by a positive macro-economic backdrop with an increase in GDP and stable employment levels, which have led to increased spending in the workplace channel. In addition, we believe that an increasing preference for drinking premium coffee and out-of-home consumption, increased mobility, and the desire for easy availability of healthy and quality products is driving consumers towards our pan-European on-the-go self-service retail offerings. For example, sales of coffee within the Addressable Market has grown at a CAGR of 2.8% between 2012 to 2017, reaching €16.0 billion, and is expected to grow at a CAGR of 3.9%, reaching €19.4 billion by 2022. Moreover, the growing trend toward premium brands has created a shift in consumer emphasis on high quality product offerings, including organic and name-brand coffee, a trend which we are addressing with our 110 ----- Starbucks, and Lavazza brand partnerships. For example, we are able to offer consumers a premium hot drinks experience, both in the workplace and on-the-go through our long-standing partnership with Starbucks. As of June 30, 2019, we have installed approximately 1,964 Starbucks concepts across Europe, and the price of a coffee sold in our Starbucks on-the-go concept is between 20% to 90% higher than a coffee sold in traditional self-service PoS, and such trends for premium brands support our profitability. Similarly, through our partnership with Lavazza we offer our customers and consumers additional options for a premium coffee experience. As of June 30, 2019, we had over 15,637 PoS selling Lavazza coffee and we estimate that approximately 40,000 PoS will serve Lavazza coffee in the long-term.

Subsubsection Title: Leading Unattended Self-Service Coffee and Convenience Food Provider in the European Unattended SSR Market with Growth above Market
Subsubsection Text: We are the leading route-based unattended self-service coffee and convenience food provider in the Unattended SSR Market, and had an estimated 10% market share by revenue in the Focus Countries for the year ended December 30, 2017, compared to 6% over the same period in 2016. We believe that our adjusted revenue (on a constant scope and constant currency basis) for the year ended September 30, 2018, was approximately 3.5 times that of the second largest market player. As of June 30, 2019, we had operations in 16 European countries, which covered approximately 95% of European GDP and contain approximately 78% of the European population. In 2016, we served over six million consumers per day, which we have nearly doubled to more than ten million consumers served per day. We held the number one or number two market position based on revenue in 2017 in our ten core markets, and we estimate that this market data is still accurate as of the date of this Offering Memorandum. Our sales in these markets represented 90.7% of our revenue for the twelve months ended June 30, 2019. As of June 30, 2019, we operated a network of more than 475,000 active coffee and convenience food and beverage self-service PoS, approximately 2.5 times the number of PoS of the second largest market player. With regards to our suppliers, we believe we are the largest machine buyer in the highly fragmented Unattended SSR Market, making us the customer of choice for our suppliers, which in turn provides us with competitively priced procurement arrangements on, amongst other, a wide selection of market leading machines. The Unattended SSR Market is characterized by fragmentation and intense competition on a local level. We are one of the very few operators on a pan-European level, which increases the appeal of our brands and offerings with consumers and of our services and concepts with customers, as compared with our smaller competitors. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2019, our Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) in each of our three geographic segments was split relatively evenly with Central accounting for 37%, North accounting for 26%, and South, UK & Ireland accounting for 37%. This is in contrast to the second largest market player, over three quarters of whose revenue in its last financial year was derived from Italy alone. In addition, the breadth of our product portfolio enables us to better address consumers’ preferences across geographic segments, including evolving market trends, and to provide a one-stop shop offering for our customers. Additionally, our established brands and unique concepts differentiate us from our competitors and enable us to secure attractive and comprehensive contracts with a variety of suppliers and premium brands, which help us maintain our high market share.

Subsubsection Title: Using Innovation and Technology to Drive Growth and Improve Margins
Subsubsection Text: We use innovation and new technologies to drive our growth and improve margins, and we have a track record of innovation leadership through continuous rollouts of upgrades to our PoS across all geographies. Innovation and technology improve the consumer experience, enhance operational excellence and allow us to further expand our route-based business model. Cashless payment systems and digital touchscreen user interfaces that we are rolling out across our PoS park enhance the consumer experience by providing additional accessibility and simplicity of use, thereby driving number of sales and average transaction size compared to cash transactions. As of June 30, 2019, daily revenue per PoS equipped with cashless technology are on average 10% to 20% higher than PoS that only accept cash, and the average transaction value of products sold from cashless PoS is between 5% to 10% higher, making cashless payment options an important driver in increasing sales from existing PoS. As of June 30, 2019, 95% of our public PoS deployed cashless technology. Telemetry in our PoS allows us to better adjust our pricing and product offerings to drive sales and to more efficiently monitor inventory levels and determine maintenance requirements, which increases our route efficiency and operational excellence, and thereby improves service quality and customer retention. As of June 30, 2019, we had telemetry devices installed in approximately 95% of our public PoS. In addition to technological innovation, we also continue to innovate and introduce new unattended self-service retail concepts, such as MicroMarkets, to adapt to market and consumer trends, increase sales and improve profitability, while reducing capital expenditures. 111 -----

Subsubsection Title: Route-Based Business Model with High Density on the Last Mile
Subsubsection Text: Our route-based business model combined with our size represents a distinct competitive advantage, particularly on the last mile of service, which allows us to service and supply PoS at an optimized cost level, thereby improving our profitability compared to other competitors. In addition, we continuously optimize the density of our PoS to make routes more efficient, thereby reducing driving time and increasing our ability to service more PoS per hour and more PoS per FTE. We are, therefore, able to offer more competitive pricing at the same profitability point or the same levels of service at a lower price, as compared to less profitable smaller regional players, thereby creating genuine barriers to match our scale. We also use data from our PoS equipped with telemetry and our dedicated team of approximately 150 planners (as of June 30, 2019) to continuously optimize our over 3,800 dense and cost-effective routes. As of June 30, 2019, our 4,900 route merchandizers and 1,400 route technicians were able to service their routes using a fleet of over 5,000 vehicles. The map below illustrates the location of each of our PoS, and shows the density of our route-based networks.

Subsubsection Title: Scale Driven Business Model Creating Attractive Economics and Enhancing Established Market Presence
Subsubsection Text: We have developed a business model with a cost advantage through economies of scale and high density, and we believe it will be difficult for potential competitors to replicate the scale, breadth, and efficiency of our organization. Our scale also enables us to deliver superior customer service by leveraging our knowledge of the industry to provide customers and consumers with a comprehensive range of products and innovative service offerings. These attributes lead to an estimated 5% to 15% EBITDA margin (as defined by and according to OC&C) advantage over smaller competitors. We deploy capital expenditures in order to retain and acquire new customers and do so by acquiring new PoS and refurbishing our existing PoS in order to enhance returns on investment. Capital expenditure for new PoS and refurbishment of existing PoS of the Group typically achieves a ROI ranging from 100% to 250%, depending on the country, with the highest returns in the Netherlands, the UK and Switzerland. We have consistently achieved efficiencies stemming from PoS park rationalization (which includes margin management, relocating PoS to more profitable locations, and decreasing the types of PoS in use) and refurbishment. In addition to the operational advantages explained above we also believe that given our scale we retain a cost advantage over our competitors in terms of pricing from machine suppliers and that our in-house refurbishment and maintenance capabilities also provide us a cost advantage.

Subsubsection Title: Attractive Financial Profile with Organic Growth, Profitability and Cash Conversion Momentum
Subsubsection Text: Our business has delivered consistent financial results with resilient Adjusted EBITDA margins and stable cash flow generation, with a non-IFRS cash conversion (calculated as Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC) minus Adjusted Net Capital Expenditures (CS & CC), divided by Adjusted EBITDA (CS & CC)) of 46.7%, 45.9%, and 52.0% for the years ended September 30, 2016, 2017, and 2018, respectively, and 49.1% for the twelve months ended June 30, 2019. Adjusted EBITDA minus net capital expenditures, divided by Adjusted EBITDA, amounted to 38.2%, 42.5% and 50.8% for the years ended September 30, 2016, 2017 and 2018, respectively, and 112 ----- 49.0% for the twelve months ended June 30, 2019. Following the Pelican Rouge Acquisition, the Argenta Acquisition, and the Express Vending Acquisition, we have also benefited from significant cost synergies including, among others, procurement savings, footprint optimization, headquarters integration, and price harmonization and streamlining. As we continue to realize synergies, our efficiency improves and cash conversion continues on a positive trend. Our strong market positions in key markets, coupled with our ongoing efforts to optimize PoS density and operational efficiencies, increased technology penetration, as well as data analytics across all markets contribute to further enhancing our financial profile and organic growth. Excluding France and the UK, we achieved revenue growth of 4.3% for the year ended September 30, 2018, compared to the year ended September 30, 2017, and 5.2% for the twelve months ended June 30, 2019, compared to the twelve months ended June 30, 2018, while achieving organic revenue growth at constant scope and constant currency (as further described under “Unaudited Non-GAAP Aggregated Financial Information”) of 3.4% and 2.7% during the same respective periods. Additionally, through our continued efforts to install new and upgrade existing PoS as well as optimize our product offering, we have seen a growth of 1.4% in our daily revenue per PoS in the twelve months ended June 30, 2019 compared to the same period in 2018.

Subsubsection Title: Experienced Executive Management Team with Proven Execution Track Record
Subsubsection Text: We have a long and successful track record of attracting and retaining top talent and have continued to invest in a high quality management team in order to most effectively manage our existing operations and execute our strategies. Our senior management team is led by our CEO, David Flochel, Chairman, David Hamill, CFO, Gabriel Pirona, and COO, Pascal Uffer, who have more than 80 years of combined experience and leadership track record with international companies. The senior management team has a strong focus on functional expertise and is complemented by local management teams with regional focus. Over the past three years, the team has successfully led the roll-out of our innovative Starbucks on-the-go concepts, the implementation of our profitable partnership with Lavazza, as well as our MicroMarkets concept, and have successfully progressed the roll-out of new technologies for our PoS across our geographic markets and the integration of the Pelican Rouge and Gruppo Argenta acquisitions. We believe that the collective industry knowledge and leadership of our senior management team will enable them to continue to grow our business and execute our strategies.
We believe that we benefit from the key competitive strengths listed below.

We intend to continue to nurture our strong reputation with our customers and consumers and to deliver consistently superior financial results, in line with our ultimate goal of achieving a culture of excellence. This excellence stems from a driven and successful team combined with a clear, strategic, and consistent framework, according to which we take decisions and run our business. We have identified the following key pillars driving our strategy, as further described below.

The first line for growing our business and improving our margins is excellence in sales, as it is through sales that we increase our pipeline of potential new contracts, increase our new contract gains and maintain our high level of customer retention. Sales excellence is the key driver of our organic growth, and over the last two years we committed a substantial portion of our resources to improving our salesforce effectiveness and further strengthening our relationship with our customers. We focus on performance-led management and increased activity dedicated to new business sales teams and account managers. As part of this initiative, we are engaging in training, coaching on the job and concept selling to enhance the capabilities of our sales force and to lead the execution of our strategies. The tables below show our new contract pipeline, increase in new gains and customer retention since 2017:

Subsubsection Title: Further Developing Pricing and Category Management
Subsubsection Text: We believe that there is a significant opportunity to increase daily revenue per PoS by improving pricing and category management. We have initiated an analytical approach to support decision making and assess the impact of pricing and category management across our footprint. With telemetry now equipped on most of our public PoS, it allows us to analyze sales data and unlock pricing capabilities in ways previously unavailable to us. We believe this gives us an opportunity to continuously optimize performance, with location specific product assortment and pricing initiatives, allowing us to better manage margins on underperforming accounts, upsell our services to B2B customers, and reduce leakage to competing local offerings. We expect pricing and category management efforts to have a more than €10.0 million impact on revenue for our 2019 fiscal year.

Our route-based business model benefits from the significant increases in productivity resulting from our dense network of PoS and depots, and we are continuously optimizing route density through professional route planning. We thereby leverage our focus on technology and innovation to further improve our operational excellence. For example, the installation of telemetry capabilities in our PoS allows for dynamic route planning and increased efficiency of our refillers by reducing preparation time and enabling the refiller to visit more PoS. Density optimization is also a key consideration in our bolt-on acquisition program, and one of the key drivers of synergy achievement. Our operational excellence is also driven by our success in acquiring and integrating companies, such as Pelican Rouge, Argenta and Express Vending. Led by an integration office reporting to the Board of Directors of the Group, we have identified approximately €75 million in annualized procurement, SG&A and operational synergies that are at being implemented and that we expect to be fully realized by the end of 2020, resulting in a strong margin uplift. In terms of procurement, we expect to achieve up to €30 million of annualized synergies from equipment, ingredients, bought-in goods, disposables, packaging and spares and the in-sourcing of coffee production. SG&A synergies in an amount of up to €13 million include the consolidation of country and group headquarters and the optimization of overhead and corporate costs. We expect to achieve up to €33 million of operational synergies from the transfer of best practices within our group and from an increase in density as a result of depot, merchandizer and technician network optimization and increase in utilization of telemetry capabilities, which drives route efficiency for our refillers.

Subsubsection Title: Continued Roll Out and Focus on Our Technology and Innovation Capabilities
Subsubsection Text: We deem technology and innovation to be a competitive differentiator for our current operations and business going forward. We continue to commit resources and make the necessary investments to be at the forefront of technology and innovation in our industry. Currently, we are managing three footprint-wide key enablers that contribute to an improvement in daily revenue per PoS and operational efficiency. Firstly, we are expanding and upgrading our current PoS base with telemetry technology, a remote PoS monitoring allowing for optimization of cost-to-serve and product availability while leading the transformation toward an end-to-end operating model. Approximately 29% of our eligible PoS park has already been upgraded as of June 30, 2019, while we aim to roll-out telemetry to all eligible PoS across the footprint. Secondly, we are also upgrading our PoS to support cashless technology to enhance check-out experience at the point of sale by providing access to non-cash payment methods, i.e. credit cards and proprietary apps. Approximately 20% of our eligible PoS park has already been upgraded as of June 30, 2019. Thirdly, our MicroMarket concept allows us to introduce an innovative, unique, and attractive format bringing together technology, brands, and operational capabilities while combining the classic vending model (convenience) with the cafeteria model (premium and healthy). While the concept is already established in the UK, Italy, Switzerland and, recently, the Netherlands, we plan to roll-out the format across our other markets to further expand our current footprint of 104 MicroMarkets as of June 30, 2019. For example, we have launched our MicroMarket concept in Spain, where we have already entered into agreements to install MicroMarkets, and in Germany, where we have started discussions with potential customers.

Subsubsection Title: Pursuing Growth Through a Disciplined Capital Expenditure Program
Subsubsection Text: We intend to continue to pursue growth through a disciplined capital expenditure program that provides an attractive return on investment period, while also optimizing the capital intensity of our operations. We have a structured and consistent governance with respect to capital expenditures across our group, with pre-investments business cases and post-investment appraisals and tracking of outcomes. At the same time, we are working to 114 ----- optimize the capital intensity of our operations by refurbishing existing PoS to increase their life and maximizing our refurbishment capabilities and re-siting underperforming PoS. We also intend to continue exploring off-balance sheet funding options, such as our alternative arrangements with Lavazza and other leasing companies, to finance PoS investments for our customers, thereby reducing our initial investment cost for new client contracts. Innovative route-based solutions such as MicroMarkets also have lower capital expenditure requirements than classic impulse purchase offerings, while generating two to three times the revenue of a classic self-service retail site, with each MicroMarket generating an approximate turnover of €50,000 annually. Through these and other initiatives, we intend to reduce our PoS related cash capital expenditures to under €100.0 million per year.

Subsubsection Title: Engaging in Bolt-On Acquisition Opportunities in Our Fragmented Industry
Subsubsection Text: Our reference markets present a fragmented structure with significant bolt-on M&A opportunities, which would allow us to further strengthen our position as the leading unattended self-service coffee and convenience food provider in Europe. Given our scale and market knowledge, we continue to see ourselves as a natural market consolidator. We intend to continue to selectively undertake accretive bolt-on acquisition opportunities to continue our growth, improve our density and improve our technical as well as service capabilities. The Unattended SSR Market is characterized by a large number of operators, which on average tend to be very small in terms of revenue. The following table shows the competitor fragmentation in certain of our key markets:

Subsection Title: Number of** **Average Size of Vending Operators** **Tail [(1)]
Subsubsection Text: **~100–150** **5.7 ~200–250** **0.7 ~1000–1200** **1.7 600–700** **2.2 ~3,000** **0.4 ~100-200** **3.5 1,600–1,900** **0.6 1,000–1,500** **2.1** (1) Average size of tail refers to the average size of our competitors. This fragmentation, and our position as the leader in the Unattended SSR Market, provide us with a large number of bolt-on acquisition opportunities. We have completed five bolt-on acquisitions over the past two years. Each acquisition we make is underpinned by a clear strategy, whether it be to increase density in existing regions, develop market shares, expand our portfolio of offerings, improve technical capabilities in specialized services or some combination of the foregoing. We aim to purchase companies at mid-single-digit EV/EBITDA multiples, and to extract at least a turn of synergies from those acquisitions. Underpinning our success in bolt-on acquisitions is a disciplined execution and integration program that has been proven through our track record of identifying, purchasing at attractive multiples and successfully integrating these bolt-on acquisition opportunities.

Subsection Title: Number of** **Average Size of Vending Operators** **Tail [(1)]
Subsubsection Text: Our people underlie our success, and we believe that our employees are an integral part in successfully executing our strategies. To that end, we are undertaking initiatives related to performance management, sales and operational capabilities, employee engagement and employer branding to ensure we maximize the potential of our talent across our organization. Included among these initiatives are talent reviews of all teams to provide improved management of the talent pools within each of our markets. We have developed a sales and operations academy in order to train and develop our team with the right programs to drive customer satisfaction and efficiencies. We have also worked to improve our employee on-boarding and performance management for our field force, with a focus on developing first-line manager capabilities. In terms of employee engagement, we have created a baseline employee survey in partnership with GALLUP, and plan to implement a tailored action 115 ----- plan based on the survey results for each team. We are also focused on improving our internal communication strategy, with improvement of our intranet, implementation of a new ethics program and the publishing of our first CSR report. We believe that continued implementation of these initiatives, and a focus on the continued development of our people, will support the execution of our strategies.

Since our founding in Switzerland in 1957, we have grown both organically as well as through acquisitions. Following our first acquisition in Switzerland in 1959, we expanded into Germany in 1986, Sweden and France in 1990, Austria, Slovakia and the Baltic countries in 1995, Belgium in 1997, Spain in 1998, the United Kingdom and Ireland in 2001 and the Netherlands in 2004. In 1985, we were acquired by the Valora group, and, in 1997, we listed on the SIX before de-listing in 2001. In 2001, we were acquired by the Compass group before becoming part of Allianz Capital Partners through its acquisition of our business in 2007. We were acquired by KKR in 2015. In September 2017, we acquired the Pelican Rouge Group, previously known as Autobar Group Ltd, a company incorporated in London in 1925, which engages in roasting and blending, packaging, and self-service retail of coffee in the United Kingdom and internationally. In 2014, Autobar Group changed its name to Pelican Rouge and relocated to Dordrecht, the Netherlands. The coffee brand Pelican Rouge (Roode Pelikaan) was originally founded in 1863 in Antwerp. In February 2018, we acquired the Argenta Group. Since its founding in Carpi, Modena, Italy in 1968, the Argenta Group has grown organically as well as through acquisitions to become the second largest food and beverage self-service retail operator in the Italian market. In 2016, the Argenta Group expanded into southern Italy through the acquisition of Somed, and into the food retail business under the Foodie’s brand and through agreements with 365 Retail Market with its MicroMarket concept. In August 2018, we acquired Express Vending, a leading UK supplier of premium self-service retail services with a focus on London and its neighboring counties. Express Vending’s offering of products and services includes table top coffee machines and MicroMarkets. Express Vending was established in 1992 and is headquartered in Hemel Hempstead, Hertfordshire, Great Britain. We also made three smaller acquisitions in Italy in 2018.

We are the leading route-based unattended self-service coffee and convenience food provider Europe by revenue. We cover more than 3,800 routes reaching over ten million consumers with more than 475,000 PoS in 16 countries. As of June 30, 2019, our logistics set up was supported by approximately 150 planners, 4,900 route merchandizers, 1,400 route technicians and a fleet of over 5,000 vehicles. We pro-actively plan routes for our merchandizers based on PoS consumption, capacity and other specific requirements, such as hygiene or customer commitments. Our planning teams organize these visits by static route-planning with routes planned four to eight weeks in advance based on historic consumption and internal tools, and by dynamic route-planning with daily plans generated based on real-time data and forecasts collected from PoS through telemetry. We plan routes for our technicians when one of our PoS experience a breakdown and, to a lesser extent, pro-actively to prevent any issues. Our operations span across the value chain of the self-service coffee and convenience food markets. We purchase machines for our customers, or procure third party financing for our customers to purchase machines, install them at their premises and manage the sourcing and stocking of the food and beverages on behalf of our customers. We provide quality coffee brands and convenient food and beverage concepts, including premium coffee concepts through our Starbucks and Lavazza partnerships. We also offer cleaning, maintenance and technical support services, which can be customized to individual customers’ preferences. In addition to our selfservice retail operations, we sell self-service retail machines, machine parts and products independently of service arrangements. We operate our PoS network under the “Selecta” brand across all our markets, except in Italy where we use the “Argenta” brand and in Finland where we use the “Pelican Rouge” brand. We believe our brands enjoy strong brand recognition in many of the markets in which we operate and stand for quality and innovation. 116 -----

Our self-service business serves consumers in the following business channels: - The workplace channel, which is comprised of (i) private self-service retail, consisting of PoS placed and serviced in various private locations, such as large corporate customers, in various businesses and industries and including in corporate offices, manufacturing and logistics sites and (ii) OCS, which is comprised of table-top coffee machines rented out to corporate customers for office use along with the provision of technical services and coffee and related supplies for the PoS. OCS is targeted primarily at small and medium-sized enterprises. - The on-the-go channel, which is comprised of PoS placed and serviced in semi-public areas, or public areas following a successful bidding process with relevant government authorities to place our PoS in a given location. The types of public locations include train stations, airports and gas stations. The types of semi-public locations include hospitals, universities and entertainment venues. The bidding process by which we obtain our public contracts is long and contentious, and subject to many local laws and ordinances. These contracts, however, are very lucrative to our business as these public spaces experience high traffic during all hours in the day, including late nights when most other food and beverage stores are closed for business. For example, we were able to grow our revenues in Germany as a result of a public contract with Deutsche Bahn to place PoS throughout rail stations in the West and South of Germany. Although the number of Selecta PoS used for public areas only represents 4% of our PoS as of June 30, 2019, it accounts for 18% of our revenue for the twelve months ended June 30, 2019. - The trading channel, which is comprised of sales of machines and products, including coffee roasted in our roasting facility, as well as the provision of technical and hygienic support to customers.

As of June 30, 2019, we had combined operations in 16 countries across Europe. For operational, management and financial reporting purposes, we divide our operations into the following three geographic segments: - _South, UK & Ireland includes operating entities in Ireland, Italy, Spain and the UK; - _Central includes operating entities in Austria, France, Germany, Liechtenstein, and Switzerland; and - _North includes operating entities in Belgium, Denmark, Finland, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Norway, and Sweden. As of October 1, 2017, one operating in Finland was classified as held for sale and excluded from this segment; it was subsequently sold in March 2018.

Subsubsection Title: Hot Drinks Sold Through Our PoS
Subsubsection Text: For the twelve months ended June 30, 2019, 56% of our revenue was generated by our variety of table top and free-standing hot drink self-service PoS, with instant, roasted whole bean and ground coffee options, professional espresso machines, and roasted coffee beans. These machines serve a wide variety of coffee and coffee specialty drinks as well as freshly brewed tea, hot chocolate and soups. In 2009, we introduced our own brand coffee blends under the Miofino brand to complement our range of hot drink self-service PoS. Following the Pelican Rouge Acquisition, we have increased our range of own brand coffee offerings under the name Pelican Rouge. Both Pelican Rouge and Miofino coffee offerings include mild, medium, and bold blends as well as decaffeinated and organic and fair trade-certified blends, including instant, roasted whole bean and ground coffee options. Specific Pelican Rouge and Miofino coffee blend availability varies according to country. Table top machines are primarily targeted at the private self-service retail segment, such as offices, but are also frequently located in restaurants and cafés and in certain specific public locations such as gas stations. Free 117 ----- standing PoS, in contrast, are primarily suited for public locations in high-traffic areas such as airports and train and subway stations. We offer table top and free-standing models on either free vend basis, where the customer covers the cost of the products and users do not need to pay at the PoS, or pay vend basis, where consumers purchase items using coins or a form of cashless payment systems. See “—Payment Options.” Our wide selection of hot drink self-service PoS allows customers to select the right machine for their needs based on additional factors, such as cup capacity and the number of available drink selections. For example, our Ferrara coffee selfservice machine has capacity for 100 cups per day, can vend a variety of coffee specialties, in addition to freshly brewed tea and hot chocolate. It also features an integrated color touch screen that allows users to select and customize their drinks by adding sugar or increasing or decreasing the strength of drinks to taste, and nutritional and allergy information is available via the touch screen to help consumers make informed choices. In addition, we provide a range of premium hot drink self-service PoS through the following partnerships: - _Starbucks: We introduced Starbucks on-the-go PoS for public spaces in 2013. These PoS feature premium coffee self-service machines manufactured by Franke that include space for two types of coffee beans, offer a wide variety of coffee specialty drinks and allow users to choose from three drink sizes depending on the beverage selection. Additionally, flexible payment options are available and each PoS can be configured with a payment module. On January 12, 2015, we entered into a partnership with Starbucks governed by an exclusive contract and, in August 2018, we signed a new agreement with Starbucks. This agreement is valid until July 2021 and provides us with the license to develop and operate Starbucks premium self-serve solutions, including Starbucks on-the-go for public and semi-public channels and Starbucks workplace for private channels, in 13 markets in Europe. Under this agreement, we market, sell and operate the concepts while Starbucks provides all the ingredients, taking into account a profit element. We earn the revenue and the profit through the sale of the products and applicable maintenance and service charges. For the year ended September 30, 2018, sales from Starbucks concepts accounted for €61.6 million of our revenue, which was a 7.9% increase compared to the same period in 2017. We installed 168 additional Starbucks concepts in the twelve months ended June 30, 2019, and, as of June 30, 2019, we had over 1,964 Starbucks concepts in 11 countries, increasing from 1,151, 1,490 and 1,796 PoS as of September 30, 2016, 2017, and 2018, respectively. - _Lavazza: We introduced our range of Lavazza self-service PoS in 2017 for private and public customers. Lavazza PoS can be ordered for an array of spaces from small or large offices to gas stations and major public transportation hubs. Our partnership with Lavazza is governed by a framework contract that we entered into on December 22, 2016, with an indefinite term set to expire 60 days from the expiry of the last lease agreement under such framework agreement. Under this framework agreement, we derive our revenue from (i) sales of products used in connection with leased self-service PoS owned by Lavazza and (ii) sales of Lavazza coffee from our PoS. We installed 3,654 new Lavazza PoS selling Lavazza coffee in the twelve months ended June 30, 2019, and, as of June 30, 2019, we operated over 15,637 PoS selling Lavazza coffee across eight countries. In the long-term, we plan on installing approximately 40,000 PoS throughout our markets. Our range of Lavazza PoS can be combined with our full ranges of services and we have launched our telesales of Lavazza coffee capsules for table-top machines in eight countries. Lavazza telesales are conducted from our call centers, and generally target offices where table-top machines that use Lavazza coffee capsules may be operated. See “—Machines, Machine Parts and Products.” We also enter into alternative lease arrangements with Lavazza whereby Lavazza directly buys the machine, and we receive the revenue generated by such PoS less a commission withheld by Lavazza. For the year ended September 30, 2018, sales from Lavazza PoS accounted for €61.1 million of our revenue, which was a 200% increase compared to the same period in 2017.

Subsubsection Title: Roasted Coffee Produced by Our Roasting Facility
Subsubsection Text: We operate a roasting facility in Dordrecht, the Netherlands, from which we supply the Group and third parties, such as wholesale businesses, other self-service retailers, and industrial customers in over 65 countries, with coffee. While the primary focus of the facility is producing roasted whole bean and ground coffee, which accounted for 44% of our Adjusted Revenue (CS & CC) for the year ended September 30, 2018, it also mixes instant coffee products, in each case under the Pelican Rouge brand, which accounted for 56% of our Adjusted 118 ----- Revenue (CS & CC) over the same period. Within the capsule, roasted whole bean, ground and instant coffee categories, customers may choose among a wide selection of arabica or robusta, and caffeinated or decaf roasts of varying strengths, some of which are certified organic. The typical customers for these products include retail and food self-service chains, hotels, restaurants, and cafés. Revenue generated from the roasting facility is accounted for within our trade segment.

Subsubsection Title: Snacks, Cold Drinks and Non-Food Items Sold Through Our PoS
Subsubsection Text: We offer a range of free-standing PoS for snacks, cold drinks, or a combination of the two. Each PoS can be configured as a free vend or pay vend PoS, with pay vend PoS being accompanied by a choice of various cashless payment systems. Our snack, cold drinks and combination PoS are primarily differentiated by their product capacity. For example, each of our Santa Fe touch and Santa Fe XL machine models are equipped to vend snacks, confectionary items, cans, bottles and tetra packs, and their flexible layouts allow for easy reconfiguration to accommodate changes in product offering or layout, i.e. snacks and cold beverage combination in the warm months and snacks and hot beverage combination in the colder months. Through the electronic shelf labels and the touchscreen of the Santa Fe Touch, we can ensure accurate and up-to-date price, allergy, and nutrition information is provided to the consumers. We generally offer customers a standard assortment of brand name and top sellers snacks and beverages, but the product mix can also be tailored to the customer’s needs to reflect, for example, particular regional tastes in snack foods or drinks as well as locally-sourced items. Our newest glass-fronted cold drinks machines, such as the St. Tropez, include a modern cooling system which concentrates the air flow at the front of the shelves in order to provide the next drinks to be dispensed at the optimum temperature, and ensures a shake-free delivery at an ergonomic height. They also feature an integrated robotic lift, which delivers the selected drink to the carousel within ten seconds, and use energy-saving LED lights. These machines can be programmed to automatically switch off the illumination or reduce the chiller outside of working hours. In addition, our PoS typically feature separators, which can be easily removed for cleaning and separate access to payment systems.

Our water dispensers are primarily suited for offices and other private settings. Our water dispensers use tap water with integrated filtration systems to control water quality, allow the water temperature to be adjusted and, depending on the type of dispenser, offer multiple water dispensing options—unchilled, medium chilled or chilled still water and medium or highly carbonated soda water. Additionally, flavor concentrates can be installed inside the water dispenser unit to provide flavored water.

HoReCa are products offered historically by Pelican Rouge and targeted at hospitality professionals, such as food self-service chains, hotels and restaurants. HoReCa products are fully automatic, table top dispensers suitable for high use environments that provide a wide variety of hot drinks, such as espressos, cappuccinos, hot chocolates and teas. These products have a distinctive and refined aesthetic appeal, which is a key factor in this segment. Our line of HoReCa products and services are differentiated on cup capacity and efficiency, multibeverage optionality and flexibility, allowing our customers to select a model that is ideally suited to their particular environment and the taste and preferences of their consumers.

MicroMarkets, which are unmanned and unattended, self-service convenience stores designed for the workplace in companies with over 200 employees, are a recent addition to our product offering. These MicroMarkets provide a wide product range, including fresh products, coffee, drinks and snacks, and are a lowercost alternative for consumers to office cafeterias with similar offerings and limited times of operation. Alternatively, the self-checkout system in MicroMarkets is available 24 hours a day. MicroMarkets offer a greater variety of products than traditional self-service retail, specifically fresh foods offerings, such as sandwiches or fruits, and innovative and healthy snacks and drinks. MicroMarkets allow us to sell products in various formats and sizes and offer an innovative and digital consumer experience through the ability to touch products and read labels and the advanced checkout process, while requiring significantly lower capital expenditures compared with traditional PoS with impulse offerings and less complex operational and planning requirements of cafeterias. 119 -----

We also sell new and unwanted used machines, machine parts and products to customers and third parties, including self-service retail operators, separately and independent of service arrangements. Certain customers contract with us for the supply of products to stock existing machines on their premises. Revenue generated from such sales is accounted for within our trade segment. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2019, revenue from trade sales of machines and products amounted to €253.2 million, or 16% of our total revenue for the period.

We provide customers with a range of mainstream to premium coffee and a variety of convenience food and beverage products, including hot drinks, snacks, cold beverages, and filtered water, through a variety of table-top coffee machines or free-standing PoS, coffee, cold beverages and snacks PoS and water dispensers. We also sell coffee from our roasting facility, machines for hotels, restaurants and cafés (“HoReCa”), and machines directly to customers or third parties independently of any services arrangements. Furthermore, through a partnership agreement with 365 Retail, we operate MicroMarkets in Italy.

Our full service package is our most comprehensive self-service retail concept. It includes installation of PoS, regular filling and cleaning of PoS, as well as cash collection and technical maintenance. In addition, daily or weekly visits ensure that our customers’ PoS are well-maintained, functioning properly and frequently stocked with fresh products, including new product introductions. Under our full services package, we pay a fee to our customer based on sold cups or a flat fee, and we directly collect the proceeds of the sales from the PoS.

Our partial service concept primarily targets smaller office environments. Under this package, we provide the PoS and the ingredients to the customer in exchange for a monthly fee or vending fee. The customer is responsible for cleaning and refilling the PoS. We primarily offer our partial services package to address the OCS segment.
We also offer our technical support services under separate contracts negotiated with the customer, and these can be combined with our other services to meet the customers’ specific needs.

In conjunction with our range of PoS for our workplace and on-the-go channels, we offer three categories of services to meet our customers’ needs: full services package, partial service package, and supply/technical services.

Our pay vend PoS allow for a range of payment options from traditional cash payments with coins to cashless and mobile payment technologies. These include employee cash cards and keys, bank cards and credit cards, corporate cashless payment systems and mobile phone payments, including Selecta eWallet, which we introduced in the summer 2018 as a lower cost (to us) alternative to other contactless payment systems, and the Argenta App (described below). Cash card and key options are relatively common among our PoS located in offices or other private points of sale due to the ability to set different prices for different consumers, such as company personnel and visitors. As the growth in the use of alternative payment methods accelerates, credit card and mobile phone payment options are more frequently included in our PoS located at publicly accessible points of sale. We have also started to add alternative payment methods to our paid vend PoS in semi-public and private sites. Cashless payment options help to support sales from PoS and enable higher average spend of consumers than cash transactions. We have, therefore, updated our Selecta app and Selecta eWallet, to function not only as a tool to locate our PoS, but also as a method of payment at certain of our PoS, including all public PoS in Switzerland and approximately 8,000 PoS in Italy. Similarly, in addition to being a cashless method of payment, the Argenta App is designed to feature a variety of promos and a loyalty program to incentivize the repeated use of Argenta’s PoS. As of June 30, 2019, we had approximately 42,287 cashless devices. Certain customers in our private channel make our PoS available to their employees on a free vend or partially subsidized basis. This is particularly true for office coffee machines and is more common among our customers in Northern European and Scandinavian countries.

The Unattended SSR Market is characterized by fragmentation and intense competition on a local level. We are one of the very few self-service retail operators active on a pan-European level. We are the leading routebased unattended self-service coffee and convenience food provider in Europe by revenue, with operations in 16 countries across Europe. We compete with regional players in Europe such as Kaffeepartner, Dallmayr, IVS 120 ----- and Daltys, among others, and with Nespresso and JDE and other OCS providers, in our workplace business channel. In addition, we compete against a large number of small players that operate a few PoS on a local or regional basis, particularly in our workplace channel. See “Industry and Market Data” and “Risk Factors—Risks _Related to Our Business—We operate in a highly competitive market, and if we do not compete effectively, we may lose market share or be unable to maintain or increase prices for our products and services.”_

We serve a large base of public, semi-public and private customers, including companies, manufacturing, logistics, and office environments, hospitals and universities, hotels, restaurants and cafés, as well as networks of gas stations, airports, train and subway stations. We broadly segregate our customers into workplace and on-the-go customers. Our customers in our North region are predominantly workplace coffee focused, while our Central region customers are on-the-go focused, and our South, UK, and Ireland region customers are predominantly comprised of private customers. We aim to further expand our customer base and, for example, we have recently won or renewed contracts with Madrid Airport in Spain, Amsterdam UMC hospital and the National Police in the Netherlands, Texaco (fuel provider) in Belgium, Volvo (car manufacturer) in Sweden, Welcome Break (motorway services operator) and Coca Cola European Partners in the UK and the Pathé Gaumont Cinema chain in France. For public customers and, to a very limited extent, large private customers, we generally pay vending fees to place our PoS on their premises. Vending fee arrangements include fixed or variable fees (based on a percentage of revenue from vends) as well as a combination of the two. They are based on a number of factors, including tender specifications for public bids, competitive pressure, contract length, offers by competitors, expected revenue, locations and the demographics of the relevant locations. Our extended experience in the self-service retail operator industry provides us with insight to help determine competitive yet prudent vending fee levels. Vending fees are typically higher for countries with a higher share of public PoS in their portfolio, given that these fees refer to the consideration paid to customers for the use of their premises. In addition to originating new customer business, our sales teams coordinate and monitor the renewal of customer contracts and the public tenders in which we participate. Approximately an average of 20% of our contracts are up for renewal each year. In our private self-service retail operations (including our OCS services), typical customer contract terms range from three to five years. Our contracts with public customers are frequently longer, typically ranging from five to ten years. Our customer contracts typically provide us with the exclusive right to install and operate PoS on our customer’s premises, although certain contracts with public customers do not include such exclusivity rights. Our customer contracts generally automatically renew for a period of one or two years at the end of the initial term in the absence of notice of termination. The notice period for termination of customer contracts is typically three or six months for each contracting party. In the event of a breach of contract that has not been remedied within one month from the provision of notice of the breach, our customer contracts commonly allow for termination by the non-breaching party at any time. We believe our reputation for quality products, innovation and customer service has enabled us to form strong and long lasting customer relationships across a broad range of customers. We believe this is also evident in our overall average customer retention rate. We estimate that our retention rate was approximately 95.9% for the twelve months ended June 30, 2019, without taking into account the Express Vending Acquisition, which is an increase of approximately 1.8% compared to the same period in 2018. 121 ----- In terms of revenue, we maintain a low customer concentration; for example, for the twelve months ended June 30, 2019, our top ten customers accounted for 9.0% of our revenue, and no single customer accounted for more than approximately 1.5% of our revenue for the same period. The following table presents information related to our top ten customers for the twelve months ended June 30, 2019:

Subsection Title: Longstanding Relationships with Our Customers #** **Segment** **Customer** **Country Length of Customer Relationship (Years) Contract Expiration Year
Subsubsection Text: Food and beverages available from our PoS are purchased by individuals who consume such items during breaks, as in-between meals in their offices, at recreational or educational facilities, in hospitals, schools, government buildings, while on-the-go on public transportation, at airports or at highway service or gas stations. As a result, we devote significant resources to the consumer experience and specifically to maintaining our PoS and keeping them clean, updated and well-stocked with international brand-name and local products that appeal to a variety of demographics and palettes. Furthermore, we leverage the data we collect through telemetry to tailor our offering of drinks and snacks in each location based on local consumer preferences in order to enhance the consumer experience with our PoS.

Subsection Title: Longstanding Relationships with Our Customers #** **Segment** **Customer** **Country Length of Customer Relationship (Years) Contract Expiration Year
Subsubsection Text: 1 Public Customer 1 30 2025 2 Public Customer 2 50+ 2022 3 Public Customer 3 9 2021 4 Public Customer 4 15 2020 5 Technical Customer 5 14 2022 Service 6 Public Customer 6 6 2022 7 Public Customer 7 4 2020 8 Public Customer 8 25 2020 9 Public Customer 9 3 2023 10 Public Customer 10 9 2021

We purchase our supplies and stock from a number of suppliers, including from private label suppliers as well as brand name producers such as Coca-Cola, Danone, Lavazza, Mars, Mondelez, Nestlé, Pepsi and Starbucks. We purchase the green coffee beans used for our coffee roasting business from Mercon Europe SL, Supremo SA, Ecom Agroindustrial Corp. Ltd., Bernard Rothfos GmbH and Coffeeteam SA, and most volume is sourced from Brazil, Vietnam and Colombia. We choose our suppliers carefully and value maintaining a broad supplier base. For significant portions of our purchasing volumes, we generally enter into framework agreements with our suppliers pursuant to which products and materials, quality standards, terms and prices are specified. Such framework agreements typically have terms of three years. Due to the extensive variety of types and brands of food and drinks we can offer in our PoS, we are not faced with supplier concentration. 122 -----

We purchase and lease our machines from 16 key suppliers, including Franke for our premium hot drink machines, WMF for coffee machines, Evoca Group for our mainstream hot drink machines, Crane MS and Sielaff for our combination public machines and Borg & Overström for our water dispensers, with no single supplier representing more than 30% of total PoS capital expenditures. We purchase or lease a variety of different models of machines depending on, among others, the market, concept, product volumes, and the customer’s requirements. See “—Real Estate and Equipment.” We purchase our machines in the currency of the supplier to limit our foreign exchange exposure. As of June 30, 2019, we owned approximately 78% of the PoS in our active PoS park, while the remainder were operated through leases.

As part of our strategy to improve our offering and deliver the best self-service and convenience solutions to our customers and consumers, from time to time we upgrade our public PoS with a new appearance. We have two primary refurbishment facilities for such purposes located in Milan and Madrid, with a third smaller site in Dordrecht. While the majority of the refurbishments are processed in one of our three refurbishment facilities, in cases where the shipping costs for the amount of work required are prohibitive, we use external providers in the local market. Collectively, our refurbishment plants and external providers can upgrade or repair approximately 30,000 PoS per year. As a result of the Argenta Acquisition, we have gained new and more cost-effective methods of refurbishment. Refurbishing and upgrading existing PoS can save up to 70% of capital expenditures when compared to buying a new PoS.

Our Group procurement department is responsible for negotiating contracts for various products and stock, which are used uniformly throughout the Group. Such items include machines, coffee, sugar, cups, stirrers and other ancillary products. In purchasing these products at the Group level, we are able to leverage our size to obtain better terms than our smaller regional competitors. Certain other items, such as confectionary products and machine spare parts, and the organization of logistics related to such items generally remain the responsibility of our local procurement departments at the country level.

We are continuously upgrading and improving our PoS park with the latest technology. Telemetry devices provide real-time sale information from our PoS to remote data collection points. We can then use this data to improve our product selection for each PoS and our over-all business strategy based on major trends. We also incur lower service costs by collecting such data as we avoid unnecessary trips to already well-stocked PoS. Additionally, real time inventory monitoring allows us to avoid stock-outs and lost sales. Approximately 29% of our eligible PoS park has already been upgraded with telemetry devices as of June 30, 2019, while we aim to roll-out telemetry to all eligible PoS across the footprint. The number of PoS that include telemetry devices has increased to 65,813 as of June 30, 2019, from 9,643, 21,573, and 41,612 as of September 30, 2016, 2017 and 2018, respectively. We are also upgrading our PoS to support cashless technology to enhance check-out experience at the point of sale by providing access to non-cash payment methods, i.e. credit cards and proprietary apps. Among other cashless payment options, consumers can choose to pay with their smart-phones through our apps, including the Selecta eWallet or the Argenta App. See “—Payment Options.” We have been steadily increasing the number of our PoS equipped with cashless payments, with a cost of approximately €150 to €300 to upgrade each PoS, depending on the type of payment system and PoS, and approximately 20% of our eligible PoS park has already been upgraded as of June 30, 2019. As of June 30, 2019, we had approximately 42,287 cashless devices, primarily located in public locations.

Our sales and marketing activities are largely organized on a decentralized basis. While our best practices, brand guidelines and sales and marketing concepts are developed centrally at our office in Cham, Switzerland, the implementation of such practices and concepts is conducted at the country level. Similarly, the organization of our sales and marketing teams varies by country. In some countries, particularly the smaller countries in which we operate, the head functions in sales and marketing are combined in one role. In larger countries, we typically have distinct sales and marketing directors responsible for the respective activities, including setting the budgets and oversight of small teams of sales and marketing representatives focused on our customers and services in that country. At a Group level, we incentivize our sales force to focus on increasing turnover contribution margins, contract length, and customer retention. Following the integration of the Pelican Rouge Group and the Argenta Group, we have developed strategic initiatives to increase sales efficiency (particularly in France and in the UK), such as increased focus on customer satisfaction, systematic approach to gathering customer feedback, introduction of training and incentivizing staff based on customer satisfaction and local sales team offering specifically tailored propositions to new customers. We have rolled out a strategic sales acceleration program in Italy, the Netherlands, Sweden, Switzerland and the UK as a result of these initiatives. 123 ----- Our private customers frequently come to us through a combination of channels. The Selecta and Pelican Rouge brand names are among the largest self-service retail companies in the market and potential new customers may contact us directly. However, we have structured lead generation processes in place, where leads can be generated from visit to our websites, prospects entered into our CRM tool, incoming calls to our customer service/telesales departments and also sales force cold calling/visits. The main focus of our local marketing teams is lead generation. In addition, larger private companies tender their services and we are usually invited to these tenders. Our cooperation and framework agreements with facility management also provide us with new customers and leads. We have developed for our sales team a central program coordination team with strong local capabilities and support to help harmonize prices in all of our markets. We differentiate prices by applying segmentation and deploying segment specific and location specific price strategies and to monitor and analyzing sales data collected through telemetry, in order to formulate pricing strategies for each category of products in each market, we then focus on price strategies for the top ten popular products in each market. Our telemetry data also allows for a dynamic pricing strategy, which is capable of adapting to consumer reactions in real time. In the business-to-business to consumer space we have implemented margin management on underperforming accounts and systematic annual price increases in addition to price differentiation between brand and non-brand items; in the business-to-business space, we have implemented similar systematic annual price increases, in addition to upselling products such as premium coffee and reducing leakage. We continually aim to provide efficient and effective customer care. Our business operates with the support of service call centers in each country, which accept inbound calls for PoS malfunctions and maintenance issues, and sales call centers, which place outbound calls to generate sales of our OCS and machine products and services. Our relevant call centers’ telephone numbers are displayed on all of our PoS, allowing customers or consumers to directly get in touch with us for a quick resolution of any maintenance or other technical issues. In addition, inbound calls received by customers can be directed to technicians to help customers troubleshoot or resolve technical issues in order to avoid the need for, and time and expense associated with, a site visit. We improved our average of serviced PoS per technician from 264 for the year ended September 30, 2017 (after giving effect to the Pelican Rouge Acquisition and the Argenta Acquisition) to 269 over the same period in 2018.

Our IT operations have historically been performed primarily on a decentralized basis. In particular, IT functions related to matters such as procurement, tracking and logistics have largely been managed at the country level, supported by four teams of IT personnel located in Switzerland, Spain, the Netherlands, France and the United Kingdom. We continue to invest in our IT systems in order to maintain and enhance our overall business processes. We use IT solutions in nearly all phases of our operations, from procuring machines, spare parts and products to monitoring operational processes and tracking logistics and maintenance of our machines. Furthermore, certain IT systems acquired through the Argenta Acquisition support and facilitate the use and development of various applications, information streams, and other services that are vital to the efficiency of business operations. This includes, among others, field service management, supply chain management, business sales, and finance. We have a dedicated IT department in Italy, with the capability to assist our Italian operations on all software-related projects. We have undertaken a detailed assessment of our IT infrastructure, systems, and applications and are currently in the process of implementing an enhanced IT architecture with a more centralized focus, in particular with respect to core applications.

We conduct our operations primarily through PoS that we own. We own or lease a combination of warehouses and regional and branch offices in many of the countries in which we operate. Our properties are typically leased for fixed terms of between five and 20 years. In general, our lease agreements can be terminated at our option prior to the maturity date, in certain cases with a penalty. We believe that our properties meet our present needs and that they are sufficiently maintained and suitable for their intended use. Additionally, we have started to lease our coffee roasting plant in the Netherlands since September 2019, pursuant to a sale and leaseback transaction in respect of all lands and buildings of our roasting facility. The term of the lease, in line with our other lease agreements, is 20 years. With respect to other fixed assets, we owned and operated more than 475,000 PoS as of June 30, 2019, and a fleet of over 5,000 vehicles dedicated to restocking our PoS. Depending on the country, we either purchase or 124 ----- lease our vehicles through finance or operating leases. We believe our equipment is in good condition and suitable for our operations and their intended use. We depreciate our free-standing hot drink PoS over a period of six years, table top machines over a period of four years, and snack and cold drink PoS over a period of eight years. However, we are generally able to utilize our PoS beyond such four or eight year period, with table top machines lasting up to eight years and snack and cold drink PoS lasting up to 20 years, with the appropriate refurbishment. We continually refurbish and upgrade some of our PoS to extend their useful life. For example, public PoS can be refurbished twice, tripling their useful life. PoS that are not refurbished and redeployed are either sold or scrapped. The typical cost of a refurbished PoS is approximately 30% to 40% that of a new PoS, which can vary widely depending on the level of refurbishment required.

As of June 30, 2019, we had 10,305 FTEs, compared to 9,757 FTEs as of September 30, 2018, and 9,878 as of September 30, 2017. As of June 30, 2019, 1,387, or 13%, of our FTEs were technicians and 4,896, or 48%, were merchandizers employees. As of September 30, 2018, 1,389 of our FTEs were technicians and 4,679 were merchandizers employees, compared to 1,447 technicians and 4,751 merchandizers employees as of September 30, 2017. The following table shows the number of Selecta’s FTEs by region for the periods indicated.
